PREFACE 
This Code constitutes a recodification of the general and permanent ordinances of the Charter Township of Oxford, Michigan. 
Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were ordinances adopted by the township board. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this Code, the reader can locate any section of any ordinance included herein. 
The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order, and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this Code. 
Chapter and Section Numbering System 
The chapter and section numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash. The figure before the dash refers to the chapter number, and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of chapter 1 is numbered 1-2, and the first section of chapter 6 is 6-1. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter, and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments. For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 6-1 and 6-2 is desired to be added, such new section would be numbered 6-1.5. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject. The next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division. New chapters may be included by using one of the reserved chapter numbers. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. 
Page Numbering System 
The page numbering system used in this Code is a prefix system. The letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion. In the case of a chapter of the Code, the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter. In the case of an appendix to the Code, the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix. The following are typical parts of codes of ordinances, which may or may not appear in this Code at this time, and their corresponding prefixes: 
CODE 	CD1:1 
CODE APPENDIX 	CDA:1 
CODE COMPARATIVE TABLES 	CCT:1 
STATE LAW REFERENCE TABLE 	SLT:1 
CODE INDEX 	CDi:1 
 
Index 
The index has been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up-to-date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited, and the affected page or pages will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
Keeping this publication up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised pages are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
This publication was under the direct supervision of Roger D. Merriam, Senior Code Attorney, and Connie Timmons, Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
The publisher is most grateful to Mr. Gary R. Rentrop, Township Attorney, for his cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is hoped that his efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the township readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the township's affairs.

CHARTER TOWNSHIP OF OXFORD 
COUNTY OF OAKLAND 
STATE OF MICHIGAN 
ORDINANCE NO. 119 
AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING AND ENACTING A NEW CODE FOR THE CHARTER TOWNSHIP OF OXFORD, MICHIGAN; PROVIDING FOR THE REPEAL OF CERTAIN ORDINANCES NOT INCLUDED THEREIN; PROVIDING A PENALTY FOR THE VIOLATION THEREOF; PROVIDING FOR THE MANNER OF AMENDING SUCH CODE; AND PROVIDING WHEN SUCH CODE AND THIS ARTICLE SHALL BECOME EFFECTIVE. 
THE CHARTER TOWNSHIP OF OXFORD ORDAINS: 
Section 1. The Code entitled 'Code of Ordinances, Oxford Charter Township, Michigan," published by Municipal Code Corporation, consisting of chapters 1 through 66, each inclusive, is adopted. 
Section 2. Repealer. All ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted on or before April 9, 2003, and not included in the Code or recognized and continued in force by reference therein, are repealed. 
Section 3. Repealed ordinances not revised. The repeal provided for in section 2 hereof shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance that is repealed by this article. 
Section 4. Penalty. Unless another penalty is expressly provided, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of the Code or any ordinance, rule or regulation adopted or issued in pursuance thereof shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $500.00, and costs of prosecution or by imprisonment for a period of not more than 90 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. Except as otherwise provided by law or ordinance, as to violations of this Code that are continuous with respect to time, each day that the violation continues is a separate offense and as to other violations, each violation constitutes a separate offense. The penalty provided by this section, unless another penalty is expressly provided, shall apply to the amendment of any Code section, whether or not such penalty is reenacted in the amendatory ordinance. In addition to the penalty prescribed above, the township may pursue other remedies such as abatement of nuisances, injunctive relief and revocation of licenses or permits. 
Section 5. Amendments to Code. Additions or amendments to the Code when passed in such form as to indicate the intention of the township to make the same a part of the Code shall be deemed to be incorporated in the Code, so that reference to the Code includes the additions and amendments. 
Section 6. Later Ordinances. Ordinances adopted after April 9, 2003, that amend or refer to ordinances that have been codified in the Code shall be construed as if they amend or refer to like provisions of the Code. 
Section 7. Effective Date. This article shall become effective 30 days following the date of publication hereof. 
This article is adopted by the Board of Trustees of the Charter Township of Oxford at a regular meeting of the Board held on the 10 th day of January 2007.

Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 1-1. - Designation and citation of Code. 
The ordinances embraced in this and the following chapters shall constitute and be designated the "Code of Ordinances, Oxford Charter Township, Michigan," and may be so cited. Such ordinances may also be cited as the "Oxford Charter Township Code."  
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
The following definitions and rules of construction shall apply to this Code and to all ordinances and resolutions unless the context requires otherwise or except as otherwise defined in a particular provision of this Code or an ordinance or resolution. 
Generally. When provisions conflict, the specific shall prevail over the general. All provisions shall be liberally construed so that the intent of the township board may be effectuated. The provisions of this Code are minimum requirements adopted for the protection of the natural resources and the public health, safety and welfare of the township. When provisions within this Code or other township ordinances conflict with this Code, the more restrictive requirements or the requirements imposing the higher standard shall control. Words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words, technical phrases and words and phrases that have acquired peculiar and appropriate meanings in law shall be construed according to such meanings. 
Code. The term "Code" means the Code of Ordinances, Oxford Charter Township, Michigan, as designated in section 1-1. 
Computation of time. In computing a period of days, the first day is excluded and the last day is included. If the last day of any period or a fixed or final day is a Saturday, Sunday, or legal holiday, the period or day is extended to include the next day that is not a Saturday, Sunday, or legal holiday. 
Conjunctions. In a provision involving two or more items, conditions, provisions or events, which items, conditions, provisions or events are connected by the conjunction "and," "or" or "either…or," the conjunction shall be interpreted as follows: 
(1)  "And" indicates that all the connected terms, conditions, provisions or events apply. 
(2)  "Or" indicates that the connected terms, conditions, provisions or events apply singly or in any combination. 
(3)  "Either…or" indicates that the connected terms, conditions, provisions or events apply singly but not in combination. 
County. The term "county" means Oakland County, Michigan. 
Delegation of authority. A provision that authorizes or requires a township officer or township employee to perform an act or make a decision authorizes such officer or employee to act or make a decision through subordinates. 
Gender. Words of one gender include all other genders. 
Includes, including. The terms "includes" and "including" are terms of enlargement and not of limitation or exclusive enumeration, and the use of the terms does not create a presumption that components not expressed are excluded. 
Joint authority. A grant of authority to three or more persons as a public body confers the authority on a majority of the number of members as fixed by statute or ordinance. 
May. The term "may" is to be construed as being permissive and not mandatory. 
May not. The term "may not" states a prohibition. 
Month. The term "month" means a calendar month. 
Number. The singular includes the plural and the plural includes the singular. 
Oath, affirmation, sworn, affirmed. The term "oath" includes an affirmation in all cases where an affirmation may be substituted for an oath. In similar cases, the term "sworn" includes the term "affirmed." 
Officers, departments, etc. References to officers, departments, boards, commissions or employees are to township officers, township departments, township boards, township commissions and township employees. 
Owner. The term "owner," as applied to property, includes any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety of the whole or part of such property. With respect to special assessments, however, the owner shall be considered to be the person whose name appears on the assessment roll for the purpose of giving notice and billing. 
Person. The term "person" means any individual, partnership, corporation, association, club, joint venture, estate, trust, or governmental unit, and any other group or combination acting as a unit, and the individuals constituting such group or unit. 
Personal property. The term "personal property" means any property other than real property. 
Planning commission. The term "planning commission" means the planning commission of the Charter Township of Oxford, Michigan. 
Premises. The term "premises," as applied to real property, includes land and structures. 
Property. The term "property" means real and personal property. 
Public acts. References to public acts are references to the Public Acts of Michigan. (For example, a reference to Public Act No. 246 of 1945 is a reference to Act No. 246 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1945.) Any reference to a public act, whether by act number or by short title, is a reference to such act as amended. 
Real property, real estate, land, lands. The term "real property" includes land, tenements and hereditaments. 
Shall. The term "shall" is to be construed as being mandatory. 
Sidewalk. The term "sidewalk" means any portion of the street between the curb, or the lateral line of the roadway, and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians. 
Signature, subscription. The term "signature" or "subscription" includes a mark when the person cannot write. 
State. The term "state" means the State of Michigan. 
Street, highway, alley. The term "street" or "highway" means the entire width subject to an easement for a public right-of-way or owned in fee by the township, county or state, or every way or place, of whatever nature, whenever any part thereof is open to the use of the public as a matter of right for purposes of public travel. The term "alley" means any such way or place providing a secondary means of ingress and egress to and from property. 
Swear. The term "swear" includes affirm. 
Tenses. The present tense includes the past and future tenses. The future tense includes the present tense. 
Township. The term "township" means the Charter Township of Oxford, Michigan, or Oxford Charter Township, Michigan. 
Township board. The term "township board" means the township board of Oxford Charter Township, Michigan. 
Water and sewer committee. The term "water and sewer committee" means the Oxford Township Water and Sewer Committee. 
Week. The term "week" means seven consecutive days. 
Written. The term "written" includes any representation of words, letters, symbols or figures. 
Year. The term "year" means 12 consecutive months. 
Zoning ordinance. The term "zoning ordinance" means the zoning ordinance of the Charter Township of Oxford.  
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections; history notes and references. 
(a)  The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and are not titles of such sections, or of any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any such section, including the catchline, is amended or reenacted. 
(b)  The history or source notes appearing in parentheses after sections in this Code have no legal effect and only indicate legislative history. Editor's notes, cross references and state law references that appear in this Code after sections or subsections or that otherwise appear in footnote form are provided for the convenience of the user of the Code and have no legal effect. 
(c)  Unless specified otherwise, all references to chapters or sections are to chapters or sections of this Code.  
Sec. 1-4. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
(a)  Unless specifically provided otherwise, the repeal of a repealing ordinance does not revive any repealed ordinance. 
(b)  The repeal or amendment of an ordinance does not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor does such repeal or amendment affect any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the amendment or repeal.  
Sec. 1-5. - Amendments to Code; effect of new ordinances; amendatory language. 
(a)  All ordinances adopted subsequent to this Code that amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of the Code and printed for inclusion in the Code. Portions of this Code repealed by subsequent ordinances may be excluded from this Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby. 
(b)  Amendments to provisions of this Code may be made with the following language: "Section _______ (chapter, article, division or subdivision, as appropriate) of the Oxford Charter Township Code is hereby amended to read as follows: …." 
(c)  If a new section, subdivision, division, article or chapter is to be added to the Code, the following language may be used: "Section _______ (chapter, article, division or subdivision, as appropriate) of the Oxford Charter Township Code is hereby created to read as follows: …." 
(d)  All provisions desired to be repealed should be repealed specifically by section, subdivision, division, article or chapter number, as appropriate, or by setting out the repealed provisions in full in the repealing ordinance.  
Sec. 1-6. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  Supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the township. A supplement to this Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances adopted during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in this Code. The pages of the supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into this Code and will, where necessary, replace pages that have become obsolete or partially obsolete. The new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, this Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of this Code that have been repealed shall be excluded from this Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the person authorized to prepare the supplement may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as necessary to do so in order to embody them into a unified code. For example, the person may: 
(1)  Arrange the material into appropriate organizational units. 
(2)  Supply appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for chapters, articles, divisions, subdivisions and sections to be included in this Code and make changes in any such catchlines, headings and titles or in any such catchlines, headings and titles already in this Code. 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to chapters, articles, divisions, subdivisions and sections to be added to this Code. 
(4)  Where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing numbers assigned to chapters, articles, divisions, subdivisions or sections. 
(5)  Change the words "this ordinance" or similar words to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," "this subdivision," "this section" or "sections _____ to _____" (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of this Code that embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated in this Code). 
(6)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of the ordinances inserted in this Code.  
Sec. 1-7. - General penalty; continuing violations. 
(a)  In this section, the term "violation of this Code" means any of the following: 
(1)  Doing an act that is prohibited or made or declared unlawful, an offense, a violation, a civil infraction, a municipal civil infraction or a misdemeanor by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. 
(2)  Failure to perform an act that is required to be performed by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. 
(3)  Failure to perform an act if the failure is prohibited or is made or declared unlawful, an offense, a violation, a civil infraction, a municipal civil infraction or a misdemeanor by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. 
(b)  In this section, the term "violation of this Code" does not include the failure of a township officer or township employee to perform an official duty unless it is specifically provided that the failure to perform the duty is to be punished as provided in this section. 
(c)  Unless declared to be a civil infraction or a municipal civil infraction, a violation of this Code is a misdemeanor. 
(d)  Except as otherwise provided, a person convicted of a violation of this Code that is a misdemeanor shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $500.00, and costs of prosecution, or by imprisonment for a period of not more than 90 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment; provided, however, that a violation of this Code is punishable by imprisonment for not more than 93 days or a fine of not more than $500.00, or both, if the violation substantially corresponds to a violation of state law that is a misdemeanor for which the maximum period of imprisonment is 93 days. 
(e)  The following provisions apply to violations of this Code that are municipal civil infractions: 
(1)  A person found responsible or responsible with explanation for a municipal civil infraction shall be subject to a civil fine to be determined by the district court having jurisdiction in the township. 
(2)  Such person shall be subject to costs, including all expenses, direct and indirect, to which the township has been put to enforce such civil infraction, in the amount of not less than $9.00 and not more than $500.00. 
(3)  If such person refuses to pay such civil fine and costs in a timely manner as set forth under court order, the township may obtain a lien against the land, building or structure involved in the violation. Such lien may be obtained, enforced and discharged subject to the procedures and limitations in section 8731(3) of the Revised Judicature Act of 1961 (MCL 600.8731(3)). 
(4)  The penalties set forth in this section are otherwise controlled by the requirements of Michigan law. The township may further pursue injunctive or other remedies permitted at law to enforce provisions of this Code. 
(f)  Except as otherwise provided by law or ordinance: 
(1)  As to violations of this Code that are continuous with respect to time, each day that the violation continues is a separate offense. 
(2)  As to other violations, each violation constitutes a separate offense. 
(g)  The imposition of a penalty does not prevent suspension or revocation of a license, permit or franchise or other administrative sanctions. 
(h)  Violations of this Code that are continuous with respect to time are a public nuisance and may be abated by injunctive or other equitable relief. The imposition of a penalty does not prevent injunctive relief or civil or quasijudicial enforcement.  
Sec. 1-8. - Severability. 
If any provision of this Code or its application to any person or circumstances is held invalid or unconstitutional, the invalidity or unconstitutionality does not affect other provisions or applications of this Code that can be given effect without the invalid or unconstitutional provision or application, and to this end the provisions of this Code are severable.  
Sec. 1-9. - Provisions deemed continuation of existing ordinances. 
The provisions of this Code, insofar as they are substantially the same as legislation previously adopted by the township relating to the same subject matter, shall be construed as restatements and continuations thereof and not as new enactments.  
Sec. 1-10. - Code does not affect prior offenses or rights. 
(a)  Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code affects any offense or act committed or done, any penalty or forfeiture incurred, or any contract or right established before the effective date of this Code. 
(b)  The adoption of this Code does not authorize any use or the continuation of any use of a structure or premises in violation of any township ordinance on the effective date of this Code.  
Sec. 1-11. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. 
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code affects the validity of any of ordinance or portion of an ordinance listed in this section. Such ordinances or portions of ordinances continue in full force and effect to the same extent as if published at length in this Code. 
(1)  Any ordinance or portion of any ordinance annexing property into the township or describing the corporate limits. 
(2)  Any ordinance or portion of any ordinance deannexing property or excluding property from the township. 
(3)  Any ordinance or portion of any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money or authorizing the issuance of bonds or other instruments of indebtedness. 
(4)  Any ordinance or portion of any ordinance authorizing or approving any contract, deed, or agreement. 
(5)  Any ordinance or portion of any ordinance making or approving any appropriation or budget. 
(6)  Any ordinance or portion of any ordinance providing for salaries or other employee benefits not codified in this Code. 
(7)  Any ordinance or portion of any ordinance granting any right or franchise. 
(8)  Any ordinance or portion of any ordinance adopting or amending the comprehensive plan. 
(9)  Any ordinance or portion of any ordinance levying or imposing any special assessment. 
(10)  Any ordinance or portion of any ordinance dedicating, establishing, naming, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, repairing or vacating any street, sidewalk or alley. 
(11)  Any ordinance or portion of any ordinance establishing the grade of any street or sidewalk. 
(12)  Any ordinance or portion of any ordinance dedicating, accepting or vacating any plat or subdivision. 
(13)  Any ordinance or portion of any ordinance levying, imposing or otherwise relating to taxes not published in this Code. 
(14)  Any ordinance or portion of any ordinance granting a tax exemption for specific property not published in this Code. 
(15)  Any ordinance or portion of any ordinance pertaining to zoning, including, but not limited to, the basic zoning ordinance, ordinances rezoning property or amending the zoning map and ordinances promulgating zoning text amendments. 
(16)  Any ordinance or portion of any ordinance that is temporary, although general in effect. 
(17)  Any ordinance or portion of any ordinance that is special, although permanent in effect. 
(18)  Any ordinance or portion of any ordinance the purpose of which has been accomplished.  
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 2-1. - Public notice of meetings; publication of proceedings, ordinances and notices. 
(a)  Public notice of meetings. Public notice of meetings of the township board shall be posted at the principal office of the township and at any other location determined appropriate by the township board. The public notice shall contain the name of the township, its telephone number and its address. 
(b)  Publication of proceedings, ordinances, and notices other than meeting notices. Publication of proceedings of the township board or a synopsis of such proceedings, the publication of notices other than notice of meetings and the publication of a summary or a true copy of an ordinance after final passage, as part of the published proceedings of the township, shall be made by publication in a newspaper which is published and circulated in the township, if there be one so published and circulated, or if there is no such newspaper, then in one published in the county in which the township is located. If a summary of an ordinance is published, the township shall include in the publication the designation of a location in the township where a true copy of the ordinance can be inspected or obtained. 
(Ord. No. 66.001, 11-26-2002)  
Secs. 2-2—2-30. - Reserved.

ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[2] 
Footnotes:

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-61. - Ordinance enforcement officer. 
(a)  Office established. There is hereby established the office of ordinance enforcement officer within the township. 
(b)  Appointment and removal; term. The township board is hereby authorized by resolution, at any regular meeting of the board, to appoint any person or persons to the office of ordinance enforcement officer for such term or terms as may be designated in such resolution. The board may further, by resolution, remove any person from such office, at the discretion of the board. 
(c)  Authority to enforce ordinances. The ordinance enforcement officer is hereby authorized to enforce all ordinances of the township, whether heretofore or hereafter enacted, and whether such ordinances specifically designate a different official to enforce the ordinance or do not designate any particular enforcing officer. Where a particular officer is so designated in any such ordinance, the authority of the ordinance enforcement officer to enforce the ordinance shall be in addition and supplementary to the authority granted to such other specific officer. The authority of the ordinance enforcement officer shall also be in addition and supplementary to the authority vested in the township supervisor by state statute. The ordinance enforcing authority of the township supervisor and the other officers specifically designated in any township ordinance shall continue in full force and effect and shall in no way be diminished or impaired by the terms of this section. 
(d)  Specific enforcement duties. The ordinance enforcement duties authorized in this section shall include, among others, the following: investigation of ordinance violations, serving notice of violations, serving appearance tickets as authorized by Public Act No. 175 of 1927 (MCL 760.1 et seq.), appearance in court or other judicial proceedings to assist in the prosecution of ordinance violators, and such other ordinance-enforcing duties as may be delegated by the township supervisor or assigned by the township attorney. 
(Ord. No. 63, §§ 1—4, 3-12-1986)  
Secs. 2-62—2-80. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - BENEFITS 
 
Sec. 2-81. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Appointed officials include the deputy/assistant clerk, deputy/assistant treasurer, assessor, and building official/zoning administrator. An appointed official may also be considered a full-time employee pursuant to this division provided the appointed official is scheduled to regularly work 40 hours per week in a calendar year. 
Elected official means a person who has been elected to serve in a public office of the township by the qualified electors of the township. The term "elected officials" shall also include an official who has been appointed to serve part or all of the remainder of an elected official's term of office. Elected officials include the supervisor, the clerk, the treasurer, and the four trustees of the township board for purposes of this division. 
Full-time employee means an employee who is scheduled to regularly work 40 hours per week in a calendar year. 
Personnel policy means the personnel policy, as amended, adopted and in effect for the township. 
Temporary employees means employees who occupy positions that are temporary in nature, for specific purposes, and with expected end dates. 
(Ord. No. 91, § 2, 12-13-1995) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 2-82. - Scope and effect of division. 
(a)  This division shall not affect any additional benefits provided for in the personnel policy of a nature not described in this division. Such benefits provided in the personnel policy shall remain in full force and effect. 
(b)  This division shall not affect any benefits which the township is required to provide pursuant to the laws of the state. Such benefits shall remain in full force and effect. 
(c)  The authority given under this division is in addition to and not in derogation of any power existing in the township under the laws of the state. 
(Ord. No. 91, § 5, 12-13-1995)  
Sec. 2-83. - Ratification of existing plans. 
The township hereby ratifies and confirms the validity of any annuity or pension plan, insurance or prepayment plan arrangement in existence on the effective date of the ordinance from which this division is derived. 
(Ord. No. 91, § 6, 12-13-1995)  
Sec. 2-84. - Retirement system. 
(a)  Pursuant to Public Act No. 77 of 1989 (MCL 41.110b) the township board is hereby authorized, but not required, to create and establish or maintain an existing annuity or pension program for the pensioning of its elected and appointed officials and full-time employees, in addition to the salary or wage of each appointed official and full-time employee as determined by the township board. 
(b)  For purposes of creating and establishing or maintaining an existing annuity or pension program, the township supervisor and the township clerk, with approval of the township board, are hereby authorized to sign the contract in the name of the township, subject to approval by the township board, with any company authorized to transact such business within the state for annuities or pensions. 
(c)  The annuity or pension plans created and established under this division, or the annuity or pension plans maintained hereafter, shall cover elected and appointed officials and each full-time employee as set forth in the personnel policy. 
(d)  The township may make contributions to the annuity or pension plan created or maintained under this division for each employee according to the terms of the plan created or maintained and amended from time to time, and by the personnel policy. The following contributions by the township shall be made to an existing annuity or pension plan approved by the township board: 
(1)  Fifteen percent of an eligible appointed official's or full-time employee's salary or wage. 
(2)  Ten percent of an elected official's, including township board trustees, salary or wage. 
This contribution shall be secured from the general fund of the township. 
(e)  The responsibility and method of each employee for the employee's individual contributions to the annuity or pension plan, and the method for making such contributions, shall be governed by the terms of the plan created or maintained and amended from time to time, and by the terms of the personnel policy. 
(f)  Each employee's eligibility to participate in the annuity or pension plan created or maintained pursuant to this division, and the vesting of the employee's right or interest in the plan, shall be governed by the criteria established under the plan, as amended from time to time, and by the terms of the personnel policy. 
(g)  The responsibility and method of each elected official for the official's individual contributions to the annuity or pension plan, and the method for making such contributions, shall be governed by the terms of the plan created or maintained and amended from time to time by resolution of the township board. 
(h)  Each elected official's eligibility to participate in the annuity or pension plan created or maintained pursuant to this division, and the vesting of the official's right or interest in the plan, shall be governed by the criteria established under the plan, as amended from time to time by resolution of the township board. 
(i)  Any appointed official or full-time employee, though eligible to participate in an annuity or pension plan pursuant to this section, may decline to participate by giving written notice to the township clerk prior to the commencement of any coverage period. If the appointed official or full-time employee decides to terminate such coverage during a coverage period, the coverage will cease according to the terms of the plan. 
(Ord. No. 91, § 3, 12-13-1995)  
Sec. 2-85. - Other benefits. 
(a)  Pursuant to Public Act No. 77 of 1989 (MCL 41.110b) the township board is hereby authorized but not required to make arrangements with a prepayment plan or a co-payment plan authorized to transact business within the state, to insure and cover township elected or appointed officials (excluding, however, the four trustees for purposes of this section) and full-time employees under policies of group insurance or prepayment plan contracts, or both, covering life, accident, health, hospitalization, dental, optical, medical and surgical service insurance, including hospitalization and medical and surgical service and expense for their spouse and/or dependents prior to their 19th birthday of the appointed officials and full-time employees. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section, the following classes of persons in the township are eligible for the benefits as set forth in subsection (a) of this section: 
(1)  Full-time employees. 
(2)  Elected officials. 
(3)  Appointed officials who are also full-time employees. 
Township board trustees, although elected, and temporary employees are not eligible for benefits for purposes of this section. 
(c)  Employee eligibility for insurance or coverage for full-time appointed officials and full-time employees shall be governed by the terms of the personnel policy and the terms of the contract or arrangement as both may be amended from time to time. 
(d)  If the appointed official or full-time employee decides to terminate such coverage as set forth in subsection (a) of this section during a coverage period, the coverage will cease according to the terms of the plan. 
(e)  Full-time appointed officials and full-time employees who are eligible to participate in the township's medical insurance plan and also have medical insurance coverage available on another policy can instead opt to accept compensation in lieu of medical insurance. Full-time elected officials (the supervisor, clerk, and treasurer) are not eligible to receive compensation in lieu of participation in the township's medical insurance plan. 
(f)  Any appointed official or full-time employee, though eligible to participate in a group insurance or other plan pursuant to this section, may decline to participate by giving written notice to the township clerk prior to the first day of the last month of the end of the township's fiscal year in order for the appointed official or full-time employee to receive compensation in lieu of participation in the township's medical insurance plan for the immediately succeeding fiscal year. 
(g)  If an appointed official or full-time employee waives the medical insurance coverage offered, the appointed official or full-time employee has the option to be compensated by an increase in the appointed official's or full-time employee's salary or wage. 
(h)  The compensation received by eligible appointed officials and full-time employees shall apply to their salary and is not transferable or applicable to a future employee's starting wage or salary for a similar position. 
(i)  The eligibility of appointed officials and full-time employees for compensation in lieu of medical insurance or coverage shall be governed by terms as set forth in a resolution adopted by the township board. 
(j)  If an appointed official or full-time employee who is currently receiving compensation in lieu of medical insurance or coverage elects to be included in the township's group insurance or other plan pursuant to this section, he shall be monetarily compensated, until he receives insurance or coverage, proportionately for the months in which he elected to accept compensation in lieu of insurance or coverage. This compensation shall be paid in a lump sum total to the appointed official or full-time employee on the final scheduled working day of the township's fiscal year. 
(k)  An appointed official or full-time employee may elect to be included in the township's medical insurance plan at any time. Reinstatement shall occur only one time for any appointed official or full-time employee in any particular fiscal year of the township. The township board may permit more than one reinstatement in any fiscal year if warranted by extenuating circumstances. 
(l)  If an appointed official or full-time employee is currently accepting compensation in lieu of participation in the township's medical insurance coverage plan and elects to be included in the township's medical insurance coverage plan, the effective date of coverage shall be governed by the terms of the existing medical insurance coverage plan in effect for the township. 
(Ord. No. 91, § 4, 12-13-1995)

ARTICLE IV. - FINANCE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money or authorizing the issuance of bonds or other instruments of indebtedness saved from repeal, § 1-11(3); taxation, ch. 50. 
 
Sec. 2-111. - Recovery of expenses of emergency responses to incidents involving motor vehicles and alcohol or drugs. 
(a)  Purpose. The township finds that a significant number of traffic arrests and traffic accidents in the township involve drivers who are operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of, or impaired by, an intoxicating liquor or a controlled substance, or a combination thereof, or having an unlawful blood alcohol level. In addition, the township finds that, when a traffic accident involves drivers who were operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of, or impaired by, an intoxicating liquor or controlled substance or a combination thereof, or having an unlawful blood alcohol level, there is a greater likelihood of personal injury and property damage. As a result, a greater operational and financial burden is placed upon the township's police, firefighting and rescue services by persons who are operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of, or impaired by, an intoxicating liquor or a controlled substance or a combination thereof, or having an unlawful blood alcohol level. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Emergency response means: 
(1)  The providing, sending, or dispatch of police, firefighting, emergency medical or rescue services by personnel employed by and/or acting on behalf of the township at an accident involving a motor vehicle or vehicles where one or more of the drivers of such vehicle or vehicles was operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of, or impaired by, intoxicating liquor or a controlled substance, or a combination thereof, or having an unlawful blood alcohol level. 
(2)  The making of a traffic stop and arrest by a law enforcement officer where a driver was operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of, or impaired by, intoxicating liquor, or a controlled substance, or a combination thereof, or having an unlawful blood alcohol level. 
Expense of an emergency response means the direct and reasonable costs incurred by the township, a public entity under contract with the township, an intergovernmental entity of which the township is a part, or a private person, authority, or corporation operating at the request or direction of the township, when making an emergency response, including the costs of providing police, firefighting and rescue services at the scene of the emergency response. These costs further include all of the salaries and wages of the personnel responding, all salaries and wages of the personnel engaged in investigation, supervision and report preparation, all costs connected with the administration and provision of all chemical tests of his or her blood, breath, or urine and all costs related to any prosecution of the person causing the incident. 
(c)  Liability for expense of emergency response. 
(1)  Responsible person. Any person is liable for the expense of an emergency response, if while under the influence of, or impaired by, an intoxicating liquor or a controlled substance, or the combined influence of an intoxicating liquor and a controlled substance, or having an unlawful blood alcohol level, such person's operating of a motor vehicle proximately causes an emergency response, and that person is determined to be guilty of any of such drunk driving offenses in a district court proceeding associated with the emergency response. 
(2)  Charge against person. The expense of an emergency response shall be a charge against the person liable for the expenses under this section. The charge constitutes a debt of that person and is collectible by the township for incurring those costs in the same manner as in the case of an obligation under a contract, express or implied. Additionally, the district court is authorized to collect such debt for the township and may charge a service fee for such collection in an amount mutually agreed upon by the court and the township. 
(3)  Cost recovery schedule. The township shall, by resolution, adopt a schedule of the costs to be charged and included within the expense of an emergency response. This schedule shall be available to the public from either the township clerk or the county sheriff's department. 
(4)  Billing. The township clerk or his or her designee may, within 30 days of receiving the itemized costs, or any part thereof, incurred by the township for emergency response, submit a bill for these costs by first class mail or personal service to the person liable for the expenses as enumerated under this section. The bill(s) shall require full payment in 30 days from the date of service. The 30-day period shall begin two days after the bill is postmarked. 
(5)  Failure to pay bill; procedure to recover costs. Any person described in this section as liable for the expense of an emergency response failing to pay the bill within 30 days of service shall be considered to be in default. The 30-day period shall begin two days after service is postmarked. The failure to pay may further be considered a violation of probation if the payment was ordered by the court at the time of sentencing. The township may commence civil suit to recover the expenses, attorneys' fees, and all costs allowed by law. 
(Ord. No. 94A, arts. 1—3, 12-13-2000) 
APPENDIX A
  
Secs. 2-112—2-140. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - ACCESS TO PUBLIC RECORDS 
 
Sec. 2-141. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
FOIA means the Freedom of Information Act (MCL 15.231 et seq.). 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 2-142. - General policy. 
It is the policy of the township that all persons are entitled to full and complete information regarding the affairs of the township and the official acts of those who represent them as public officials and public employees, consistent with the Freedom of Information Act (MCL 15.231 et seq.). 
(Ord. No. 89-A, § 1, 11-10-1999)  
Sec. 2-143. - Submission of request for record. 
A person desiring to inspect or receive a copy of a public record pursuant to the FOIA (MCL 15.231 et seq.) may make a written request for the public record. A written request means a writing that asks for information and includes a writing transmitted by facsimile, electronic mail, or other electronic means. Such requests shall be directed to the township clerk, who, as the designated FOIA coordinator, is responsible for accepting and processing requests for the township's public records. A written request sent by facsimile, electronic mail, or other electronic transmission is not considered to be received by the township clerk until one business day after the electronic transmission is made. If the township clerk is unavailable, the request shall be submitted to the township deputy clerk or other person designated to receive such requests by the township clerk. 
(Ord. No. 89-A, § 2, 11-10-1999)  
Sec. 2-144. - Processing of request for record. 
Upon receipt of a request to inspect or receive a copy of a public record pursuant to the FOIA (MCL 15.231 et seq.), a township official or employee shall promptly deliver the request to the township clerk, deputy clerk or other person designated to receive such request by the township clerk together with a written memorandum setting forth a brief summary of the request and the date of the request. 
(Ord. No. 89-A, § 3, 11-10-1999)  
Sec. 2-145. - Response to request for record. 
Within five business days of the day upon which a request is received under section 2-144, unless otherwise agreed to in writing by the person making the request, the township shall respond to the request by one of the following: 
(1)  Grant the request. 
(2)  Issue a written notice to the requesting person denying the request. 
(3)  Grant the request in part and issue a written notice denying the request in part. 
(4)  Under unusual circumstances, issue a notice extending for not more than ten business days the period during which the township shall respond to the request. Such a notice shall set forth the reasons for the extension and the date by which the township shall respond in one of the ways specified in subsections (1) through (3) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 89-A, § 4, 11-10-1999)  
Sec. 2-146. - Notice of denial of request for record. 
A written notice denying a request under this division in whole or in part shall contain: 
(1)  An explanation of the basis under the FOIA (MCL 15.231 et seq.) or other statute for the determination that the public record, or the portion thereof, is exempt from disclosure, if that is the reason for denying the request or a portion thereof. 
(2)  A certificate that the public record does not exist under the name given by the requestor or by another name reasonably known to the township, if that is the reason for denying the request or a portion thereof. 
(3)  A description of a public record or information on a public record which is separated or deleted because of its exempt status under the FOIA (MCL 15.231 et seq.). 
(4)  An explanation of a requesting person's right to do either of the following: 
a.  Submit to the township supervisor a written appeal of the denial that identifies the reason why the denial should be reversed. 
b.  Commence an action in the county circuit court to compel the township's disclosure of the public records within 180 days after the township's final determination to deny a request. 
(5)  Notice of the requesting person's right to receive attorneys' fees and damages if, after judicial review, the circuit court determines that the township has not complied with the FOIA and orders disclosure of all or a portion of a public record. 
(Ord. No. 89-A, § 5, 11-10-1999)  
Sec. 2-147. - Rights of requesting person on denial of request for record. 
If the township makes a determination to deny all or a portion of a request under this division, the requesting person may do one of the following at his or her option: 
(1)  Submit to the township supervisor a written appeal that specifically states the word "appeal" and identifies the reason or reasons for reversal of the denial. 
(2)  Commence an action in the county circuit court to compel the township's disclosure of the public records within 180 days after the township's final determination to deny a request. 
(Ord. No. 89-A, § 6, 11-10-1999)  
Sec. 2-148. - Response to appeal of denial of request for record. 
Within ten days after receiving a written appeal pursuant to section 2-147, the township supervisor shall do one of the following: 
(1)  Reverse the disclosure denial. 
(2)  Issue a written notice to the requesting person upholding the disclosure denial. 
(3)  Reverse the disclosure denial in part and issue a written notice to the requesting person upholding the disclosure denial in part. 
(4)  Under unusual circumstances, issue a notice extending for not more than ten business days the period during which the township supervisor shall respond to the written appeal. The township supervisor shall not issue more than one notice of extension for a particular written appeal. 
(Ord. No. 89-A, § 7, 11-10-1999)  
Sec. 2-149. - Duties of township clerk; protection of records. 
The township clerk, as the FOIA coordinator, is responsible for approving or denying requests made pursuant to the FOIA (MCL 15.231 et seq.), and shall sign all written notices of denial. The township clerk shall keep a copy of all written requests for public records on file for no less than one year. The township shall protect public records from loss, unauthorized alteration, mutilation or destruction. 
(Ord. No. 89-A, § 8, 11-10-1999)  
Sec. 2-150. - Fee. 
(a)  The township may charge a fee for the production of documents pursuant to a FOIA (MCL 15.231 et seq.) request, including the costs of searching for a public record, copying the record and providing the record, or the township may search for and/or furnish such documents without charge or at a reduced charge if the township determines that a waiver or reduction is in the public interest. The township shall search for and/or furnish public records without charge for the first $20.00 of the fee for each request, to an individual who submits an affidavit stating that the individual is then receiving public assistance, or, if not receiving public assistance, stating facts showing inability to pay the cost because of indigence, provided the individual is entitled to information under the FOIA. Fees shall otherwise not be dependent upon the identity of an individual making a request. 
(b)  The fee, if any, shall be calculated to include the following charges, in accordance with the following method and policy: 
(1)  Actual mailing costs. 
(2)  Actual duplication costs, using the most economical means available. 
(3)  Actual labor costs, which shall be calculated based on the hourly wage of the lowest paid employee of the township capable of retrieving the information necessary to comply with the FOIA (MCL 15.231 et seq.) request, and these labor costs shall include time spent for search, examination, review, deletion and separation of exempt from nonexempt information, duplication and mailing. Upon receipt of a FOIA request, the township clerk or designee, as acting FOIA coordinator, shall make a determination as to which township employee is capable of conducting the search, examination, review and deletion and separation of exempt from nonexempt information (referred to in this section as "FOIA processing"). The FOIA coordinator shall select the lowest paid capable employee to conduct FOIA processing. When selecting a capable employee with the lowest hourly wage, a determination of the lowest hourly wage shall include the employee's salary plus the township's cost of fringe benefits provided to that employee. The FOIA applicant shall then be charged for the time necessary for the employee to conduct the FOIA processing based on the employee's hourly wage, plus the actual cost of duplicating and mailing the requested documents. 
(4)  If FOIA processing takes no longer than one-half hour, there shall be no charge for processing costs, although duplication, copying and mailing costs shall be determined and be assessed to the FOIA applicant. For the purpose of this subsections the Township Board of Trustees has determined that a response to a FOIA request requiring time in excess of one-half hour represents an unreasonably high cost to the township unless the township is able to be reimbursed for its processing costs. 
(5)  These costs shall be calculated for each separate request so that each individual pays the actual costs of providing to the individual the requested information. 
(c)  If the FOIA coordinator, upon receipt of the FOIA (MCL 15.231 et seq.) request, estimates that the total cost of responding to the FOIA request will exceed $50.00, the FOIA coordinator may request a deposit from the applicant equal to one-half the estimated cost of responding to the FOIA request. If a deposit is requested pursuant to this section, the township need not commence a response to the FOIA request until the deposit has been paid. 
(d)  The township shall provide each FOIA (MCL 15.231 et seq.) applicant a statement of the bill which categorizes the costs to the township as to mailing, duplication and labor costs. 
(e)  Once a FOIA request has been fully processed and documents prepared, and the total costs of the FOIA response have been determined, the township shall not release the requested documents to the FOIA applicant until the total costs of the FOIA response have been paid. The FOIA coordinator shall treat each FOIA request as a separate request, and the FOIA coordinator shall not decline to respond to an applicant's new FOIA request based upon the applicant's failure to pay the costs associated with a prior distinct FOIA request by the same applicant. 
(Ord. No. 89-A, §§ 9—12, 11-10-1999; Ord. No. 89A.001, arts. I—III, 8-9-2000)  
Chapter 6 - ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 14; alcoholic liquor in parks, § 34-36. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 6-1. - Alcoholic liquor defined. 
In this chapter the term "alcoholic liquor" has the meaning assigned to it in section 105 of the Michigan Liquor Control Code of 1998 (MCL 436.1105).  
Sec. 6-2. - Purchase, consumption, possession or transportation by underage persons. 
No person under the age of 21 years shall purchase, consume or knowingly possess or transport any alcoholic liquor, or knowingly possess, transport, or have under his control any alcoholic liquor in any motor vehicle, unless the person is employed by a licensee of the state liquor control commission and is possessing, transporting, or having such alcoholic liquor under his control in a motor vehicle during regular working hours and in the course of his employment. 
(Ord. No. 43A, § 43-A.2(21), 6-26-1980; Ord. No. 43-A.001, § 1, 1-14-1998)  
Sec. 6-3. - Furnishing alcoholic liquor to underage persons. 
No person shall willfully give or furnish any alcoholic liquor to a person under the age of 21 years except upon authority of and pursuant to a prescription of a duly licensed physician and except as otherwise permitted by law. 
(Ord. No. 43A, § 43-A.2(21), 6-26-1980; Ord. No. 43A.001, § 1, 1-14-1998)  
Sec. 6-4. - Adoption of Section 703 of Public Act 58 of 1998, MCL 436.1703. 
(a)  Purpose and intent . This is a section to adopt Section 703 of Public Act 58 of 1998, MCL 436.1703, as amended at this time or as may be amended in the future, by reference, for the purpose of regulating purchase, consumption, or possession of alcoholic liquor by minor; attempt; violation; fines; sanctions; furnishing fraudulent identification to minor; use of fraudulent identification by minor; prior violation; screening and assessment; chemical breath analysis; notice to parent, custodian, or guardian; exceptions; definitions. 
(b)  Adoption by reference. Section 703 of Public Act 58 of 1998, MCL 436.1703, as amended at this time or as may be amended in the future, is hereby adopted by reference. 
(c)  Definition of minor. As defined in Section 109 of Public Act 58 of 1998, MCL 436.1109, as amended, "minor" means an individual less than 21 years of age. 
(d)  Limitations. Violations of Section 703 of Public Act 58 of 1998, MCL 436.1703, as amended at this time or as may be amended in the future, for which the maximum period of imprisonment is greater than 93 days shall not be enforced by the Township of Oxford as an ordinance violation. 
(e)  Penalties. The penalties provided in Section 703 of Public Act 58 of 1998, MCL 436.1703, as amended at this time or as may be amended in the future, are adopted by reference, subject to the limitations stated in subsection (d) of section 6-4. 
(f)  Repealer. All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby repealed only to the extent necessary to give this section full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 43A.004, § 1, 3-14-2018)  
Secs. 6-5—6-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - LIQUOR CONTROL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 58A, adopted Oct. 22, 2003, repealed art. II and enacted a new article as set out herein. The former art. II, §§ 6-31 and 6-32, pertained to license issuance, renewal and revocation recommendations and derived from Ord. No. 58, §§ I and II, adopted Feb. 9, 1983; an ordinance adopted June 8, 1994; and Ord. No. 58.002, art. 1, adopted May 9, 2001. 
 
Sec. 6-31. - Short title. 
This article shall be known as the "Charter Township of Oxford Liquor Control Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 58A, art. 1, 10-22-2003)  
Sec. 6-32. - Definitions. 
[The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
Alcoholic liquor shall mean any spirituous, vinous, malt, or fermented liquor, liquids and compounds, whether or not medicated, proprietary, patented, and by whatever name called, containing one-half of one percent or more of alcohol by volume which are fit for use for beverage purposes, and including, but not limited to, beer, wine, spirits or any combination thereof. 
Board shall mean the Charter Township of Oxford Board of Trustees. 
Commission shall mean the Michigan Liquor Control Commission. 
License shall mean a liquor license, as issued by the commission, or issued by the commission's equivalent in another jurisdiction of the United States. 
Licensed establishment shall mean a business, enterprise, or operation for which a license has been issued. 
Licensed premises shall mean the property upon which a licensed establishment is located. 
Licensee shall mean the person who holds a license. 
Manager shall mean any person engaged in the operation of an establishment who is, for any substantial period of time, the highest-ranking agent or employee of the owner of the establishment present at the premises, and who is engaged in the operation of the establishment in a supervisory capacity. The fact that a person has the title "manager" shall be indicative of his or her status as a manager under this article, but shall not be necessary for such a determination. 
Operating plan shall mean a detailed description of the intended operation of a proposed licensed establishment. At a minimum, it shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The proposed manner in which the proposed licensed establishment will be used and operated. 
(2)  The proposed days and hours of operation. 
(3)  Proposed crowd control, security, alcohol management, parking, interior use and layout, entertainment, staffing level, and food service plans. 
(4)  Any other information necessary to fully inform the board of the nature of the use and planned activity to take place at the proposed licensed establishment. 
Person shall mean any individual, firm, company, limited liability company, partnership, corporation or any other legal entity of any kind or nature whatsoever, or any combination thereof, whether for profit or not for profit. 
Township shall mean the Charter Township of Oxford. 
(Ord. No. 58A, art. 2, 10-22-2003)  
Sec. 6-33. - License required. 
(a)  Requirement for sale. No person shall sell any alcoholic liquor unless such person has first obtained a license from the commission as required by state law. 
(b)  No right for a license. No person shall be entitled to the issuance of such license, or to the consideration by the board of the application for a license. 
(c)  Non-consideration of license application. The board may determine, at any time, that the issuance of a new license would be detrimental to the health, safety, or welfare of the township, and that applications for licenses shall not be considered. 
(Ord. No. 58A, art. 3, 10-22-2003)  
Sec. 6-34. - New licenses. 
(a)  Applications. Applications for a license shall be submitted to the board in writing, on a form provided by the township. If an applicant is an individual, the application shall be signed by the individual applicant. If the applicant is a partnership, corporation, or limited liability company, the application shall be signed by a duly authorized agent. In all cases, the signature shall be verified by oath or affidavit, and the application shall contain the following statements and information: 
(1)  The name, date of birth, and address of the applicant, and any person who will serve as a manager of the proposed licensed establishment. In the case of a partnership, the application shall also contain the name, date of birth and address of each partner and/or other person entitled to share in the profits of the partnership. In the case of a corporation or limited liability company, the application shall also contain the names, dates of birth, and addresses of the officers, directors, managers and of all shareholders or members who hold directly or indirectly five percent or more of the voting stock, shares of the corporation, or ownership interest, as the case may be. 
(2)  The type of license desired. 
(3)  The citizenship of the applicant, the date and place of the applicant's birth, and, if the applicant is a naturalized United States citizen, the date and place of his or her naturalization. 
(4)  A description of the nature of the business for which the license is applied for, and, in the case of a corporation or limited liability company, the object for which it was formed. 
(5)  The length of time the applicant has conducted a business of the nature as provided in the response required by subsection (4), or, in the case of a corporation or limited liability company, the date when its articles of incorporation or articles of organization were filed. 
(6)  The location and description of the premises or place of business which is to be operated under such license, including but not limited to the street address and legal description. 
(7)  A statement whether any person required to be identified under subsection (1), has ever had a similar or other license suspended or revoked, the reason therefore, and the date and location where such suspension or revocation occurred. 
(8)  A statement whether any person required to be identified under subsection (1) has made an application, or applications, for another license for the proposed licensed premises other than that described in the application, and the disposition of such other application(s). 
(9)  A statement whether any person required to be identified under subsection (1) has ever been convicted of a felony, and a statement that no such person is disqualified to receive a license by reason of any matter or thing contained in this article, the laws of the state, or any regulations promulgated by the commission. 
(10)  A statement that no person required to be identified under subsection (1) will violate any laws of the state or of the United States, or any ordinances of the township, or any regulations promulgated by the state or the United States, including regulations promulgated by the commission, in the conduct or operation of the proposed licensed establishment. 
(11)  A statement that all personal property taxes and real property taxes, and all other obligations due and payable to the township, have been paid with regard to the proposed licensed premises and, in the case of an application for the transfer of a license, the licensed premises from which the applicant seeks to transfer the license. 
(12)  A statement as to the applicant's character, experience, and financial ability to meet the obligations and business undertakings for which the license is sought. 
(13)  The application shall be accompanied by building and plat plans showing the entire structure where the proposed licensed establishment is to be located, and the proposed licensed premises, and in particular the specific areas where the license is to be utilized. The plans shall demonstrate adequate off-street parking, lighting, refuse disposal facilities and, where appropriate, adequate plans for screening and police control. 
(14)  The application shall be accompanied by a general area plan encompassing a one-quarter square mile area, surrounding the proposed licensed premises, showing the proximity of churches and schools (giving distances in lineal feet) to the proposed licensed establishment. 
(15)  The application shall be accompanied by an operating plan. 
(16)  The applicant shall pay any fees required by this article at the time of submitting the application. 
(17)  At the time of submitting the application to the township, the applicant shall provide authorization for the township to have access to any and all files in the possession of the commission regarding the commission's investigation of the applicant for the proposed license, or any past license. Such authorization shall be communicated in writing to the commission, and the applicant shall instruct the commission to promptly provide all such files to the township. 
(18)  At all times during the application process, the applicant shall provide notice to the township, by providing written notice to the township clerk, of all proceedings, formal and informal, related to the application, conducted by or held before any governmental agency, body, or court, including the commission, other than the township itself. 
(b)  Investigation. If the board wishes to consider the issuance of a license to the applicant, the board shall make an investigation into the proposed licensed premises, the proposed licensed establishment, the applicant and/or its shareholders, members and partners, and managers, as the board deems necessary or desirable for the protection of the public health, safety and welfare. 
(c)  Reviews required. Upon receipt of the application, the board shall forward copies to the county sheriff's department (and/or such other police agency as the board shall direct), the fire chief, planning commission, building department, township attorney and/or such other persons, township agencies or employees as the board deems necessary or desirable for review and comment. The applicant shall be responsible for the cost of all outside consultant reviews, including the township attorney's review. 
(d)  Public hearing. If the board wishes to consider the issuance of a license to the applicant, the township board shall hold a public hearing upon the license application. Following such hearing the board shall submit to the applicant a written statement of its findings and determination. The board's determination shall be based upon subsection (e). No person whose application is denied for any reason may reapply for one year from the date of denial, regardless of the location, unless the board determines otherwise for good cause shown. 
(e)  Board approval of license applications. 
(1)  Restrictions. The board shall decline to allow a license to be issued in any of the following circumstances: 
a.  To any person who has failed to comply with subsection (a), or any person who has provided false or misleading information to the township regarding his, her, or its application. 
b.  To a person who has had a license revoked for cause. 
c.  To a partnership of any kind, unless all of the members of such partnership are qualified under this article to obtain a license. 
d.  To a corporation, if any officer, manager or director thereof, or a stock owner or stockholders owning in the aggregate more than five percent of the stock of such corporation, would not be eligible to receive a license under this article for any reason. 
e.  To a limited liability company, if any manager or member would not be eligible to receive a license under this article for any reason. 
f.  To a person whose proposed licensed establishment is or will be operated at any time by a manager, unless such manager would be eligible to receive a license under this article. 
g.  To a person who has been convicted of a violation of any United States, state, or local law, regulation, or rule concerning the manufacture, possession or sale of alcoholic liquor or a controlled substance. 
h.  To a person who has been convicted of a crime punishable by death or imprisonment in excess of one year under the law of the place where convicted; or a crime involving theft, dishonesty or false statement (including tax evasion), regardless of punishment. This subsection shall not apply if the conviction was entered by a court that was not governed by the Constitution of the United States, unless the convicting court provided due process to the applicant. 
i.  To a person who does not own the proposed licensed premises, or who does not have a lease therefore for the full period for which the license is proposed to be issued, or to a person that does not have sufficient financial assets to carry on or maintain the business of the proposed licensed establishment. 
j.  To any law enforcing public official, or any member of the board. 
k.  For proposed licensed premises where there exists a violation of applicable building, electrical, mechanical, plumbing, or fire codes, applicable zoning laws or regulations, or applicable public health regulations, or any township ordinance. 
l.  To a person who is in default of any personal or real property taxes, or any other obligation due and payable to the township. 
m.  For any proposed licensed establishment unless the sale of alcoholic liquor is shown to be incidental and subordinate to other permitted business uses upon the premises, including but not limited to food sales, motel operations, or recreational activities. 
n.  For a proposed licensed premises where it is determined by a majority of the board that the proposed licensed premises do not, or will not reasonably soon after commencement of the operation of the proposed licensed establishment, have adequate off-street parking, lighting, refuse disposal facilities, screening, landscaping, noise or nuisance control, or where a nuisance does or is reasonably likely to exist. 
o.  To any person who is unable, or whom the board reasonably believes to be unable, to adequately meet the obligations involved in operating the proposed licensed establishment. 
(2)  The board may decline to approve an application for a license based upon any of the following grounds: 
a.  Where the board determines that the proposed location is inappropriate for the area where it is proposed to be located, based upon any of the following factors: 
1.  The desirability of establishing a licensed establishment in developed, commercial areas, in preference to isolated, undeveloped areas. 
2.  Input from surrounding residents and property owners. 
3.  Traffic safety. 
4.  Accessibility to the proposed site from abutting roads, and/or the capability of abutting roads to accommodate the commercial activity. 
5.  Distance from public or private schools for minors. 
6.  Proximity to an inconsistent zoning classification. 
7.  Accessibility from primary roads or state highways. 
8.  Any other factors which, based upon the complete record before the board, reasonably indicate that the approval of the proposed licensed establishment would be inappropriate for the area where it is proposed to be located. 
b.  When the board determines that, at the time of the application process, issuance of a new license is not in the interest of the health, safety, or welfare of the residents of the township. 
c.  When the board determines, based upon the materials submitted by the applicant, the board's investigation, the reviews conducted pursuant to subsection (c), and/or the public hearing held pursuant to subsection (d), that the issuance of a license to the applicant would not be in the best interest of the health, safety or welfare of the residents of the township, based upon any of the following factors: 
1.  The applicant's experience in the alcohol/liquor business, and/or any other business that the proposed licensed establishment will be involved in. 
2.  The applicant's business reputation. 
3.  The applicant's moral character. 
4.  The impact of the proposed licensed establishment on the economic development of the area where it is to be situated, and the township as a whole. 
5.  The ability of law enforcement personnel to police the proposed licensed establishment. 
6.  The potential impact of the proposed licensed establishment on law enforcement within the township generally. 
7.  The potential impact of the proposed licensed establishment on the safety within the township. 
8.  If the application is for a license for an existing establishment, the history and reputation of that establishment. 
9.  The compatibility of the proposed licensed establishment within the surrounding land use and architecture. 
10.  Sewer capacity available for the proposed licensed premises. 
11.  Any other factors which, based upon the complete record before the board, reasonably indicate that the approval of the license would be a detriment to the health, safety, and welfare of the township. 
(f)  Conditions and agreements. 
(1)  Conditional approval. 
a.  All license approvals granted by the board shall be conditioned upon the completeness of the record before the board. If, after board approval but before the license is issued by the commission, any information is brought to the board's attention regarding the application, the board may rescind its approval of the license. 
b.  During the period between board approval of the license and issuance of the license by the commission, the applicant shall inform the township if there is any change to any of the information provided under subsection (a). 
(2)  The board may place additional conditions upon the granting of a license, and/or may require the applicant to enter into additional agreements as the board deems, in the board's sole discretion, to be necessary or desirable for the protection of the public health, safety and welfare. 
(g)  Term of license. Approval of a license shall be for a period of one year, subject to renewal, nonrenewal, and/or revocation, at the discretion of the township board, based upon compliance with the requirements of this article as set forth herein. 
(Ord. No. 58A, art. 4, 10-22-2003)  
Sec. 6-35. - Communications with commission. 
No officer, agent, trustee, or official of the township shall make a recommendation to the commission, positive or negative, regarding a pending application for a license within the township without the authorization of the board. 
(Ord. No. 58A, art. 5, 10-22-2003)  
Sec. 6-36. - Operation of licensed establishment. 
(a)  Inspections.
