All licensees shall make the licensed premises available for inspection and search by all commission investigators and local law enforcement officers designated by the state, county, or township, or any other township agent, during regular business hours or when the licensed premises are occupied by a licensee or a clerk, servant, agent or employee of the licensee. Evidence of a violation discovered pursuant to this article may be seized and used in an administrative or court proceeding, or in any hearing before the board. Furthermore, all prospective licensees and applicants shall make the premises available for inspection by the township's representatives so as to establish compliance with all applicable building, electrical, mechanical, plumbing, fire, zoning, sanitation, and public health regulations and/or any other applicable township ordinance or regulation, including this article. 
(b)  Nudity. 
(1)  No person, while appearing in a state of nudity shall frequent, loiter, work for or perform in any licensed establishment or upon any licensed premises. No licensee or manager of any such establishment shall allow the presence in such establishment of any person who violates the provisions of this section. 
(2)  "Nudity," for purposes of this subsection, shall be defined to be the exposure by view of persons, of any of the following body parts, either directly or indirectly, including but not limited to exposure, see-through clothing articles or body stockings: 
a.  The whole or part of the pubic region; 
b.  The whole or part of the anus; 
c.  The whole or part of the buttocks; 
d.  The whole or part of the genitals; 
e.  The breast area including nipple, or more than one-half of the area of the breast. 
(Ord. No. 58A, art. 6, 10-22-2003)  
Sec. 6-37. - Commission materials and proceedings. 
(a)  Licensees shall instruct the commission, in writing, to promptly provide to the township all materials generated and received in connection with their respective licenses, and notice of all commission proceedings regarding the licensee and/or license. 
(b)  At all times, a licensee shall provide notice to the township, by providing written notice to the township clerk, of all proceedings, formal and informal, related to the license, conducted by or held before any governmental agency, body, or court, including the commission, other than the township itself. 
(Ord. No. 58A, art. 7, 10-22-2003)  
Sec. 6-38. - Insurance. 
Licensees shall provide and keep in force a comprehensive policy of liability insurance, covering both injuries to persons and property, in the amount of not less than $1,000,000.00 per occurrence. Licensees shall provide a current proof of insurance to the township clerk upon request, and said policy shall further require notification to the township 30 days prior to the termination or expiration of such policy. 
(Ord. No. 58A, art. 8, 10-22-2003)  
Sec. 6-39. - Change from representation. 
(a)  Deviation from representation. If, for any reason, a licensee acts, or intends to act, contrary to a representation made in connection with its license application, the licensee shall so inform the board. The board may approve such deviation, decline to approve such deviation, approve the deviation provisionally, or approve the deviation conditionally. 
(b)  Alteration of operating plan. After the issuance of a license, the licensee may amend its operating plan only with the permission of the board. 
(Ord. No. 58A, art. 9, 10-22-2003)  
Sec. 6-40. - Transfer or sale of license. 
Licenses shall be transferred or sold pursuant to the procedures and regulations of the commission and state law, unless the board determines that an objection to the transfer is appropriate for any reason that would justify the denial of a license application, or the nonrenewal or revocation of a license. Anyone wishing to transfer a license or to obtain a license by transfer or sale shall first comply with the requirements set forth herein pertaining to new licenses. No license may be transferred unless said transfer has been pre-approved by the board. 
(Ord. No. 58A, art. 10, 10-22-2003)  
Sec. 6-41. - License renewals. 
Licenses shall be renewed on an annual basis pursuant to the procedures of the Michigan Liquor Control Commission, unless the board determines an objection to the renewal is appropriate as set forth in section 6-42. The board may require, at its sole discretion, annual review of the operating plan and performance of any licensee, a public hearing, reviews of the history of the establishment and licensee, and/or comment from township agencies, officers, employees or others regarding the performance of the licensee. 
(Ord. No. 58A, art. 11, 10-22-2003)  
Sec. 6-42. - Recommendation of revocation or nonrenewal of licenses. 
(a)  Grounds. The township board may object to the renewal, and/or request revocation, of a license if the board determines that the continued possession of the license by the licensee would not be in the best interest of the public, and would be contrary to the health, safety and welfare of township residents and the general public. Grounds for such a determination shall include one or more of the following: 
(1)  The licensee, during the period for which the license is issued, would not be eligible for such license upon a first application. 
(2)  Failure of the licensee to permit an inspection as required in section 6-36(a). 
(3)  Failure of the licensee to comply with section 6-37. 
(4)  Failure of the licensee to comply with section 6-41. 
(5)  Past or present violation of this article or any other ordinance of the township, or any state or federal law or regulation, including any commission regulation or order, or court order by the licensed establishment, or the licensee or any agent thereof, if the violation involves the operation of the licensed establishment or takes place upon the licensed premises. 
(6)  Failure of the licensed establishment to comply with the operating plan. 
(7)  Failure of the licensee to keep the licensed premises insured as required by this article. 
(8)  Maintenance of a nuisance upon the licensed premises by the licensee or its agents, or acquiescence by the licensee or its agents in the creation or maintenance of a nuisance upon the licensed premises by others, including, but not limited to, the following: 
a.  Past or present violation of building, electrical, mechanical, plumbing, zoning, health, sanitation, fire, occupancy, use, or other applicable regulatory codes, rules, ordinances or laws. 
b.  Past or present failure to maintain the exterior of the licensed premises, including the building, parking lot, lighting, grounds or landscaping, and to keep same free from litter and debris. 
c.  Past or present pattern of patron behavior in or upon, or adjacent to, the licensed premises which is a violation of law, or a state or federal regulation, or a disturbance of the peace, order and tranquility of the surrounding neighborhood. 
d.  Any activity that is defined as a nuisance for purposes of MCL 600.3801, either by MCL 600.3801, or by any case interpreting MCL 600.3801. 
e.  Failure to comply with any permit, standard, plan or agreement entered into in consideration for the issuance, transfer, renewal or continuance of the license or any required permit related to the premises. 
f.  Violation of section 6-36(b). 
(9)  Any advertising, promotions, entertainment or activity, on the part of the licensed establishment or on the part of the licensee or its agent, and related to the licensed establishment, which causes, creates or contributes to disorder, disobedience to state or federal regulations (including regulations promulgated by the commission), ordinances, or laws, or contributes to the disruption of normal activities in the neighborhood where the licensed establishment is located. 
(10)  Any condition of default in the payment of any tax, fee, charge, water bill, special assessment, debt or unpaid judgment to the township, whether owed by the licensee, the licensed establishment, or the owner of the property upon which the licensed premises, or any part thereof, is located. 
(11)  Perjury, or any false or misleading statement or representation, made the by the licensee or any agent thereof, in the application, operating plan or other document, or in a public hearing or meeting related to the grant, renewal, or revocation of any license. 
(12)  Any material deviation from any representation made in connection with the approval of the license, except for such deviations as have been approved by the board. 
(13)  A delay of six months or more, after the grant of the license, in commencement of alterations to the licensed premises that are agreed to by the applicant during the application process. 
(14)  Failure on the part of the licensee to comply with any conditions imposed under section 6-34(f). 
(15)  If the continuation of the license would constitute a threat to the health, safety, or welfare of residents of the township, based on any of the grounds set forth in section 6-34(e)(2). 
(b)  Conditional renewal. If the board finds grounds to object to the renewal, and/or to request a revocation of a license, the board may, in lieu of such an objection and/or recommendation, permit the renewal and/or nonrevocation of the license with conditions. Violation of any such condition shall be a basis for revocation and/or nonrenewal. 
(c)  Procedure. 
(1)  Before objecting to the renewal, and/or requesting the revocation, of a license by the commission, the township board shall conduct a public hearing on the proposed request for revocation and/or nonrenewal. At such public hearing, the licensee may appear and address the board, may present evidence and witnesses on his or her behalf, may confront adverse witnesses, and may be represented by an attorney. 
(2)  Before conducting a hearing as provided for in subsection (1), the board shall serve notice of the hearing to the licensee, personally or by first class mail at the street address of the licensed establishment, or, if the licensed establishment has ceased to operate, at the last known address of the licensee. The notice shall be mailed or served not less than ten days prior to the date designated for the public hearing, and the notice shall state: 
a.  Notice of the action proposed to be taken by the board; 
b.  The reason therefore; 
c.  The date, time and place of the hearing; 
d.  A statement that the licensee may appear and address the board, and may present evidence and witnesses on his or her behalf, may confront adverse witnesses, and may be represented by an attorney. 
(d)  Written findings/resolutions. Within 60 days following completion of the public hearing, the board shall make written findings and may request revocation, and/or object to the renewal, of the license. The findings and decision of the board may be by resolution. in the event that the board decides that the license should be revoked, and/or that an objection to renewal should be made, it shall forward a copy of the resolution to the commission pursuant to state law, and shall serve a copy of same upon the licensee by first class mail at the street address of the licensed establishment, or, if the licensed establishment has ceased to conduct business, at the last known address of the licensee. 
(Ord. No. 58A, art. 12, 10-22-2003)  
Sec. 6-43. - Fees. 
The township board may set fees for the review of license applications under this article. Such fees shall be set by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 58A, art. 13, 10-22-2003) 
APPENDIX A
 
  
Chapter 7 - ANIMALS  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 7-1—7-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - DANGEROUS ANIMALS 
 
Sec. 7-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
State law means the Dog Law of 1919, MCL 287.261 et seq. and/or the Dangerous Animal Act, MCL 287.321 et seq. 
Owner means any person having a property interest in an animal or any person harboring, feeding, caring for, and/or sheltering an animal in the absence of a property interest, or any person who allows a usually domesticated animal to remain on or about any premises occupied by the person. 
(Ord. No. 114, art. 1, 4-24-2002) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 7-32. - Township assistance in dangerous animal cases. 
(a)  Report of violation of state law. Any person may report to the township offices any of the following incidents or occurrences, so long as the person has contacted, or made a good faith effort to contact, the Oakland County Animal Control regarding the incident or occurrence prior to contacting the township, or within a reasonable time thereafter; and a person making such a report may make a sworn statement to the township supervisor, township elected official or ordinance enforcement officer that the reported incident has taken place: 
(1)  After January 10 and before June 15 in each year a dog over six months old is running at large unaccompanied by its owner or is engaged in lawful hunting and is not under the reasonable control of its owner without a license attached to the collar of the dog. 
(2)  A dog, licensed or unlicensed, has destroyed property or habitually causes damage by trespassing on the property of a person who is not the owner. 
(3)  A dog, licensed or unlicensed, has attacked or bitten a person. 
(4)  A dog has shown vicious habits or has molested a person when lawfully on the public highway. 
(5)  A dog duly licensed and wearing a license tag has run at large contrary to state law. 
(6)  A dangerous animal, as defined under state law in MCL 287.321, has caused serious injury or death to a person or dog. 
(b)  Filing of sworn complaint by the township. 
(1)  Authorization. Upon receipt of a sworn statement as described in subsection (a) above, the township supervisor, township elected official or ordinance enforcement officer may, on behalf of the township, file a sworn complaint with the appropriate court as provided for in MCL 287.286a and/or MCL 287.322, at the discretion of the township supervisor, township elected official or ordinance enforcement officer, in order to address the situation. 
(2)  Withdrawal and reinstatement of sworn statement. At any time and for any reason, the township supervisor, township elected official or ordinance enforcement officer may withdraw a sworn complaint filed under subsection (b)(1) above on behalf of the township, and, after such withdrawal, the township supervisor, township elected official or ordinance enforcement officer may refile such a complaint, as permitted by the appropriate court. 
(Ord. No. 114, art. 2, 4-24-2002)  
Sec. 7-33. - Cost recovery. 
The owner of any animal which has necessitated any expense by the township under or related to this article shall be liable to the township for all expenses, including but not limited to legal fees, incurred by the township pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. No. 114, art. 3, 4-24-2002)  
Sec. 7-34. - Private actions. 
Nothing in this article shall impair any person's ability to bring legal action, including an action under state law, without recourse to the procedures of this article, and the township's action or inaction pursuant to this article shall in no way impair a person's ability to bring such an action. 
(Ord. No. 114, art. 4, 4-24-2002)  
Chapter 10 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Environment, ch. 22; fire prevention and protection, ch. 26; obstructing public ways or buildings, § 30-96; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 42; subdivisions and other divisions of land, ch. 46; utilities, ch. 62; waterways, ch. 66; zoning, app. B. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 10-1—10-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - STATE CONSTRUCTION CODE 
 
Sec. 10-31. - Election to enforce; enforcing agency. 
(a)  The township shall administer and enforce the Michigan Building Code, Michigan Residential Code, Michigan Mechanical Code, Michigan Plumbing Code and Michigan Electrical Code pursuant to Public Act No. 230 of 1975 (MCL 125.1501 et seq.) within township limits pursuant to the township supervisor's notice of adoption provided to the state department of consumer and industry services to administer and enforce such codes. The township shall also enforce Public Act No. 230 of 1975 (MCL 125.1501 et seq.) within the township limits. 
(b)  Pursuant to section 8b of Public Act No. 230 of 1972 (MCL 125.1508b), the township building official is hereby designated as the enforcing agency to discharge the township's responsibility to enforce and administer such codes and act within the township limits. 
(Ord. No. 112, art. I, 5-9-2001; Ord. No. 113, arts. 1, 2, 10-10-2001)  
Sec. 10-32. - Permit fees. 
Fees to be paid to the township for permits under the state construction code shall be as established by resolution.  
Sec. 10-33. - Penalties. 
Pursuant to section 23 of Public Act No. 230 of 1975 (MCL 125.1523), violation of the codes designated in section 10-31 and of Public Act No. 230 of 1975 (MCL 125.1501 et seq.) shall constitute a municipal civil infraction. 
(Ord. No. 113, art. 3, 10-10-2001)  
Secs. 10-34—10-60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - UNSAFE STRUCTURES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Environment, ch. 22. 
 
Sec. 10-61. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Dangerous building means any building or structure which has any of the following defects or is in any of the following conditions: 
(1)  Whenever any door, aisle, passageway, stairway, or other means of exit does not conform to the approved fire code of the township. 
(2)  Whenever any portion has been damaged by fire, wind, flood, or any other cause in such a manner that the structural strength or stability is appreciably less than it was before such catastrophe and is less than the minimum requirements of this article or any building code of the township for a new building or similar structure, purpose or location. 
(3)  Whenever any portion or member or appurtenance is likely to fall or to become detached or dislodged, or to collapse and thereby injure persons or damage property. 
(4)  Whenever any portion has settled to such an extent that walls or other structural portions have materially less resistance to winds than is required in the case of new construction by this article or the building code of the township. 
(5)  Whenever the building or structure or any part, because of dilapidation, deterioration, decay, or faulty construction, or because of the removal or movement of some portion of the ground necessary for the purpose of supporting such building or portion thereof, or for other reason, is likely to partially or completely collapse, or some portion of the foundation or underpinning is likely to fall or give way. 
(6)  Whenever for any reason whatsoever the building or structure or any portion is manifestly unsafe for the purpose for which it is used. 
(7)  Whenever the building or structure has been so damaged by fire, wind or flood, or has become so dilapidated, as to become an attractive nuisance to children who might play therein to their danger, or as to afford a harbor for vagrants, criminals or immoral persons, or as to enable persons to resort thereto for the purpose of committing a nuisance or unlawful or immoral acts. 
(8)  Whenever a building or structure used or intended to be used for dwelling purposes, because of dilapidation, decay, damage or faulty construction or arrangement or otherwise, is unsanitary or unfit for human habitation or is in a condition that is likely to cause sickness or disease when so determined by the health officer, or is likely to work injury to the health, safety or general welfare of those living within. 
(9)  Whenever any building becomes vacant, dilapidated and open at door or window, leaving the interior of the building exposed to the elements or accessible to entrance by trespassers. 
(Ord. No. 39, § II, 7-9-1975) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 10-62. - Prohibition. 
It shall be unlawful for any owner or agent thereof to keep or maintain any dwelling or part thereof which is a dangerous building as defined in section 10-61. 
(Ord. No. 39, § I, 7-9-1975)  
Sec. 10-63. - Notices. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, when the whole or any part of any building or structure is found to be in a dangerous or unsafe condition, the enforcing agency shall issue a notice of the dangerous and unsafe condition. 
(b)  Such notice shall be directed to the owner, agent or lessee registered with the enforcing agency in accordance with law. If no owner, agent or lessee has been registered, then the notice shall be directed to each owner of or party in interest in the building in whose name the property appears on the last township tax assessment records. 
(c)  The notice shall specify the time and place of a hearing on the condition of the building or structure at which time and place the person to whom the notice is directed shall have the opportunity to show cause why the building or structure should not be ordered to be demolished or otherwise made safe. 
(d)  The hearing officer shall be appointed by the township supervisor to serve at his pleasure. The enforcing agency shall file a copy of the notice of the dangerous and unsafe condition with the hearing officer. 
(e)  All notices shall be in writing and shall be served upon the person to whom they are directed personally, or in lieu of personal service may be mailed by certified mail, return receipt requested, addressed to such owner or party in interest at the address shown on the tax records, at least ten days before the date of the hearing described in the notice. If any person to whom a notice is directed is not personally served, in addition to mailing the notice, a copy thereof shall be posted upon a conspicuous part of the building or structure. 
(Ord. No. 39, § III, 7-9-1975)  
Sec. 10-64. - Hearing; order by township board; lien. 
(a)  The hearing officer shall take testimony of the enforcing agency, the owner of the property and any interested party. The hearing officer shall render his decision either closing the proceedings or ordering the building to be demolished or otherwise made safe. 
(b)  If it is determined by the hearing officer that the building or structure should be demolished or otherwise made safe, he shall so order, fixing a time in the order for the owner, agent or lessee to comply therewith. 
(c)  If the owner, agent or lessee fails to appear or neglects or refuses to comply with the order, the hearing officer shall file a report of his findings and a copy of his order with the township board and request that the necessary action be taken to demolish or otherwise make safe the building or structure. A copy of the findings and order of the hearing officer shall be served on the owner, agent or lessee in the manner prescribed in section 10-63. 
(d)  The township board shall fix a date for the hearing reviewing the findings and order of the hearing officer, and shall give notice to the owner, agent or lessee in the manner prescribed in section 10-63 of the time and place of the hearing. At the hearing, the owner, agent or lessee shall be given the opportunity to show cause why the building should not be demolished or otherwise made safe and the township board shall either approve, disapprove or modify the order for the demolition or making safe of the building or structure. 
(e)  The cost of the demolition or making the building safe shall be a lien against the real property and shall be reported to the assessing officer of the township, who shall assess the cost against the property on which the building or structure is located. 
(f)  The owner or party in interest in whose name the property appears upon the last local tax assessment records shall be notified of the amount of such cost by first class mail at the address shown on the records. If he fails to pay the cost within 30 days after mailing by the assessor of the notice of the amount thereof, the assessor shall add the cost to the next tax roll of the township and the cost shall be collected in the same manner in all respects as provided by law for the collection of taxes by the township. 
(Ord. No. 39, § IV, 7-9-1975)  
Sec. 10-65. - Appeals. 
An owner aggrieved by any final decision or order of the township board under section 10-64 may appeal the decision or order to the circuit court by filing a petition for an order of superintending control within 20 days from the date of the decision. 
(Ord. No. 39, § V, 7-9-1975)  
Secs. 10-66—10-90. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - BUILDING NUMBERING 
 
Sec. 10-91. - Enforcement. 
It shall be the duty of the building department of the township to enforce this article. Existing structures affected by this article shall be required to be in compliance within three months of January 14, 1987, except that incorrectly numbered premises shall be corrected immediately. New structures shall be brought into compliance upon completion. Upon notification of noncompliance, the owner, occupant or agent in charge of the premises shall have seven days to install approved numbers. Failure to comply shall be a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 64, § 6, 1-14-1987)  
Sec. 10-92. - Assignment of numbers. 
The principal building on each premises fronting on a township street or road shall bear a distinctive street number as assigned by the township. The appropriate street number for each new building constructed shall be issued by the township. 
(Ord. No. 64, § 1, 1-14-1987)  
Sec. 10-93. - Duty to place and maintain numbers. 
It shall be the duty of each owner, occupant or agent in charge of a building, premises or dwelling unit to place and maintain the correct identifying number on the front (or rear identification when required) of any building, residence or premises, and to properly identify by letter or number each unit of a multiple-dwelling residence. 
(Ord. No. 64, § 2, 1-14-1987)  
Sec. 10-94. - Location of numbers. 
(a)  Approved numbers shall be placed on all new and existing buildings in such a position near the principal entrance, no less than five feet above the ground, so as to be readily visible and legible from a vehicle on the street fronting the property. 
(b)  Approved numbers shall be placed on or near the principal entrance of each unit so as to readily and adequately identify each unit. 
(c)  Approved numbers shall be placed on all new and existing commercial or industrial buildings located on premises that have frontage on two parallel streets in such a position anywhere on the rear of such building, no less than five feet and not more than 12 feet above the ground, so as to be visible and legible from a vehicle on the street to the rear of such building. 
(d)  If premises are located at a distance making three-inch letters indiscernible from the closest public roadway, then a second numerical sign (not a mailbox post) must be located nearest the point of access to the premises discernible from nearest public roadway. 
(Ord. No. 64, § 3, 1-14-1987)  
Sec. 10-95. - Multiple-family dwellings. 
(a)  Multiple-family dwellings shall be identified by one placard containing the building number. The individual apartment numbers of each family dwelling must be posted on or near the principal entrance of each unit, so as to readily and adequately identify each unit. Placards shall be a color which contrasts with the immediate background on which they are mounted. 
(b)  Buildings with four or more family units shall contain at least two placards placed at opposite corners of the building, which shall be facing the street on which the building fronts. A map with all units properly drawn out and identified shall be filed with all local emergency services agencies and the township clerk's office. 
(Ord. No. 64, § 4, 1-14-1987)  
Sec. 10-96. - Visibility of numbers. 
Approved numbers or letters shall: 
(1)  Be colored to readily and visibly contrast with the background. 
(2)  Be a minimum height of three inches. 
(3)  Be readily legible from the closest public roadway, and in numerical form (i.e., not spelled out in words). 
(4)  Not be mounted on a door covered by screen or storm doors, or under awnings projecting out. 
(Ord. No. 64, § 5, 1-14-1987)  
Chapter 14 - BUSINESSES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Alcoholic liquor, ch. 6; emergency services, ch. 18; peddlers and solicitors, ch. 38; taxation, ch. 50; telecommunications, ch. 54; utilities, ch. 62; franchises, app. A. 
 
Sec. 14-1. - Moral character. 
(a)  The provisions of this section do not apply to chapter 6 of this Code. 
(b)  In this Code, the phrase "good moral character" shall be construed to mean the propensity of the person to serve the public in the licensed area in a fair, honest and open manner. 
(c)  A judgment of guilt in a criminal prosecution or a judgment in a civil action shall not be used in and of itself as proof of a person's lack of good moral character. It may be used as evidence in the determination and when so used the person shall be notified and shall be permitted to rebut the evidence by showing that: 
(1)  At the current time the person has the ability to, and is likely to, serve the public in a fair, honest and open manner; and 
(2)  The person is rehabilitated, or that the substance of the former offense is not reasonably related to the occupation or profession for which he seeks a business license or business permit. 
(d)  The following criminal records shall not be used, examined, or requested by the township in a determination of good moral character when used as a requirement to obtain a business license or business permit: 
(1)  Records of an arrest not followed by a conviction. 
(2)  Records of a conviction which has been reversed or vacated, including the arrest records relevant to that conviction. 
(3)  Records of an arrest or conviction for a misdemeanor or a felony unrelated to the person's likelihood to serve the public in a fair, honest, and open manner. 
(4)  Records of an arrest or conviction for a misdemeanor for the conviction of which a person may not be incarcerated in a jail or prison.  
Chapter 16 - CEMETERIES 
 
Sec. 16-1. - Title. 
This chapter shall be known and cited as the "Oxford Charter Township Cemetery Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 121, § 1, 1-11-2012)  
Sec. 16-2. - Definitions. 
[The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
Burial rights certificate shall mean a certificate which grants the right of burial in a grave. 
Cemetery shall mean a burial ground for earth interments. 
Cemetery services shall mean all services offered to the public, including grave opening, closings and foundation installation. 
Cremains shall mean the container and incinerated body of the deceased person. 
Grave or grave site shall consist of a single burial space, consisting of a land area of approximately four feet wide and ten feet in length, sufficient to accommodate one vault; one vault and one cremain; or up to two cremains. 
Grave or lot owner shall mean the owner(s) of burial rights. Such rights are limited to a burial privilege as evidenced by a burial rights certificate. The ownership interest created by purchase or transfer of any grave or lot is a personal contract right and not an interest or estate in real property. Spouses, or no more than two persons may be joint owners with rights of survivorship to any burial space. 
Immediate family shall mean the spouse, parent, stepparent, grandparent, child, stepchild, grandchild and spouse of the aforementioned, of the owner(s), and shall include "great" to the above where applicable. 
Interment shall mean the disposition of the remains of a deceased human by earth interment. 
Lot shall mean a cemetery lot shall consist of numbered divisions as shown on the recorded plats, sufficient to accommodate up to eight grave sites. A typical lot consists of eight graves. 
Lot marker refers to any means used by the township to locate and mark corners of the lot. 
Management shall mean the person or persons duly designated by the township board for the purpose of managing the cemetery. 
Marker/headstone shall mean a marker or headstone is a stone or plaque either flush or above the ground usually used for a single grave site indicating the given and/or family name(s). 
Mausoleum shall mean above-ground entombment units for human remains/cremains. 
Memorial shall mean an object commemorating the remembrance of a person. 
Monument shall mean a sculpted and shaped stone extending above the ground inscribed with the family name, and usually used to mark multiple grave sites. 
Resident shall mean any person who has legal or official ownership, individually or jointly with another, of any real property which is subject to assessment by the township for ad valorem property taxes. 
Trustee shall mean the township board of trustees. 
Urn shall mean a concrete or stone container with an open top for planting flowers. 
(Ord. No. 121, § 2, 1-11-2012)  
Sec. 16-3. - Sale of lots or graves. 
(a)  Purchase of burial rights. Residents and nonresidents of the township may purchase burial rights at a cost to be determined from time-to-time by resolution (Appendix A) of the township board of trustees. All such sales shall be recorded on a burial rights certificate (Appendix B) approved by the township board of trustees, which grants a right of burial only and does not convey any other title to the lot or grave sold. Such form shall be executed by the township clerk. 
(b)  Transfer of burial rights. Burial rights may be transferred. A transfer of burial rights must be endorsed by and filed with the township clerk. Upon such transfer, the clerk shall issue a new burial rights certificate (Appendix B) to the assignee and shall cancel the original burial rights certificate (Appendix B) thus issued. 
(c)  Methods of payment. Grave site(s) may be paid in full at the time of purchase or paid on an installment basis. Payment shall be made by a method as determined from time-to-time by resolution of the township board of trustees. If grave(s) are purchased on an installment basis, ownership of said "burial rights" will not vest until the entire cost has been paid and no burial may take place on any grave that is not paid in full. 
(d)  Contract purchases. Graves purchased on an installment basis will be evidenced by a contract form furnished by the township with the following stipulations: 
(1)  One grave site will require 25 percent of the cost thereof to be paid at the time of the execution of the contract, and the balance shall be paid within one year from the date thereof. 
(2)  Two grave sites will require 50 percent of the cost thereof to be paid at the time of the execution of the contract, and the balance shall be paid within one year from the date thereof. 
(3)  Three grave sites will require 50 percent of the cost thereof to be paid at the time of the execution of the contract, and the balance shall be paid in full within two years from the date thereof. 
(4)  All other multiple grave site purchases will require a down payment of 25 percent of the cost thereof at the time of execution of the contract, and the balance must be paid in full within three years from the date thereof. 
Any grave site, which has not been paid in full within the time hereinbefore provided, shall automatically revert to the township and any sums so paid thereon shall be returned to the purchaser of said "burial rights" less any administrative charge as set by resolution (Appendix A) of the township board of trustees, payable to the township. 
(Ord. No. 121, § 3, 1-11-2012)  
Sec. 16-4. - Purchase price. 
(a)  Fees. The township board of trustees shall establish the fee for the purchase of a grave. These fees may be revised from time-to-time by resolution (Appendix A) of the township board of trustees, payable to the township. 
(b)  Deposit of cemetery revenue. The cemetery fees and charges shall be submitted to the township treasurer and shall be deposited in the cemetery fund(s) as determined by the township board of trustees. 
(c)  Authority to increase fees. The township board of trustees, by resolution, may periodically alter the foregoing fees to accommodate increased costs and needed reserved funds for cemetery maintenance and acquisition. 
(Ord. No. 121, § 4, 1-11-2012)  
Sec. 16-5. - Grave opening/closing charges. 
(a)  Authority to establish grave opening/closing fees. The opening and closing of any grave, prior to and following a burial therein, and including the interment of cremains shall be at a cost to be determined from time to time by resolution (Appendix A) of the township board of trustees, payable to the township. 
(b)  Authority to open/close graves. No graves shall be opened and closed except under the direction and control of such individual as designated by the township board of trustees. This provision shall not apply to proceedings for the removal and reinterment of bodies and remains, which matters are under the supervision of the county health department, or other properly constituted public authorities. 
(Ord. No. 121, § 5, 1-11-2012)  
Sec. 16-6. - Markers, memorials or monuments. 
(a)  Permitted materials and styles. All markers, memorials or monuments should be of quality granite, marble or standard bronze. The township board of trustees may cause a marker, memorial or monument to be removed, rebuilt or remodeled, where and when such is desirable for the proper maintenance and orderly development of the cemetery and to preserve the aesthetic value thereof. In the event that a marker, memorial or monument must be removed, rebuilt or remodeled, the township will not be responsible for any loss thereof either to the lot owner or dealer. 
(b)  Township's liability. The township assumes no responsibility for assuring that ordered markers, memorials or monuments are proper for the area and for name placement on the marker. 
(c)  Monument companies liable for damage. Monument companies are responsible for all damage to cemetery grounds and surrounding markers, memorials or monuments that occurs during the installation of a marker, memorial, or monument. 
(d)  Markers and memorials regulations. Only one marker or memorial shall be permitted per grave, with the exception of: 
(1)  The placement of a veteran's marker, which must be placed even with the existing ground elevation; 
(2)  Two markers will be allowed in the event there are two cremains burials in one grave site, provided at least one of the markers is a flat marker placed even with the existing ground elevation. 
(e)  Monument regulations. No monument will be allowed on any single grave site. All monuments must face the east or west direction. The township board of trustees must approve any variations in size, and/or location including the height and weight to prevent the monument from toppling over. 
(f)  Foundations. The foundation upon which any marker, memorial or monument must be placed, shall be constructed by such individual as designated by the township board of trustees, per specifications from the clerk's office, and shall be billed by the township to the grave owner or the deceased member's family at the rate set by resolution (Appendix A) by the township board of trustees. Orders for foundations shall be placed a minimum of 30 days in advance of delivery of the marker/memorial or monument. Foundations shall not be poured during the winter months, nor for a period of 60 days from the date of the burial to allow sufficient time for the ground to settle. 
(g)  Payment of foundation fees. No marker, memorial or monument may be placed upon any foundation for which there is a balance due nor may any marker, memorial or monument be placed upon a grave site for which payment has not been made. 
(h)  Variances from requirements. Any variance from the preceding requirements must be approved by the township board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 121, § 6, 1-11-2012; Ord. No. 121A, 9-11-2013)  
Sec. 16-7. - Interment regulations. 
(a)  Interments per grave site. Only one vault shall be allowed in a single grave site. Interments per grave site shall also allow one vault and one cremain; or up to two cremains with no vault. 
(b)  Advance notice required. Not less than 24-hour notice shall be given in advance of the time of a funeral to allow for the opening of the grave(s). 
(c)  Burial transit permit and fee required. A burial transit permit (Appendix C) and interment fee must be provided for all interments per Act No. 368 of the Public Acts of 1978 and Act No. 299 of the Public Acts of 1980. 
(d)  Method of ordering grave opening. The township shall not assume responsibility for errors in opening graves when orders are given by any means of communication other than in writing. Orders submitted by funeral directors for the opening of graves will be considered as if coming from the lot or grave owner. 
(e)  Removal of flowers and emblems. Following an interment, all flowers or emblems used at the interment that have become unsightly shall be removed and the township assumes no responsibility for their return to the owners. 
(f)  Interments on Saturdays, Sundays and holidays. Interments taking place on Saturdays, Sundays or holidays will be subject to a higher fee as set by resolution (Appendix A) of the township board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 121, § 7, 1-11-2012)  
Sec. 16-8. - Ground maintenance. 
(a)  Unauthorized groundwork. No grading, leveling or excavating upon a grave shall be allowed without the permission of the township clerk or designee(s). 
(b)  Plantings. The township board of trustees reserves the right to direct the planting of trees and shrubs in the cemetery. All requests must be submitted to the township clerk in writing. 
(c)  Board authority regarding plantings. The township board of trustees reserves the right to direct the removal or trimming of any tree, plant or shrub, or other planting(s) located within the cemetery in the interest of maintaining proper appearance and the use of the cemetery. The township has the discretionary authority to trim and/or remove all trees, shrubs and plantings, which have become unsightly, or overgrown and encroaching on an adjacent grave. No unauthorized trimming, pruning or removing of a branch from any tree or shrub in the cemetery is permitted except under the supervision of the township or their designee(s). 
(d)  Mounds are prohibited. Mounds, which hinder the free use of a lawn mower or other gardening apparatus, are prohibited. 
(e)  Maintenance authority. The township, or its designee, shall have the right and authority to remove and dispose of any and all growth, emblems, displays or containers therefore that through decay, deterioration, damage or otherwise become unsightly, a source of litter or a maintenance problem. 
(f)  Required surface. Surfaces other than earth, grass seed, hydro seed, or sod are prohibited. 
(g)  Proper disposal of refuse. With the exception of dirt or soil, all refuse of any kind or nature including, among others, dried flowers, wreaths, papers and flower containers must be removed or deposited in containers located within the cemetery. 
(h)  Urn regulations. An urn must be set in line with the marker, memorial or monument. 
(i)  Location of flower beds. Flower beds must be located directly in front of and adjacent to the marker, memorial, or monument. 
(j)  Artificial flowers, wreaths and grave blankets. The township, or its designee, shall remove all artificial flowers, wreaths and grave blankets remaining on the grave after April 1 of each year. 
(k)  Items not permitted. The following items shall not be permitted: chairs, settees, benches, hanging baskets, glass containers, glass-covered boxes, photos and boxes for the preservation of flowers, statues, ornaments and flower pots. Other questionable items are subject to the discretion of the township board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 121, § 8, 1-11-2012)  
Sec. 16-9. - Forfeiture of vacant cemetery lots or graves. 
Burial rights for cemetery lot(s) or grave(s) sold after the effective date of the ordinance and remaining vacant 75 years from the date of their sale or last transfer shall automatically revert to the township upon occurrence of the following events: 
(1)  Notice shall be sent by the township clerk by first class mail to the last known address of the last owner of record informing him or her of the expiration of the 75-year period and that all rights with respect to said lot(s) or grave(s) will be forfeited if he or she does not affirmatively indicate in writing to the township clerk within 60 days from the date of mailing the notice his or her desire to retain said burial rights. 
(2)  No written response to said notice indicating a desire to retain the cemetery lot(s) or grave(s) in question is received by the township clerk from the last owner of record of said lot(s) or grave(s) or his or her heirs or legal representative within 60 days from the date of mailing of said notice. 
(Ord. No. 121, § 9, 1-11-2012)  
Sec. 16-10. - Repurchase of lot(s) or grave(s). 
The township will repurchase the burial rights to any cemetery lot or grave from the owner for the original price paid to the township, upon written request of said owner or his or her legal heirs or representative. 
(Ord. No. 121, § 10, 1-11-2012)  
Sec. 16-11. - Records. 
The township clerk shall maintain records concerning sales of all burial rights, all burials, issuance of burial permits and transfers of burial rights. 
(Ord. No. 121, § 11, 1-11-2012)  
Sec. 16-12. - Vaults. 
(a)  All burials shall be contained within a standard concrete or steel vault (or vaults made of other materials when standardized and accepted) placed in each grave before interment with the exception of cremains. 
(b)  Per MCL 339.1811(1), the purchase of a vault or similar receptacle designed or intended to enclose or receive a casket, coffin, or other similar container from a particular individual, partnership, association, or corporation shall not be required as a condition to burial in a cemetery in this state. There shall not be a discrimination by price, burial fee, or otherwise by reason of a failure to purchase the vault or similar receptacle from or under the direction of the cemetery or the owner of the cemetery. 
(c)  Per MCL 339.1811(2), this section shall not limit the right of the township to require the use of a vault in a burial in the township cemeteries. 
(Ord. No. 121, § 12, 1-11-2012)  
Sec. 16-13. - Cemetery hours. 
(a)  Public visitation hours. Township cemeteries shall be open during the time from sunrise to sunset Eastern Standard Time. 
(b)  Visitation during nonvisitation hours. No person shall be permitted in any township cemetery at any time other than during sunrise to sunset Eastern Standard Time, except upon permission of the township clerk. 
(Ord. No. 121, § 13, 1-11-2012)  
Sec. 16-14. - Penalties. 
Any person, firm or corporation who violates any of the provisions within this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to a fine of up to $500.00 and/or imprisonment for up to 90 days in jail as may be determined by a court of competent jurisdiction, plus the costs of prosecution. Each day that a violation continues to exist shall constitute a separate offense. Any criminal prosecutions hereunder shall not prevent civil proceedings for abatement and termination of the activity. 
(Ord. No. 121, § 14, 1-11-2012)  
Sec. 16-15. - Damage to cemetery properties. 
The township shall not be responsible for any kinds of damage by the elements, vandals, and thieves or by other causes beyond its control. The defacement of markers, memorials, monuments, graves or cemetery appurtenances, whether intentional or otherwise, and the removal of flowers, urns or any of the cemetery equipment without proper authority will be considered a misdemeanor and the individual(s) shall be liable for the damages. 
(Ord. No. 121, § 15, 1-11-2012)  
Sec. 16-16. - Vehicles and speed limit. 
The operator of any vehicle shall be liable for any damage caused by said vehicle, whether intentional or unintentional. The speed limit established on cemetery roads is ten miles per hour. 
(Ord. No. 121, § 16, 1-11-2012)  
Sec. 16-17. - Disinterments and reinterments. 
(a)  Disinterment regulations. Disinterment of a body once properly interred shall not be made without approval of the township clerk and is subject to the orders and laws of the properly constituted public authorities. Graves shall not be opened for inspection except for official investigation. 
(1)  A permit for disinterment and reinterment is required before disinterment of a body. The county health department shall issue the permit. 
(2)  The county health department shall prepare and furnish to the township the forms for permits and applications therefore, which shall be used in the procedures prescribed by this section. The county health department and the township shall retain an application for a disinterment and reinterment permit for not less than five years. A duplicate copy of the permit shall be maintained in permanent records of the cemetery from which the body was disinterred. 
(3)  If a required consent cannot be obtained, a person may petition the county circuit court for disinterment order. 
(b)  Notice and fees required. At least one week's notice is required prior to any disinterment or removal, subject to the acquisition of a permit from the county health department. All fees for disinterment and reinterment shall be prepaid at the rate determined by resolution (Appendix A) of the township board of trustees. 
(c)  Markers, memorials, or monuments. Any markers, memorials, or monuments designating the location of an interment may be removed at the time a disinterment is made. 
(Ord. No. 121, § 17, 1-11-2012)

Chapter 18 - EMERGENCY SERVICES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 14; fire prevention and protection, ch. 26. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 18-1—18-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - ALARM SYSTEMS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 18-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Alarm system means a detection device or an assembly of equipment and devices arranged to signal the presence of a hazard requiring urgent attention and to which police, fire, or EMS personnel are expected to respond. An alarm system is designed for use for one or any combination of the following: 
(1)  The detection of an unlawful entry or attempted unlawful act within a building, structure or facility. 
(2)  The detection of fire, smoke, or heat within a building, structure, or facility. 
(3)  The detection of an injury or event to a person within a building, structure, or facility. 
Alarm system user means any owner or occupant who has physical control over the premises where an alarm system is installed within the township, except for alarm systems on motor vehicles. However, if an alarm system on a motor vehicle is connected to an alarm system at any premises, the person using such system is an alarm system user. Excluded from this definition and coverage of this section are persons who use self-contained alarm systems, i.e., a system which signals or alerts authorized persons who are on the premises of an authorized intrusion, attempted robbery or fire condition. However, if such a system employs an audible signal emitting sounds, a flashing light or a beacon designed to signal persons outside the premises, such systems shall be within the definition of an alarm system and shall be subject to this article. 
Authority means the Oxford Public, Fire and EMS Commission (OPFEC) under the provisions of Public Act No. 57 of 1988 (MCL 124.601 et seq.). 
False alarm means the activation of an alarm system through mechanical failure, malfunction, improper installation, or the negligence of the owner or user of an alarm system, or the negligence of the occupant of the residence and/or building in which the alarm system is located or of their employees or agents. The term "false alarm" also means any activation of an alarm system which indicates a crime or situation other than that which it was designed to indicate, or, in the case of a fire alarm, any alarm condition not resulting from a fire or potential fire condition. 
(Ord. No. 77A, § 2, 8-10-1994) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 18-32. - Licensing of alarm businesses. 
A person shall not engage in the business of providing for the installation, operating and/or maintenance of alarm systems unless properly licensed by the state pursuant to Public Act No. 330 of 1968 (MCL 338.1051 et seq.). 
(Ord. No. 77A, § 3, 8-10-1994)  
Sec. 18-33. - Automatic dialing systems prohibited. 
A person shall not sell, install, operate, adjust, arrange for, or contract to provide a device which upon activation, either mechanically, electronically, or by any other means, initiates the automatic calling or dialing of, or makes a connection directly to, a telephone assigned to the police department, the fire department, a township department, the EMS agency or the authority for the purpose of delivering a prerecorded message. 
(Ord. No. 77A, § 4, 8-10-1994)  
Sec. 18-34. - Separate alarm required for each unit of occupancy in multiple-occupancy buildings. 
Separate alarm systems are required whenever a single building contains more than one unit of occupancy and each unit has a separate entrance. If such occupant elects to install an alarm system, the person shall be required to have a separate alarm system for each such unit located in the building. Whenever a multiple-housing residential structure shall have separate entrances for each occupancy unit, and such occupant elects to have an alarm system, each separate entrance to the occupancy unit shall contain a separate alarm system. 
(Ord. No. 77A, § 5, 8-10-1994)  
Sec. 18-35. - Duration of audible and visual alarms. 
(a)  No person shall operate, install or direct the installation of any alarm system that emits an audible and/or visual signal for a period longer than 15 minutes from the initial signaling of the device. 
(b)  An owner or lessee of an alarm system shall, within 180 days from the effective date Ordinance No. 77A, bring presently installed alarm systems and alarm systems offered for sale into conformance with this subsection. 
(c)  Whenever any alarm system continues to emit audible signals, whether continuously or on a regularly repeating basis, for over 30 minutes, and the person contacted by the authority does not respond within 30 minutes of being contacted, and the audible signals create a nuisance or other disturbance of the peace and tranquility of the neighborhood, the alarm user responsible for such alarm shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. In addition, the authority shall be authorized to disconnect or otherwise disable the alarm system by cutting the wires, disconnecting the speakers, or disabling other components of the alarm system that are located on the exterior of the premises. 
(d)  The provisions of this section do not apply to fire/EMS alarms. 
(Ord. No. 77A, § 10, 8-10-1994)  
Sec. 18-36. - False alarms. 
(a)  Fee imposed; purpose. Notwithstanding any penalties provided for conviction for any violation of this article, and notwithstanding the fact that prosecution for a violation of this article has or has not commenced, there shall be imposed a false alarm fee on alarm system users responsible for false alarms. The fee shall be paid to the authority in order to defray a portion of the cost of response to false alarms. 
(b)  Fee schedule. False alarm fees for police and fire/EMS alarms shall be charged in an amount determined by resolution of the township board and may be modified from time to time as the board deems appropriate. 
(c)  Exceptions from fee. A false alarm shall not be charged for when an alarm system is activated by the following extenuating circumstances: 
(1)  Storms, earthquakes, tornados or other violent conditions beyond the control of the owner or lessee; 
(2)  Persons working on an alarm system with prior notification to the police department of the authority; and 
(3)  Disruption or disturbance of Michigan Bell Telephone Company facilities or motor vehicle utility pole accidents. 
(d)  Notice. The police department of the authority shall mail a false alarm notice to the alarm system user following false alarm occurrence indicating therein the appropriate warning and the fees as prescribed by this article. 
(Ord. No. 77A, §§ 11—13, 8-10-1994)  
Secs. 18-37—18-60. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 
 
Sec. 18-61. - Required. 
(a)  No alarm user shall install, possess, maintain or operate an alarm system for summoning police department aid without first obtaining a permit from the police department of the authority. 
(b)  No alarm user shall install, possess, maintain or operate an alarm system for summoning fire/EMS department aid without first obtaining a permit from the fire department of the authority. 
(c)  A permit shall be issued by the appropriate police or fire/EMS department of the authority upon completion and approval of an application therefor and payment of the required fee. 
(Ord. No. 77A, § 6, 8-10-1994)  
Sec. 18-62. - Application. 
(a)  The application for a permit under this division must be completed and signed by both the owner and the lessee, if any, of the premises on which the alarm system is maintained. 
(b)  The application shall include the following information: 
(1)  The address and telephone number of the premises on which the alarm system is maintained. 
(2)  The name, address and telephone number of the owner of the premises. 
(3)  The name, address, and telephone number of the lessee, if any, of the premises. 
(4)  The name, address, and telephone number of the person installing and/or servicing the alarm system. 
(5)  Names, addresses, and telephone numbers of at least two persons responsible for extinguishing or resetting the alarm or device, checking the premises or responding to notice from the police department or fire/EMS department of the authority of an activation of the alarm system, who can respond within 30 minutes. 
(6)  A description of the alarm system. 
(7)  Such additional information as may be required by the police department. 
(c)  The police department of the authority shall provide all applicants for a police-related alarm system permit with a copy of this article along with the application form. Receipt of the copy of this article by the applicant shall constitute notice to the applicant of his obligations and liabilities under this article. 
(d)  The fire/EMS department of the authority shall provide all applicants for a fire emergency or EMS alarm system permit with a copy of this article along with the application form. Receipt of the copy of this article by the applicant shall constitute notice to the applicant of his obligations and liabilities under this article. 
(e)  The application shall contain a statement signed by all alarm users who are applying for a permit under this section that the applicants have read the copy of this article provided and are signing the application with full knowledge and understanding of the provisions of this article and their duties and liabilities under this article and that, if applicable, they consent to the police or fire/EMS department of the authority disabling or disconnecting the alarm system under circumstances described in section 18-35. 
(f)  Upon issuance of a police or fire/EMS alarm permit, the holder thereof shall notify the respective department of the authority immediately of any changes to the information provided in the application for the permit. Failure to so notify the respective department may constitute grounds for revocation of the permit. 
(Ord. No. 77A, § 7, 8-10-1994)  
Sec. 18-63. - Fee. 
(a)  A fee shall be charged for the permit required by this division in an amount determined by resolution of the township board and as may be modified from time to time as the board deems appropriate. 
(b)  There shall be no prorating of charges or refunds for voluntary cancellation or revocation for a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 77A, § 8, 8-10-1994)  
Sec. 18-64. - Illegal use. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use a permit issued under this division for any premises other than those identified on the application for the permit. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to cause an alarm system permit to be bought, sold, or leased, or caused to be sold or leased, for any value or consideration in any form whatever. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to buy or otherwise acquire for value or use any alarm system permit, except as provided for in this article. 
(d)  Upon conviction of any permit holder of a violation of subsection (b) or (c) of this section, the police or fire/EMS alarm system permit shall be void and must be surrendered to police department of the authority. 
(Ord. No. 77A, § 9, 8-10-1994)  
Sec. 18-65. - Revocation. 
(a)  Whenever there are five or more false police alarms, or two or more false fire/EMS alarms, within a calendar year, emanating from a specific occupancy unit, such alarm system shall be determined defective. Upon written notice from the appropriate department (police or fire/EMS) of the authority to the owner or lessee, the owner or lessee shall, within ten days from the date of such inspection, file a written report with the appropriate department of the authority with the results of his inspection of the system, together with the finding of probable cause of the false alarms and the measures implemented to eliminate the false alarms. 
(b)  Failure to comply with the provisions of this article or failure to eliminate the occurrence of any additional false alarms may result in the revocation of a permit. A written notice of revocation, stating the cause thereof, shall be delivered to the permittee personally or sent by registered mail. Unless a written request for a meeting is filed with the appropriate department head (police or fire/EMS department) of the authority or his designated representative within ten days from the receipt of the notice of revocation, a permit shall be revoked and the permittee shall immediately discontinue operation of the alarm system. If a meeting is requested under this section, it shall take place within ten days of the request. 
(c)  The permittee at the time shall have the opportunity to present written and oral evidence as to why the revocation of the permit would not be justified. If it is determined at that meeting that the permittee has failed to comply with the provisions of this article, the department head (police or fire/EMS department) of the authority shall file a written finding of his recommendation to that effect with the township clerk. 
(d)  A permittee shall immediately discontinue use of an alarm system upon being notified by the township clerk by registered mail of the revocation of the permit. A permittee whose permit has been revoked may reapply as provided in this article if any and all false alarm fees have been paid. 
(Ord. No. 77A, §§ 14, 15, 8-10-1994)  
Chapter 22 - ENVIRONMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 10; unsafe structures, § 10-61 et seq.; parks and recreation, ch. 34; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 42; subdivisions and other divisions of land, ch. 46; utilities, ch. 62; waterways, ch. 66; franchises, app. A; zoning, app. B. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 22-1—22-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - JUNK MOTOR VEHICLES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 58. 
 
Sec. 22-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Inoperable motor vehicle means those that by reason of disrepair, dismantling or other causes are incapable of being propelled under their own power, or if propelled under their own power would be unlawful on the highways of the township. 
Motor vehicle means any vehicle defined as a motor vehicle by the Michigan Vehicle Code (MCL 257.1 et seq.) 
Parts of vehicles means those components that were originally designed for or used upon a motor vehicle during the vehicle lifetime. 
Unlicensed motor vehicle means any vehicle without proper registration and license from the Michigan Secretary of State's office. 
(Ord. No. 62, § 1, 3-12-1986) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 22-32. - Parking or storage in residential zones declared nuisance. 
The presence of any unlicensed, dismantled, partially dismantled or inoperable motor vehicle, or parts thereof, outdoors on any premises in the township zoned for residential purposes is hereby declared a public nuisance and offensive to the public health, safety and welfare. 
(Ord. No. 62, § 2, 3-12-1986)  
Sec. 22-33. - Time limit for parking or storage. 
No person shall park or store any unlicensed, dismantled, partially dismantled, or inoperable motor vehicle or parts thereof on any premises in the township zoned for residential purposes for a period of more than seven consecutive days, and no person shall permit any dismantled, partially dismantled or inoperable motor vehicle, or parts thereof, to remain on any premises zoned for residential purposes for a period of more than seven days continuously. This section shall not apply to such described vehicles or parts thereof that are stored in an enclosed building. 
(Ord. No. 62, § 3, 3-12-1986)  
Sec. 22-34. - Permit for additional time for making repairs. 
Any person owning an unlicensed, dismantled, partially dismantled, or inoperable motor vehicle who is repairing or intending to repair such motor vehicle may apply to the township police department for a permit to allow such vehicle to remain on the premises for an additional ten-day period from the date of notice of such violation. Such permit, if approved, shall be issued for a sum as established by resolution, with such monies being nonreturnable to the person, and such monies shall be deposited in the police fund of the township. 
(Ord. No. 62, § 4, 3-12-1986)  
Sec. 22-35. - Enforcement. 
The law enforcement agency of the township is hereby authorized to enforce this article. This authority shall include among other authority the following: 
(1)  Investigation of ordinance violations. 
(2)  Serving notice of violations. 
(3)  Serving appearance tickets as authorized under Public Act No. 175 of 1927 (MCL 760.1 et seq.). 
(4)  Appearance in court or judicial proceedings to assist in prosecution of ordinance violators and such other ordinance-enforcing duties as may be delegated by the township supervisor or assigned by the township attorney. 
(Ord. No. 62, § 5, 3-12-1986)  
Secs. 22-36—22-60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - STORMWATER DRAINAGE AND LAND IMPROVEMENT CONTROL[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 108.A, adopted May 12, 2004, repealed art. III and enacted a new article as set out herein. The former art. III, §§ 22-61—22-69 and 22-91—22-103, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 108, §§ II—XXIV, adopted Aug. 9, 2000. 
Cross reference— Utilities, ch. 62. 
 
Sec. 22-61. - Short title. 
This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Charter Township of Oxford Stormwater Management and Land Improvement Control Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 108.A, § I, 5-12-2004)  
Sec. 22-62. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article shall be: 
(1)  To assure that landowners control stormwater runoff from their property so that lake and stream water quality is protected and flooding reduced. 
(2)  To protect the township's lakes from any adverse effects of stormwater runoff, while at the same time utilizing the water holding capacity of the lakes. 
(3)  To encourage the use of stormwater conveyance and detention systems which serve multiple purposes, including but not limited to flood control, water quality enhancement, recreation and wetlands protection. 
(4)  To provide an opportunity for stormwater management and land balancing systems to be incorporated into the early stages of site planning and design. 
(5)  To allow onsite and/or offsite wetlands to be used for stormwater detention, provided that adverse environmental impacts on wetlands are minimized and provided that any anticipated effects are acceptable to the township and/or other entities responsible for regulating wetlands. 
(6)  To allow for offsite stormwater management if proposals meet the requirements of this article and applicable county and/or state requirements. 
(7)  To assure that all stormwater conveyance and detention measures and facilities will be properly constructed, maintained and preserved. 
(8)  To provide penalties for violation of the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 108.A, § II, 5-12-2004)  
Sec. 22-63. - Definition of terms. 
The following terms, phrases, words and derivatives shall have the meaning given herein, unless the context otherwise requires: 
Applicant. An applicant for a land improvement permit pursuant to the terms of this article. 
As-built plans. Engineering drawings prepared after installation of all stormwater management appurtenances and facilities provided for under plans and specifications showing the as-built locations and dimensions of all of the stormwater management appurtenances and facilities (sometimes referred to as "record drawings"). 
Building inspector. The township building inspector and/or zoning administrator. 
Certificate of completion. A signed written statement by the township engineer or building official that specific construction has been inspected and found to comply with any approved land improvement permit application and accompanying plans and specifications and/or any stormwater management plan. 
Detention basin. A structure or facility, natural or artificial, which stores stormwater on a temporary basis and releases it at a controlled rate. A detention basin may drain completely after a storm event, or it may be a pond with a fixed minimum water elevation between runoff events. 
Discharge. The rate of flow of water at a given point in time resulting from a storm event, measured in cubic feet per second (cfs). 
Disturbed area. An area of land subjected to the removal of vegetative cover and/or earthmoving activities. 
Drainage system. All facilities, channels and areas which serve to convey, catch, filter, store and/or receive stormwater, either on a temporary or permanent basis. 
Engineering standards ordinance. The township engineering standards ordinance, chapter 42, article IV of this Code. 
Flood. A temporary rise in the level of any water body, watercourse or wetland which causes the inundation of areas not ordinarily covered by water. 
Floodplain. The area of land adjoining a river, stream, watercourse, lake or other body of water which will be inundated by a 100-year frequency flood event. 
Grading. Any stripping, excavating, filling, stockpiling or any combination thereof, including the land in its excavated or filled condition. 
Land improvement. The construction or installation, of any sanitary sewer main, storm sewer main, water main (excluding individual building sewer and water leads and maintenance and repair work completed by the municipality or its designated agent), or stormwater retention/detention pond or any activity which will affect the surface water drainage of neighboring property, or any earth change that disturbs one or more acres or is within 500 feet of a lake or stream. Land improvement does not include the plowing and tilling for the purpose of producing and harvesting crops, unless the plowing or tilling will affect surface water drainage on neighboring property, and does not include mining conducted pursuant to a mining permit issued by the township. 
Land improvement permit (permit). Permit required to conduct a land improvement according to the terms of this article. 
Maintenance agreement. A binding agreement between the applicant proprietor and township which sets forth the terms and conditions for stormwater facility maintenance. 
Off-site facility. All or part of a drainage system which is located partially or completely off of the development site which it serves. 
Peak rate of discharge. The maximum allowable rate of stormwater flow from a storm event, as measured at a given point and time in cubic feet per second (cfs). 
Person. Any individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, organization or legal entity of any kind, including governmental agencies. 
Planning commission. The township planning commission. 
Plans and specifications (plans). Those plans and specifications detailing the proposed land improvement in accordance with section 22-65. 
Proprietor. A person, public corporation or authority, or a government agency that holds an ownership interest in land, whether recorded or not. 
Retention basin. A stormwater holding area, either natural or manmade, which does not have an outlet to adjoining watercourses or wetlands. Water is removed from retention basins through infiltration and/or evaporation processes, and a retention basin may or may not contain a permanent pool of water. 
Runoff. That part of precipitation which flows off the land, measured in depth of inches. 
Site. Any tract, lot or parcel of land or combination of tracts, lots or parcels of land proposed for development. 
Storm drain. A conduit, pipe, swale, natural channel or manmade structure which serves to transport stormwater runoff. Storm drains may be either enclosed conduits or open drains. 
Stormwater management measures and facilities. Any facility, structure, channel, area or measure which serves to control stormwater runoff in accordance with the purposes and standards of this article. 
Stripping. Any activity which removes or significantly disturbs the vegetative surface cover, including clearing and grubbing operations. 
Surface drainage. Any stormwater collecting on or flowing over the surface of ground. 
Swale. Low-lying area with gradual slopes which transports stormwater, either onsite or offsite. 
Township. Charter Township of Oxford. 
Vegetative cover. Grasses, shrubs, trees and other vegetation which hold and stabilize soils. 
Watercourse. Any waterway or other body of water having reasonably well defined banks, including rivers, streams, creeks and brooks, whether continually or intermittently flowing, and lakes and ponds, and/or as shown on wetlands and watercourses maps. 
Wetlands. Land characterized by the presence of water at a frequency and duration sufficient to support and that under normal circumstances does support wetland vegetation or aquatic life and is commonly referred to as a bog, swamp or marsh and which is any of the following: 
(1)  Contiguous to an inland lake or pond, or a river or stream; 
(2)  Not contiguous to an inland lake or pond, or a river or stream and one acre or more in size. 
Zoning ordinance. Township Zoning Ordinance No. 67. 
(Ord. No. 108.A, § III, 5-12-2004)  
Sec. 22-64. - Pre-construction meeting and permit requirement. 
(a)  No person shall commence a land improvement on any parcel of land without having participated in a pre-construction meeting with the township building inspector or, if designated by the township building inspector, the township engineer. 
(b)  No person may schedule a pre-construction meeting as described in subsection (a) without having first applied for and received a land improvement permit in accordance with this article. 
(c)  No person shall commence a land improvement without having first applied for and received a land improvement permit, of the type appropriate for the proposed land improvement under section 22-65, in accordance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 108.A, § IV, 5-12-2004)  
Sec. 22-65. - Land improvement permit. 
(a)  Types of land improvement permits. A land improvement permit issued pursuant to this article shall be of one or more of the following types, depending upon the nature of the work, in the opinion of the building inspector, to be performed: 
(1)  Paving. Required for all land improvements involving paving. 
(2)  Sanitary. Required for all land improvements involving the construction or repair of sanitary sewerage systems or facilities. 
(3)  Grading. Required for all land improvements involving grading. 
(4)  Stormwater. Required for all land improvements involving stormwater management measures and/or facilities. 
(5)  Water main. Required for all land improvements involving the construction or repair of a water main. 
(b)  Application. Prior to the construction or installation of a land improvement on any parcel of land, the proprietor of such land, or an agent having the written authorization of the proprietor, shall submit an application for a land improvement permit with the township's building inspector. The application shall include the following: 
(1)  Identification of which type(s) of land improvement permit the applicant desires. 
(2)  Proprietor's and applicant's name, mailing address and telephone number. 
(3)  Common description of property. 
(4)  Written description of the proposed land use and the name of the proposed development. 
(5)  Proof of ownership of the property, as well as any offsite easements for stormwater management. If the applicant is not the proprietor, then the proprietor shall provide written, signed authorized for the application. 
(6)  An estimate of the costs of the land improvement. 
(7)  A sketch of the proposed land improvement in sufficient detail and dimension to enable the township's building inspector to determine whether the land improvement will affect stormwater flow on adjacent properties, including dimensions of land, total acreage and net acreage (total acreage minus rights-of-way), existing zoning and zoning of all adjacent properties and location and size of existing and proposed lots, buildings, structures and pavement. 
(8)  If the applicant does not intend to pursue a wetland permit, as otherwise required by subsection (e) of this section, then the applicant must sign the following statement: "I hereby represent that the activity for which a Land Improvement Permit is requested from the Township does not impact a wetland or watercourse regulated by state statute or Township Ordinance."
