If the applicant does not sign such statement, then the permit shall be required under section 22-69. 
(9)  The appropriate application fee, as set by resolution of the township board. 
(10)  In addition, land improvement plans and specifications in the form and number hereinafter specified in subsection (c) shall be required in the event the land improvement: 
a.  Affects a disturbed area that exceeds one acre in size. 
b.  Requires site plan approval under the zoning ordinance. 
c.  Requires site condominium approval under the zoning ordinance. 
d.  Requires plat approval under chapter 46, article III. 
e.  Will cause stormwater runoff to adjacent properties as determined by the township building inspector upon consultation with the township engineer. 
f.  Will be situated within 25 feet of a watercourse or a regulated wetland, or will discharge into a watercourse or regulated wetland. 
g.  Notwithstanding the foregoing, the township building inspector, upon consultation with the township engineer, may waive the requirement for plans and specifications if the land improvement proposed will not adversely affect adjacent property. 
(c)  Plans and specifications. 
(1)  Land improvement plans and specifications shall be prepared by, and each sheet of the plans signed and sealed by, a professional engineer. Plans detailing parcel surveys must be signed and sealed by a licensed land surveyor. 
(2)  Plans shall be prepared on 24-inch × 36-inch size sheets and shall generally be drawn to scale of not more than 50 feet to the inch. The drawings shall contain sufficient detail to properly show the proposed locations and methods of construction or grading and any proposed soil erosion control measures as may be required by the county drain commissioner. The township engineer may require the plans to be drawn to a scale of 20 feet to the inch when deemed necessary for proper review. The plans shall provide detail showing stormwater management associated with a land improvement including the design and dimension of stormwater conveyance facilities, stormwater management measures and facilities including detention and retention basins, and all other stormwater storage facilities. The plans shall also include the following information: 
a.  Proposed changes to the land surface and existing vegetative cover, including delineation of areas to be cut and filled. Final contours at two-foot contour intervals shall be provided. 
b.  Flow routes with directional arrows for stormwater runoff from both the ten-year storm frequency event and the 100-year storm frequency event. 
c.  Proposed outlet points and associated drainage area boundaries. 
d.  The receiving watercourses for stormwater runoff, including but not limited to lakes, streams, wetlands, road drains and county drains, whether located onsite or offsite. 
e.  Calculations of the effect of the development upon the peak rate of discharge, and a preliminary determination of the amount of detention storage required to limit the proposed discharge to the existing levels. 
f.  Entry points where stormwater runoff and watercourses enter the site from offsite locations, with arrows indicating the direction of the flow. 
g.  Outlet point and drainage area boundaries for all watercourses on the site and within 100 feet of the site. 
h.  Description of the location, type and size of stormwater management facilities and measures, including facilities for the conveyance, infiltration and/or storage of stormwater runoff. 
i.  Location of easements to protect the primary and secondary drainage systems, and to provide access for maintenance. 
j.  Other detail and dimensions to enable the township engineer to determine compliance with the requirements of this article. 
(3)  Three complete sets of plans and specifications shall be submitted with the permit application. 
(4)  After completion of the project, as-built plans, in an electronic format and acceptable to the township engineer must be submitted, showing the exact location of all land improvements prior to issuance of a certificate of completion. These plans must be prepared and certified by the owner's engineer. 
(d)  Escrow fee required. An escrow fee, as determined by resolution of the township board, in addition to the application fee, shall be required if plans and specifications are required to be submitted. 
(e)  Required permits and approvals. 
(1)  No land improvement permit shall be issued unless the applicant has obtained all necessary and/or applicable additional approvals as follows, unless the land improvement does not require the otherwise-required permit or approval under the terms of the ordinance, law, regulation, or policy governing such permit or approval: 
a.  Approvals required for a paving permit. 
1.  Approach permit, county road commission (RCOC) or the state department of transportation (MDOT). 
2.  Soil erosion and sedimentation control (SESC) permit. 
3.  National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permit. 
4.  Road plan approval required: 
(i)  Public roads. Road commission for the county and planning commission. 
(ii)  Private roads. Planning commission, pursuant to the township zoning ordinance. 
b.  Approvals required for a sanitary permit. 
1.  State department of environmental quality (MDEQ) sanitary sewer permits (Act 451 Permit). 
2.  County drain commissioner (OCDC) sanitary sewer extension permit. 
3.  Permits for work within the right-of-way: 
(i)  Road commission for the county (RCOC). 
(ii)  State department of transportation (MDOT). 
4.  Soil erosion and sedimentation control (SESC) permit. 
5.  Wetlands permits: 
(i)  Township, pursuant to chapter 22, article IV. 
(ii)  State department of environmental quality (MDEQ). 
6.  Detroit Water and Sewer Department approval. 
c.  Approvals required for a grading permit. 
1.  Soil erosion and sedimentation control (SESC) permit. 
2.  National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permit. 
3.  County drain commissioner (OCDC) stormwater drainage approvals, for county drains and plats. 
4.  Wetlands permit: 
(i)  Township, pursuant to chapter 22, article IV. 
(ii)  State department of environmental quality (MDEQ). 
d.  Approvals required for a stormwater permit. 
1.  Soil erosion and sedimentation control (SESC) permit. 
2.  National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permit. 
3.  County drain commissioner stormwater drainage approvals, for county drains and plats. 
4.  County drain commissioner (OCDC), construction inspection permit. 
5.  Permits for work within the right-of-way. 
(i)  Road commission for the county (RCOC). 
(ii)  State department of transportation (MDOT). 
6.  Wetland permits: 
(i)  Township. 
(ii)  State department of environmental quality (MDEQ). 
e.  Approvals required for a water main permit. 
1.  Soil erosion and sedimentation control (SESC) permit. 
2.  National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permit. 
3.  Permits for work within the right-of-way. 
(i)  Road commission for the county (RCOC). 
(ii)  State department of transportation (MDOT). 
4.  County drain commissioner (OCDC), construction inspection permit. 
5.  Water main plan review/approvals required. 
(i)  Township, pursuant to chapter 62, article II and chapter 42, article IV. 
(ii)  County drain commissioner (OCDC). 
(iii)  State department of environmental quality (MDEQ). 
6.  Wetlands permit: 
(i)  Township, pursuant to chapter 22, article IV. 
(ii)  State department of environmental quality (MDEQ). 
(2)  No land improvement permit shall be issued unless the applicant has obtained final site plan approval under the township zoning ordinance, if such approval is required under the zoning ordinance for the proposed land improvement, or if the proposed land improvement is an element of a larger development that requires site plan approval under the zoning ordinance. 
(3)  No land improvement permit shall be issued unless the applicant has obtained any other permit or approval required for the proposed land improvement by any ordinance, law, or regulation. 
(Ord. No. 108.A, § V, 5-12-2004)  
Sec. 22-66. - Application and plan review fees. 
A base land improvement application fee, and escrow fee to cover the cost of professional review of the application and plans and specifications, if necessary, shall be determined by resolution of the township board. Any unused amount of the escrow fee shall be returned to the applicant. The applicant shall not be required to submit an escrow fee if the applicant has provided an escrow for site plan, site condominium or plat review for the same land improvement project. 
(Ord. No. 108.A, § VI, 5-12-2004)  
Sec. 22-67. - Township review. 
Upon receipt of the permit application, cost estimate and appropriate fees, and plans and specifications, as necessary, the township building inspector shall transmit copies to the township engineer and other township professionals for their review as necessary. 
(Ord. No. 108.A, § VII, 5-12-2004)  
Sec. 22-68. - Review of plans and specifications. 
The township engineer shall review the plans and specifications and approve the same if they comply with the provisions of article IV of chapter 42, this article, and any other applicable township, county or state regulation. If the applicant submits an extra copy of the plans and specifications with its application, then, in the event any item does not comply with chapter 42, article IV, or other applicable ordinance or county or state regulation, the plans and specifications shall be returned to the applicant, with notations as to any deficiency. The applicant shall resubmit the number of copies of corrected plans directly to the township engineer in accordance with the requirements of section 22-65. Upon approval of the plans, the engineer shall notify the applicant of such approval. 
(Ord. No. 108.A, § VIII, 5-12-2004)  
Sec. 22-69. - Approval of permit. 
(a)  The building inspector, upon consultation with the township engineer, may approve and issue the land improvement permit provided, if necessary, the applicant has obtained any additional approvals required pursuant to section 22-65(e). 
(b)  Applicants required to provide plans and specifications shall submit the appropriate inspection fee, performance guarantee and escrow fee, if necessary, before a permit is issued. 
(c)  If a permit is approved under this subsection, the building inspector shall issue the permit. 
(Ord. No. 108.A, § IX, 5-12-2004)  
Sec. 22-70. - Inspection and issuance of certificate of completion. 
Following completion of the project described in the land improvement application, the work shall be inspected by the building inspector who may consult with the township engineer. The building inspector may then issue a certificate of completion if the work complies with the land improvement permit application. For applicants submitting plans and specifications, the building inspector shall issue a certificate of completion, upon consultation with the township engineer, if the work conforms appropriately with the plans and specifications and as-built plans have been submitted. No certificate of occupancy under Township Zoning Ordinance No. 67 for newly-constructed structures shall be issued unless the applicant shall have obtained a certification of completion. 
(Ord. No. 108.A, § X, 5-12-2004)  
Sec. 22-71. - Inspection fees. 
The applicant (submitting plans and specifications) shall submit an inspection escrow fee prior to inspection. An inspection escrow fee shall be established on a case-by-case basis by the township engineer based upon a formula determined by resolution of the township board. The unused portion of the escrow fee shall be returned to the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 108.A, § XI, 5-12-2004)  
Sec. 22-72. - Performance guarantee. 
(a)  The applicant that is required to submit plans and specifications or applicant's contractor shall post a performance guarantee in the form of cash, a certified check, or a letter of credit on a form approved by the township attorney in the name of the township guaranteeing completion of the land improvement in compliance with the plans and specifications as approved by the township engineer. The amount of the performance guarantee shall be 125 percent of the amount of the estimated total cost of completing the land improvement as determined by the building inspector upon consultation with the township engineer. 
(b)  Return of the performance guarantee to the applicant or the applicant's contractor shall be made on the conditions that the applicant has complied with all of the provisions of this article and all of the terms and conditions of the land improvement permit, and has completed all of the work contemplated under the land improvement permit within the time limit specified in the land improvement permit, or, if no time limit is specified, within 180 days after the date of the issuance of the land improvement permit or the completion of on-going work under the permit, whichever is later. 
(Ord. No. 108.A, § XII, 5-12-2004)  
Sec. 22-73. - Extension of time. 
If the applicant (submitting plans and specifications) is unable to complete the work within the specified time, he may, at least ten days prior to the expiration of the permit, present in writing to the building inspector a request for an extension of time setting forth the reasons for the requested extension. Upon consultation with the township engineer, additional time for the completion of the work may be granted, but no such extension shall release the owner or surety on the bond or the person furnishing the cash bond. 
(Ord. No. 108.A, § XIII, 5-12-2004)  
Sec. 22-74. - Failure to complete work. 
In the event of failure to complete the work or failure to comply with all the requirements, conditions, and terms of the permit, the township building inspector, the township board, or the planning commission, as appropriate, upon consultation with the township engineer, may order such work as is necessary to eliminate any danger to persons or property and to leave the site in a safe condition and may authorize completion of all necessary temporary or permanent measures. The township, after notice to the applicant, may use the posted performance guarantee for the purpose of completing the work. The applicant shall continue to be firmly bound under a continuing obligation for the payment of all necessary costs and expenses that may be incurred or expended by the township in causing any and all such work to be done. 
(Ord. No. 108.A, § XIV, 5-12-2004)  
Sec. 22-75. - Modification of land improvement plans. 
Any modification of the approved land improvement described in the permit application or in plans and specifications must be submitted to and approved by the building inspector upon consultation with the township engineer. All necessary supporting documentation shall be submitted with any proposal to modify the approved land improvement plans. 
(Ord. No. 108.A, § XV, 5-12-2004)  
Sec. 22-76. - Responsibility of applicant with permit. 
During land improvement operations the applicant with permit shall be responsible for: 
(1)  The prevention of damage to any public utilities or services within the limits of grading and along any routes of travel of the equipment. 
(2)  The prevention of damage to adjacent property. (No person shall grade on land so close to the property line as to endanger any adjoining public street, sidewalk, alley, or any public or private property without supporting and protecting such property from settling, cracking, or other damage which might result.) 
(3)  Carrying out the proposed work in accordance with all the requirements of the permit and this article, and all other applicable township ordinances, including chapter 42, article IV. 
(4)  The prompt removal of all soil, miscellaneous debris, or other materials applied, dumped, or otherwise deposited on public streets, highways, sidewalks, or other public thoroughfares during transit to and from the construction site, where such spillage constitutes a public nuisance or hazard. 
(Ord. No. 108.A, § XVI, 5-12-2004)  
Sec. 22-77. - Land improvement and surface drainage plans. 
All land improvement activity and corresponding land improvement plans shall conform with the site grading requirements of chapter 42, article IV. 
(Ord. No. 108.A, § XVII, 5-12-2004)  
Sec. 22-78. - Stormwater management. 
Any land improvement requiring submittal of plans and specifications including that activity associated with a site plan, site condominium, or plat, shall provide for stormwater management in the plans and specifications in accordance with the following general standards: 
(1)  Stormwater management conveyance, storage, and infiltration facilities shall be designed to prevent flood hazards and water pollution related to runoff from the proposed development project. 
(2)  Stormwater from upstream and off-site locations shall be conveyed through the Site or stored on-site. 
(3)  Unless otherwise approved, stormwater runoff shall be conveyed through swales and vegetated buffer strips so as to decrease runoff velocity, allow for natural infiltration, allow suspended sediment to settle, and to remove pollutants. 
(4)  Alterations to natural drainage patterns shall not create flooding or a water pollution condition for adjacent or downstream property owners. 
(5)  Watercourses and adjacent streambanks shall not be dredged, cleared of vegetation, deepened, widened, straightened, stabilized or otherwise altered without approval from the state department of environmental quality and/or the township in accordance with the provision of article IV of this chapter, or, if the watercourse is a designated county drain, approval from the county drain commissioner shall be obtained. 
(6)  No modifications of watercourses shall be permitted if the primary purpose is to increase the flow capacity of the watercourse except for the widening of county drains by the office of the county drain commissioner. 
(7)  Discharge of runoff from commercial and industrial sites which may contain oil, grease, toxic chemicals, or other polluting materials shall be prohibited unless measures to reduce and trap pollutants meet the requirements of the state department of environmental quality and the township. 
(8)  Drainage systems shall be designed to protect public health and safety and to be visually attractive. 
(9)  No land improvement permit shall be granted if the proposed action is likely to impact a wetland or watercourse unless a permit has been obtained pursuant to article IV of this chapter. Wetland and watercourses may be utilized for stormwater discharge associated with a land improvement provided the discharge conforms with this article and any necessary permits are obtained pursuant to article IV. 
(Ord. No. 108.A, § XVIII, 5-12-2004)  
Sec. 22-79. - Stormwater detention and retention basin standards. 
(a)  The applicant's engineer must submit copies of all design data together with plans for any storm drainage system. Determination of surface runoff and sizing of sewer system pipes, culverts, and open channels shall comply with the standards of the county drain commissioner or chapter 42, article IV, whichever standard is more strict. 
(b)  Any new development or addition(s) to an existing development must retain or detain the increased runoff onsite unless otherwise directed by the township engineer. Acceptable means of retention and/or detention can be achieved through a separate retention and/or detention basin. The county method of retention basin design, as available from the county drain commissioner's office or chapter 42, article IV, shall be utilized in determining the volume of retention and/or detention required based upon whichever standard is more strict. 
(c)  Retention and/or detention basin construction shall satisfy the design criteria of chapter 42, article IV, as it may be amended, and/or the criteria of the county drain commissioner, whichever standard is more stringent. 
(Ord. No. 108.A, § XIX, 5-12-2004)  
Sec. 22-80. - Stormwater management easements. 
(a)  Necessity of easements. Stormwater management easements shall be provided by the applicant if necessary to assure: 
(1)  Access for stormwater management measures and facilities inspections and maintenance; and 
(2)  Preservation of stormwater management conveyance, infiltration and storage areas, including flood routes for the 100-year storm event. 
(b)  Easements for offsite stormwater management. Stormwater management and flood easements are required for all areas used for offsite stormwater management measures and/or facilities, unless the areas are upon the same parcel as the proposed development site at the time stormwater management provisions of plans and specifications are submitted, or, if plans and specifications are not required, at the time of application. 
(c)  Recording of easements. Easements shall be recorded with the county register of deeds according to county requirements. 
(d)  Recording prior to building permit issuance. The proprietor must provide the building official with evidence of the recording prior to the issuance of a certificate of completion. 
(Ord. No. 108.A, § XX, 5-12-2004)  
Sec. 22-81. - Maintenance agreement. 
(a)  Purpose of maintenance agreement. The purpose of the maintenance agreement is to provide the means and assurance that maintenance of stormwater management facilities shall be undertaken. 
(b)  Maintenance agreement required. An applicant for a land improvement permit submitting plans and specifications containing stormwater management measures and facilities, which in the opinion of the township engineer, will require future maintenance to remain effective and workable, shall submit a maintenance agreement to the township in a form acceptable to the township. 
(c)  The maintenance agreement shall provide for routine maintenance and emergency maintenance. 
(d)  The maintenance agreement shall be binding on all subsequent owners of land served by the stormwater management facilities, and shall be recorded in the land records of the county within 30 days after approval by the township board. 
(e)  A certificate of completion shall not be granted until such time as a maintenance agreement has been submitted to and accepted by the township if required pursuant to subsection (b). 
(Ord. No. 108.A, § XXI, 5-12-2004)  
Sec. 22-82. - Waiver of provisions. 
The planning commission may upon appeal in a specific case authorize such waivers from the terms of this article as will not be contrary to the public interest where, owing to special conditions, a literal enforcement of the provisions of this article would result in practical difficulties or unnecessary hardship. A waiver from the terms of this article shall not be granted by the planning commission unless and until: 
(1)  A written application for a waiver is submitted demonstrating that literal enforcement of the article will result in either practical difficulties or unnecessary hardship: 
a.  The existence of practical difficulties shall be determined upon consideration of the following factors: 
1.  Strict compliance with the terms of the article will unreasonably prevent the owner from using the property for a permitted purpose or will render article conformity unnecessarily burdensome; 
2.  The waiver will do substantial justice to the applicant, as well as to other property owners; 
3.  A lesser waiver than requested will not give substantial relief to the applicant and will not be more consistent with justice to other property owners; 
4.  The need for the waiver is due to the unique circumstances peculiar to the property and not generally applicable in the area or to other properties; 
5.  The problem and resulting need for the waiver has not been self-created by the applicant and/or the applicant's predecessors; 
b.  Unnecessary hardship shall be established by demonstrating that: 
1.  The property cannot reasonably be used in compliance with this article; and 
2.  The need for the waiver is due to the unique circumstances peculiar to the property and not generally applicable in the area or to other properties; and 
3.  The requested waiver will not adversely affect surrounding properties; and 
4.  The hardship was not unreasonably self-created by the applicant; 
(2)  No incidence of noncompliance with this article by any person or on any property shall be considered grounds for the issuance of a waiver. 
(3)  Notice of a public hearing on the waiver application shall be given. The public hearing shall be held. Any party may appear in person or by agent or by attorney. 
(4)  The planning commission shall make findings of fact based upon competent evidence that the requirements of subsection (1)a. or b. have been met. 
(5)  The planning commission shall further make a finding that the reasons set forth in the application justify the granting of a waiver, and that the waiver is the minimum waiver that will make possible the reasonable use of the property; 
(6)  The planning commission shall further make a finding that the granting of the waiver will be in harmony with the general purpose and intent of this article, and will not be injurious to the neighborhood, or otherwise detrimental to the public welfare. 
(7)  In granting any waiver, the planning commission may prescribe appropriate conditions and safeguards in conformity with this article. Violation of such conditions and safeguards, when made a part of the terms under which the waiver is granted, shall be deemed a violation of this article and punishable as such. Conditions imposed shall meet all of the following requirements: 
a.  Be designed to protect natural resources, the health, safety and welfare of the community, and to advance the goals of this article. 
b.  Be related to the valid exercise of the police power, and purposes which are affected by the proposed land improvement. 
(Ord. No. 108.A, § XXII, 5-12-2004)  
Sec. 22-83. - Telecommunications providers. 
Pursuant to Act No. 48 of the Public Acts of 2002, MCL 484.3101 et seq., as it may be amended from time to time ("Act"), no telecommunications provider, as defined in the Act, shall be required to pay any fee, charge, financial requirement, or other cost under this article beyond that which is permitted by the Act. No provision of this article shall be construed in such a manner as to violate the Act. 
(Ord. No. 108.A, § XXIII, 5-12-2004)  
Sec. 22-84. - Penalties and enforcement. 
A person who violates any provision of this article or any of the terms or conditions of a permit is responsible for a municipal civil infraction as defined by state statute, and shall be subject to a civil fine of not more than $500.00 along with costs which may include all expenses, direct and indirect, to which the township has been put in connection with the municipal civil infraction. In no case, however, shall costs of less than $9.00 nor more than $500.00 be ordered. A person who violates any provision of this article or any of the terms or conditions of a permit shall also be subject to such additional sanctions and judicial orders as are authorized under state law. Each day that a violation of this article or a permit continues to exist shall constitute a separate offense. In addition, the township may pursue any injunctive or other relief which may be available. Nothing in this section 22-84 shall be construed to limit the remedies available to the township in the event of a violation by a person of this article or a permit. 
(Ord. No. 108.A, § XXV, 5-12-2004) 
APPENDIX A
 
  
Secs. 22-85—22-130. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - WETLAND AND WATERCOURSE PROTECTION[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Waterways, ch. 66. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 22-131. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Contiguous means any of the following: 
(1)  A permanent surface water connection or other direct physical contact with an inland lake or pond, a river or a stream. 
(2)  A seasonal or intermittent surface water connection to an inland lake or pond, a river or a stream. 
(3)  Two or more areas separated by barriers, such as dikes, roads, berms or other similar features, but with any area contiguous under the criteria described in subsections (1) and (2) of this definition. 
Fill material means soil, rocks, sand, waste of any kind, or any other material which displaces soil or water or reduces water retention potential. 
Minor drainage includes ditching and tiling for the removal of excess soil moisture incidental to the planting, cultivating, protecting, or harvesting of crops or improving the production of land in established use for commercial agriculture, commercial horticulture, commercial silviculture, or commercial lumbering. 
Owner means the title holder, land contract purchaser or lessee. 
Watercourse means any waterway or other body of water having reasonably well-defined banks, including rivers, streams, creeks and brooks, whether continually or intermittently flowing, and lakes and ponds, and/or as shown on wetland and watercourses maps. 
Wetland means land characterized by the presence of water at a frequency and duration sufficient to support and that under normal circumstances does support wetland vegetation or aquatic life, and is commonly referred to as a bog, swamp, or marsh, and which is any of the following: 
(1)  Contiguous to an inland lake or pond, or a river or stream. 
(2)  Not contiguous to an inland lake or pond, or a river or stream, and one acre or more in size. 
Wetland and watercourses maps means those maps which delineate wetlands and watercourses in the township, as amended and/or updated from time to time, including but not limited to United States Geological Survey maps, United States Soil Conservation Service maps, and state department of environmental quality maps. 
(Ord. No. 80B, § 3, 6-12-1996) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 22-132. - Purpose of article. 
(a)  Consistent with the letter and spirit of part 303 of Public Act No. 451 of 1994 (MCL 324.30301 et seq.), the township finds that rapid growth, the spread of development, and increasing demands upon natural resources have had the effect of encroaching upon, polluting, impairing or destroying many of its wetlands and other natural resources and processes associated therewith which, if preserved and maintained in an undisturbed and natural condition, constitute important physical, aesthetic, recreational and economic assets to existing and future residents of the township. 
(b)  Protection of the natural resources is essential to the protection of the public health, safety and welfare within the township. 
(c)  This article provides for the protection, preservation, proper maintenance, and use of township wetlands and watercourses in order to prevent pollution, impairment or destruction of them. This article adopts the definition of a wetland that is provided under part 303 of Public Act No. 451 of 1994 (MCL 324.30301 et seq.) which is specifically authorized by section 30307(4) of such act (MCL 324.30307(4)). 
(Ord. No. 80B, § 2, 6-12-1996)  
Sec. 22-133. - Penalties; restoration of altered wetlands. 
(a)  Any person found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(b)  Any person violating the provisions of this article shall become liable to the township for any expense or loss or damage occasioned by the township by reason of such violation. 
(c)  In addition to the penalties provided under subsection (a) of this section, the court may order a person who violates this article to restore as nearly as possible the wetland which was affected by the violation, to its original condition immediately before the violation. The restoration may include the removal of all material deposited in the wetland or the replacement of soil, sand, or minerals. 
(Ord. No. 80B, § 15, 6-12-1996)  
Sec. 22-134. - Areas and facilities subject to article. 
This article shall apply to: 
(1)  Watercourses as defined in this article. 
(2)  Wetlands as defined in this article. 
(3)  All retention and detention facilities constructed for the purpose of collecting and/or directing runoff water into any wetland or watercourse. 
(Ord. No. 80B, § 4, 6-12-1996)  
Sec. 22-135. - Nonconforming activities and structures. 
An activity or structure existing on October 18, 1991, or at the time of subsequent amendments to this article, but which is not in conformity with the provisions of this article, may be continued subject to the following provisions. However, the intent of this section is the gradual elimination of nonconforming uses. 
(1)  No such activity or structure shall be expanded, changed, enlarged or altered in a way that increases its nonconformity with this article. 
(2)  On a building or structure devoted in whole or in part to a nonconforming use or activity, work may be done in any period of 12 consecutive months on ordinary repairs or on repair or replacement of non-bearing walls, fixtures, wiring, or plumbing to an extent not exceeding 50 percent of the assessed value of the building or structure, provided that the cubic content of the building as it existed on October 18, 1991, or at the time of subsequent amendments to this article, shall not be increased. Should any such structure be destroyed by any means to an extent of more than 50 percent of its replacement cost, exclusive of the foundation, at the time of destruction, it shall not be reconstructed except in conformity with the provisions of this article. 
(3)  If a nonconforming activity or use is discontinued for six consecutive months, any resumption of the activity or use shall conform to this article. 
(Ord. No. 80B, § 9, 6-12-1996)  
Sec. 22-136. - Variances. 
The planning commission may, upon appeal in a specific case, authorize such variance from the terms of this article as will not be contrary to the public interest where, owing to special conditions, a literal enforcement of the provisions of this article would result in practical difficulties or unnecessary hardship. A variance from the terms of this article shall not be granted by the planning commission unless and until: 
(1)  A written application for a variance is submitted demonstrating that: 
a.  Special conditions and circumstances exist which are peculiar to the land, structure, or building involved and which are not applicable to other lands, structures, or buildings in the same district; 
b.  Literal interpretation of the provisions of this article would deprive the applicant of rights commonly enjoyed by other properties in the same district under the terms of this article; 
c.  The special conditions and circumstances do not result from the actions of the applicant; 
d.  Granting the variance requested will not confer on the applicant any special privilege that is denied by this article to other lands, structures, or buildings in the same district; or 
e.  Unnecessary hardship would result, which was not self-created, such that no useful purpose would be served by strict enforcement of the terms of this article. 
(2)  No nonconforming use of neighboring lands, structures, or buildings in the same district, and no permitted or nonconforming use of lands, structures, or buildings in other districts, shall be considered grounds for the issuance of a variance. 
(3)  The planning commission shall make findings of fact based upon competent evidence that the requirements of subsections (a)(1)a through d of this section or subsection (a)(1)e of this section have been met. 
(4)  The planning commission shall further make a finding that the reasons set forth in the application justify the granting of a variance, and that the variance is the minimum variance that will make possible the reasonable use of the land, building or structure. 
(5)  The planning commission shall further make a finding that the granting of the variance will be in harmony with the general purpose and intent of this article, and will not be injurious to the neighborhood, or otherwise detrimental to the public welfare. 
(6)  In granting any variance, the planning commission may prescribe appropriate conditions and safeguards in conformity with this article. Violation of such conditions and safeguards, when made a part of the terms under which the variance is granted, shall be deemed a violation of this article and punishable under section 22-133. Conditions imposed shall meet all of the following requirements: 
a.  Be designed to protect natural resources, health, safety and welfare, and the social and economic well-being of those who will use the building, land or activity under consideration, residents and landowners immediately adjacent to the proposed building, land use or activity, and the community as a whole. 
b.  Be related to the valid exercise of police power and purposes which are affected by the proposed building, use or activity. 
c.  Be necessary to meet the intent and purpose of this article, be related to the standards established in this article for the building, land use or activity under consideration, and be necessary to ensure compliance with those standards. 
(Ord. No. 80B, § 16, 6-12-1996)  
Sec. 22-137. - Wetland inventory map. 
The township hereby adopts and incorporates into this article an amended wetland inventory map as prepared by the township's wetland consultant, Tilton & Associates, Inc. The wetland inventory map does not create any legally enforceable presumptions regarding whether property that is or is not included on the wetland inventory map is or is not a wetland. This wetland inventory map does not necessarily include all of the wetlands within the township that may be subject to regulation under this article or under other law. 
(Ord. No. 80B.001, art. 1, 2-19-2003)  
Secs. 22-138—22-160. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 
 
Sec. 22-161. - Activities requiring permit. 
(a)  Except for those activities expressly permitted in this article, the following acts require a prior permit from the township as authorized by section 22-165, and are prohibited unless a permit is first obtained: 
(1)  Depositing or allowing the placing of any fill material in a wetland or watercourse, or within 25 feet of a watercourse. 
(2)  Dredging, removing, or allowing the removal of soil, sand, minerals, or materials, including vegetation, from a wetland or watercourse, or from any area within 25 feet of a watercourse. 
(3)  Constructing, operating, or maintaining any use or structure in a wetland or watercourse, or within an area within 25 feet of a watercourse. 
(4)  Draining surface or subsurface water from or which drains into a wetland or watercourse. 
(5)  Flooding or otherwise altering a watercourse or wetland. 
(6)  Mowing or cutting of plants in a wetland. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the prohibition of subsection (a) of this section, the following activities are permitted within a wetland or watercourse without a use permit subject to other laws of the state and the owner's regulation: 
(1)  Fishing, trapping, or hunting. 
(2)  Swimming or boating. 
(3)  Hiking. 
(4)  Grazing of animals. 
(5)  Farming, horticulture, silviculture, lumbering, and ranching activities, including plowing, irrigation, irrigation ditching, seeding, cultivating, minor drainage, harvesting for the production of food, fiber, and forest products, or upland soil and water conservation practices. Wetlands altered under this article shall not be used for a purpose other than a purpose described in this section without a permit from the Michigan Department of Natural Resources. 
(6)  Maintenance or operation of serviceable structure in existence on June 3, 1994 or constructed pursuant to this article. 
(7)  Construction or maintenance of farm or stock ponds. 
(8)  Maintenance, operation, or improvement which includes straightening, widening, or deepening of the following that is necessary for the production or harvesting of agricultural products: 
a.  An existing private agricultural drain. 
b.  That portion of a drain legally established pursuant to Public Act No. 40 of 1956 (MCL 280.1 et seq.), which has been constructed or improved for drainage purposes. 
c.  A drain constructed pursuant to other provisions of this article. 
(9)  Construction or maintenance of farm roads, forest roads, or temporary roads for moving mining or forestry equipment, if the roads are constructed and maintained in a manner to ensure that any adverse effect on the wetland will be otherwise minimized. When the temporary road ceases to be used, the land used for the temporary road shall be restored to its natural state, as near as possible, prior to construction of the temporary road. 
(10)  Drainage necessary for the production and harvesting of agricultural products if the wetland is owned by a person who is engaged in commercial farming and the land is to be used for the production and harvesting of agricultural products. Except as otherwise provided in this article, wetlands improved under this subsection after June 3, 1994, shall not be used for non-farming purposes without a permit from the department. This subsection shall not apply to a wetland which is contiguous to a lake or stream, or to a tributary of a lake or stream, or to a wetland which the department has determined by clear and convincing evidence to be a wetland which is necessary to be preserved for the public interest, in which case a permit shall be required. 
(11)  Maintenance or improvement of public streets, highways, or roads, within the right-of-way and in such manner as to ensure that any adverse effect on the wetland will be otherwise minimized. Maintenance or improvement does not include adding extra lanes, increasing the right-of-way, or deviating from the existing location of the street, highway, or road. 
(12)  Maintenance, repair, or operation of gas or oil pipelines and construction of gas or oil pipelines having a diameter of six inches or less, if the pipelines are constructed, maintained, or repaired in a manner to ensure that any adverse effect on the wetland will be otherwise minimized. 
(13)  Maintenance, repair, or operation of electric transmission and distribution power lines and construction of distribution power lines if the distribution power lines are constructed, maintained, or repaired in a manner to ensure that any adverse effect on the wetland will be otherwise minimized. 
(14)  Operation or maintenance, including reconstruction of recently damaged parts, of serviceable dikes and levees in existence on October 18, 1991, or constructed pursuant to this article. 
(15)  Construction of iron and copper mining tailings basins and water storage areas. 
(16)  After October 18, 1991, but immediately prior to the approval of a state program under section 404 of title 4 of the Clean Water Act of 1977, 33 USC 1344, where a project solely involves the discharge of fill material subject to the individual permit requirements of section 404 of title 4 of the Clean Water Act of 1977, 33 USC 1344, an additional permit shall not be required by this article. 
(17)  The placement of seasonal structures on wetlands and on the bottomland of watercourses to facilitate private noncommercial use of wetlands or watercourses. A seasonal structure includes any type of dock, boat hoist, ramp, raft or other recreational structure which is placed into a wetland or watercourse in the spring or summer and which is removed in the fall. 
(18)  Irrigation of grass, pasture, garden, or other personal property using water from inland lakes, streams and/or wetlands located in the township. 
(Ord. No. 80B, §§ 6, 8, 6-12-1996; Ord. No. 80B.002, art. 1, 10-12-2011)  
Sec. 22-162. - Wetlands less than two acres in area. 
(a)  A permit shall be approved with respect to a noncontiguous wetland less than two acres in area unless the township determines that the wetland is essential to the preservation of the natural resources of the township. 
(b)  All noncontiguous wetland areas of less than two acres which appear on the wetlands inventory map, or which are otherwise identified during a field inspection by the township, shall be analyzed for the purpose of determining whether such areas are essential to the preservation of the natural resources of the township. If there is to be a denial of a permit to dredge, fill, construct, or otherwise undertake an operation in a noncontiguous wetland of less than two acres, then, on the basis of data presented by the applicant, or supplemental data gathered by the township, findings shall be made in writing and given to the applicant stating the basis for the determination that such wetland is essential to the preservation of the natural resources of the township. In order to make such a determination, there shall be a finding that one or more of the following exist within such wetland: 
(1)  The site supports state or federal endangered or threatened plants, fish, or wildlife appearing on a list specified in section 36503 of Public Act No. 451 of 1994 (MCL 324.36503). 
(2)  The site represents what is identified as a locally rare or unique ecosystem. 
(3)  The site supports plants or animals of an identified local importance. 
(4)  The site provides groundwater recharge documented by a public agency. 
(5)  The site provides flood and storm control by the hydrologic absorption and storage capacity of the wetland. 
(6)  The site provides wildlife habitat by providing breeding, nesting, or feeding grounds or cover for forms of wildlife, waterfowl, including migratory waterfowl, and rare, threatened or endangered wildlife species. 
(7)  The site provides protection of subsurface water resources and provision of valuable watersheds and recharging groundwater supplies. 
(8)  The site provides pollution treatment by serving as a biological and chemical oxidation basin. 
(9)  The site provides erosion control by serving as a sedimentation area and filtering basin, absorbing silt and organic matter. 
(10)  The site provides sources of nutrients in water food cycles and nursery grounds and sanctuaries for fish. 
(c)  The data which must be submitted by the applicant for purposes of making the determination whether the wetland is essential to the preservation of the natural resources of the township shall include an election and response under subsections (1) and (2) of this subsection relative to each noncontiguous wetland area less than two acres: 
(1)  An acknowledgment that one or more of the criteria in subsections (b)(1) through (10) of this section exist on the wetland in question, including a specification of the one or more criteria which do exist; or 
(2)  An analysis prepared by the applicant's qualified wetlands consultant, if the applicant has been required by the township to hire one or has otherwise hired one, with respect to each criterion in subsections (b)(1) through (10) of this section, detailing whether each of the criteria in subsections (b)(1) through (10) exists or does not exist in the wetland in question, including specific reasons for the conclusion in respect to each criterion. 
(Ord. No. 80B, § 7, 6-12-1996)  
Sec. 22-163. - Application requirements; issuance of building permits for single-family homes and accessory structures. 
(a)  A use permit applicant for uses other than construction of a single-family home or accessory buildings on a single parcel shall submit the following materials to the township clerk or designated agent: 
(1)  A completed use permit application on a form provided by the township. The township shall utilize a form provided by the state. 
(2)  A use permit application fee in an amount as set by resolution of the township board. 
(3)  Where the applicant is not the owner of the property, a written authorization from the owner permitting the proposed activity. 
(4)  With the exclusion of single-family residences, a site plan, including a topographical survey drawn at no more than a two-foot contour interval, sealed by a registered engineer or registered surveyor, which includes the following information: 
a.  The shape and dimensions of the lot or parcel, together with the existing and proposed locations of structures and improvements, if any; 
b.  Specification of the extent of all areas to be disturbed, the depths to which removal or deposition activities are proposed, and the angle of repose of all slopes of deposition material and/or sides of channels or excavations resulting from removal operations; 
c.  A soils map drawn at the same scale as the site plan delineating existing general soil conditions throughout the parcel; 
d.  Location and dimensions of all setbacks, easements, and existing and proposed public and private utilities; and 
e.  A grading plan drawn at the same scale as the site plan indicating all grade changes proposed and proposed drainage pattern changes for the lot or parcel and how such changes will affect these regulations, and existing contour data for the entire property with a vertical contour interval of no more than two feet, and vertical contour data at an interval of no more than one foot, for all areas to be disturbed by proposed operations, extending for a distance of at least 50 feet beyond the limits of grading or disturbance of such areas. Indicated elevations shall be based on United States Geological Survey datum. 
f.  A soil erosion and sedimentation control plan consistent with the requirements of the county drain commissioner showing measures to protect watercourses at the 25-foot setback from construction disturbance. 
g.  Stormwater drainage plan and calculations for release of stormwater into any wetland or watercourse. 
h.  A designation on all design plans of the limits or boundaries of all watercourses and wetland areas, regardless of size, which boundaries shall be staked by the applicant or the applicant's agent on the site. 
(b)  As part of the review of any building permit application for construction of a single-family home or single-family accessory building or structure on a parcel of land, the building official or his or her designee shall inspect the property to determine whether the proposed construction would be located within any wetland or watercourse, or within 25 feet of a watercourse. 
(1)  If it appears to the building official or his or her designee that construction is proposed within a wetland or watercourse or within 25 feet of a watercourse, then a building permit shall not be issued until the township has obtained the advice of the township's wetlands consultant. 
(2)  If the township deems it necessary to obtain the advice of the township's wetlands consultant, the property owner shall be charged a fee for such costs as established by resolution of the township board; however, if an applicant can establish economic hardship, the township may waive some or all of the cost for the wetlands consultant's review. 
(3)  No building permit shall be approved if the township planning commission determines that the proposed structure is likely to pollute, impair, or destroy a wetland or watercourse of one acre or more in size, unless it determines that there are no feasible or prudent alternative, and that the approval is consistent with the public interest in light of the purposes of this article. 
(Ord. No. 80B, § 10, 6-12-1996)  
Sec. 22-164. - Fees. 
In reviewing wetlands use permit applications, the planning commission may seek opinions and advice from experts with special wetlands knowledge. The fees and costs for such consultants, including costs of field inspections, shall be paid by the applicant as established by resolution of the township board. 
(Ord. No. 80B, § 11, 6-12-1996)  
Sec. 22-165. - Review of application; granting or denial; issuance. 
(a)  The township planning commission, with the assistance of the township engineer and/or wetlands consultant, shall review the application for a wetlands or watercourses permit and shall approve or deny the application within 90 days. The planning commission shall send a copy of the application to the state department of environmental quality. 
(b)  The applicant for an approval required in conjunction with site plan approval or subdivision approval shall, at the time of the submission, elect to have the application processed under one of the following procedures: 
(1)  The wetland application shall be reviewed immediately, either prior to or concurrent with the review of the site plan, plat or other proposed land use submitted by the applicant, with the understanding that the land use review may not be completed at the time the decision is rendered on the wetland application. Election of this alternative may require a re-opening of the wetland application if the land use approval is inconsistent with the wetland approval; or 
(2)  The wetland application shall be reviewed and acted upon concurrently with the review of the site plan, plat or other proposed land use submitted by the applicant, and the 90-day review period limitation specified in section 30307(2) of Public Act No. 451 of 1994 (MCL 324.30307(2)) is thereby extended accordingly. 
(c)  In determining whether the activity is in the public interest, the benefit which reasonably may be expected to accrue from the proposal shall be balanced against the reasonably foreseeable detriments of the activity. The decision shall reflect the national, state, and local concern for the protection of natural resources from pollution, impairment, and destruction. The commission may issue development permits for certain acts in the watercourses and wetlands of the township, provided such development permit does not violate the intent of this article or of other township, county, or state ordinances or statutes. In reviewing such application, the commission shall consider the possible effects of the proposed operation upon: 
(1)  Water quality, including filtering action; 
(2)  Fish or wildlife, including their habitats, damage or change; 
(3)  Effect upon adjoining wetland or drainage areas and water tables; 
(4)  Economic impact; 
(5)  Land use for which the property is zoned or planned; and 
(6)  Recreational impact. 
(d)  No approval shall be given if the planning commission determines that the action has or is likely to pollute, impair or destroy a wetland or watercourse of one acre or more in size, unless it determines that there are no feasible and prudent alternatives and that the approval is consistent with the public interest in light of the purposes of this article. 
(e)  The planning commission may hold a public hearing on the application before making a decision. The commission shall provide the applicant with the reasons for denying the permit application. 
(f)  Whenever a use permit is granted, the commission shall: 
(1)  Impose such conditions on the manner and extent of the proposed activity or use as are necessary to ensure that the intent of this article is carried out and that the activity or use will be conducted in such a manner as will cause the least possible damage, encroachment or interference with natural resources and natural processes within the watercourse and/or wetland area. 
(2)  Fix a reasonable time within which any wetland operation must be completed, which time period may be extended by the planning commission only for good cause shown. 
(3)  Require the filing with the township of a cash bond or irrevocable letter of credit, in such form and amount as determined necessary by the township board to ensure compliance with the approved development permit. 
(g)  If a use permit is denied, the commission shall inform the applicant of the reasons for denial in writing. The failure to supply complete information with a permit application may be reason for denial of a permit. 
(h)  After the planning commission reaches its final decision, it shall forward its decision to the state as provided in part 303 of Public Act No. 451 of 1994 (MCL 324.30301 et seq.). 
(i)  Following approval of the wetland application, a wetland permit shall be issued upon determination that all other requirements of this Code, township ordinances and law have been met, including site plan, plat or land use approval, as applicable, and including issuance of a permit by the state department of environmental quality, if required under part 303 of Public Act No. 451 of 1994 (MCL 324.30301 et seq.). In cases where a state department of environmental quality permit allows activities not permitted under this article, the restrictions of approval granted under this article shall govern. 
(Ord. No. 80B, § 12, 6-12-1996)  
Sec. 22-166. - Revaluation of property for assessment purposes when permit is denied. 
If a permit is denied to a landowner to conduct activity in a wetland according to the requirements of this article, such landowner shall be entitled to request a revaluation of the affected property for assessment purposes before the township property tax valuation board of review to determine its fair market value under the use restriction. 
(Ord. No. 80B, § 13, 6-12-1996)  
Secs. 22-167—22-190. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - PUBLIC WATER SUPPLY PROTECTION[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference— Utilities, ch. 62. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 22-191. - Definitions and policy. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Township means the Charter Township of Oxford, Michigan, or its assignee. 
Wellhead protection overlay zone means an area surrounding a public well's wellhead, the circumference of which represents the area within which contaminants in surface water can travel to the wellhead within a ten-year period and which has been delineated on the appropriate appendix to Ordinance No. 110. 
(b)  Policy. 
(1)  Whereas, the groundwater in the aquifer underlying the Charter Township of Oxford is the source of drinking water for township residents, and the township desires to protect its public water supply and wellhead areas by instituting pollution source controls; and 
(2)  Whereas, the township desires to regulate potential pollutants to the fullest extent authorized by law by enacting the ordinance from which this division was derived as a measure to ensure the protection and availability of public drinking water supplies; and 
(3)  Whereas, pursuant to part 88 of the Natural Resources and Environmental Protection act (MCL 324.8801 et seq.) and associated regulations, local communities are encouraged to enact a local wellhead protection groundwater ordinance in order to qualify for certain grant funding administered by the Michigan Department of Environmental Equality (MDEQ); 
(4)  Now, therefore, the Charter Township of Oxford, Oakland County, Michigan, hereby ordains as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 110, art. 2, 11-8-2000) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 22-192. - Penalties. 
Any person who violates or continues to violate any provisions of the article beyond the time limit for compliance set forth by the township supervisor, fire chief or their designees, a notice of violation or other compliance schedule shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. If the violation is a continuing one, each day of such violation shall constitute a separate violation. 
(Ord. No. 110, art. 20, 11-8-2000)  
Sec. 22-193. - Scope of article; areas subject to article. 
(a)  The provisions of this article shall be effective within the wellhead protection overlay zone shown on the official zoning map of the township. Maps designating the wellhead protection overlay zone shall be included in the official zoning map of the township. A map showing the wellhead protection overlay zone shall be attached to this article as appendix A and may be amended as necessary by resolution of the township board. 
(b)  Nothing contained in this article shall be construed so as to interfere with any existing or future lawful requirements that may be, or heretofore were, imposed by any other governmental entity authorized to enact sanitary, health or water pollution abatement restrictions. In the event of a conflict between the intentions of this article and those of another governmental body, the strictest standard shall apply. 
(c)  Nothing contained in this article shall be construed so as to interfere with the duties and powers of the township or its agents. 
(Ord. No. 110, arts. 1, 6, 11-8-2000)  
Sec. 22-194. - Responsibility for compliance. 
It shall be the responsibility of any person owning real property and/or owning and operating a business within the township to make a determination of the applicability of this article as it pertains to the property and/or business under his ownership or operation, and his failure to do so shall not excuse any violations of this article. 
(Ord. No. 110, art. 7, 11-8-2000)  
Sec. 22-195. - Falsifying information. 
No person shall make any false statement, representation or certification in any report or other document filed or required to be maintained pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. No. 110, art. 14, 11-8-2000)  
Sec. 22-196. - Retention of records. 
Any reports or records compiled or submitted pursuant to this article shall be maintained by the user for a minimum of five years or for so long as enforcement or judicial proceedings are being pursued, whichever is longer. 
(Ord. No. 110, art. 15, 11-8-2000)  
Sec. 22-197. - Underground storage tanks. 
Underground storage tanks located within the wellhead protection overlay zone are defined and regulated within the zone in accordance with part 211 of the Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act (MCL 324.21101 et seq.) and with the corresponding administrative regulations. 
(Ord. No. 110, art. 13, 11-8-2000)  
Sec. 22-198. - Damaging or tampering with structures or equipment. 
No person shall maliciously, willfully or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance, property or equipment which is part of or used in conjunction with the water facilities, or which results in violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 110, art. 18, 11-8-2000)  
Secs. 22-199—22-220. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2. 
 
Sec. 22-221. - Generally. 
Except as otherwise provided in this article, the township supervisor, or his designated agents, shall administer, implement and enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 110, art. 3, 11-8-2000)  
Sec. 22-222. - Notice of violation. 
(a)  Any person found in violation of this article or any order, requirement, rule or regulation issued under the authority of this article will be served with a written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing reasonable time for compliance. If a person enforcing this article has previously promulgated a schedule of compliance or issued an order addressing the same type of or a similar violation and the time for compliance has passed, that person may dispense with establishing another time for compliance. 
(b)  The notice shall be served by first class mail, return receipt requested. Where the address of the violator is unknown, service may be made upon the owner of the property involved at the tax mailing address of the owner as shown on the county tax record. 
(c)  The township supervisor or his designee and/or the fire chief of the township fire department or his designee may issue a notice of violation under this article. 
(Ord. No. 110, art. 4, 11-8-2000)  
Sec. 22-223. - Inspections. 
The persons described in section 22-222(c) shall have the authority, bearing proper identification, to request entry in order to enter any premises or structure or other private property at reasonable times to inspect. Prior to entering into a space not otherwise open to the general public, the persons authorized to conduct inspection under section 22-222(c) shall make a reasonable effort to locate the owner or other person having charge or control of the structure or premises, present proper identification and request entry. If requested entry is refused or not obtained, the authorized person may pursue recourse as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 110, art. 5, 11-8-2000)  
Sec. 22-224. - Appearance tickets. 
The fire chief and the township supervisor are hereby authorized to issue appearance tickets for a violation of this article along with other persons authorized to do so by other ordinances or state law. 
(Ord. No. 110, art. 21, 11-8-2000)  
Sec. 22-225. - Enforcement actions. 
(a)  If any activity or use of a regulated substance is deemed by the township supervisor to pose a real and present danger of contaminating surface water and/or groundwater which would normally enter the public water supply, the township supervisor or fire chief is authorized to: 
(1)  Cause cessation of the activity or use of regulated substance; 
(2)  Require the provision of administrative controls and/or facilities sufficient to mitigate such danger; and/or 
(3)  Cause the provision of pollution control and/or abatement activities. However, no legal action can be taken without the authorization of the township supervisor or fire chief. 
(b)  When considering the exercise of any of the authorities or actions described in subsection (a) of this section, the township supervisor or fire chief shall ensure that the township's public water supply is reasonably and adequately protected from contamination for the present and the future, shall make every reasonable effort to coordinate and act in concert with other regulatory entities in the exercise of such authority, and may take into consideration any evidence represented by the entity regarding cost effectiveness and the economic effectiveness and the economic impact imposed by the requirements or actions. 
(Ord. No. 110, art. 16, 11-8-2000)  
Sec. 22-226. - Appeals. 
(a)  Filing. Any person may appeal an action of the township supervisor, the fire chief, or their designees made pursuant to section 22-222 by filing with the township supervisor a notice of appeal within 21 days of such action and a statement of appeal within 30 days of the date that the order being appealed was issued. A notice of appeal shall include, as a minimum, name, address, telephone number, date and a statement of intent to appeal. A statement of appeal shall include all information contained in the notice of appeal, a description of the nature of the appeal and any pertinent documentation. 
(b)  Appeals board. The board of wellhead protection appeals is hereby established. The board shall consist of the township supervisor and three designees to be named by the township supervisor. No appointment shall be final unless approved by the township board. The three designees shall serve for a term of two years. The appeals board shall have the authority to take appeals, investigate matters related to such appeals, and deny, uphold or otherwise modify or waive the actions pursuant to section 22-222 on a case-by-case basis. The appeals board shall develop rules and regulations of operation consistent with its authority, and subject to approval by the township supervisor. 
(Ord. No. 110, art. 17, 11-8-2000)  
Secs. 22-227—22-250. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - REGULATED SUBSTANCES 
 
Sec. 22-251. - Designated. 
The substances to be regulated under this article (referred to in this division as "regulated substances"), are chemicals and mixtures of chemicals which are health hazards. Regulated substances include: 
(1)  Those substances as defined by the state occupational safety and health administration (MIOSHA) as regulated under title III of the Superfund Amendments and Reauthorization Act (SARA), currently reported on MIOSHA material safety data sheets. A booklet listing substances regulated under this section shall be made available at the township offices. 
(2)  Petroleum and non-solid petroleum derivatives (except non-PCB di-electric fluids). 
(Ord. No. 110, art. 8, 11-8-2000)  
Sec. 22-252. - Exclusions. 
(a)  Any exclusions set forth in this section shall apply provided that the exclusion does not substantially increase any risk or hazard to the public health or water supply, wells or wellfields, and provided further that any spill, leak, discharge or mishandling shall be subject to the provisions of section 22-255. Any exclusions granted in this section shall not remove or limit the liability and responsibility of any person or activity involved. 
(b)  A limited exclusion from regulated substance activity inventory reporting and handling restrictions pursuant to section 22-253 is hereby authorized for incidental uses of regulated substances provided the uses are limited as follows: 
(1)  The aggregate of regulated substances in use may not exceed 20 gallons or 160 pounds at any time. 
(2)  The total use of regulated substances may not exceed 50 gallons or 400 pounds in any 12-month period. 
(c)  A limited exclusion from regulated substance activity inventory reporting and handling restrictions pursuant to section 22-253 is hereby authorized for non-routine maintenance or repair of property in the wellhead protection overlay zone provided the uses are limited as follows: 
(1)  The aggregate of regulated substances in use may not exceed 50 gallons or 400 pounds at any time. 
(2)  The total use of regulated substances may not exceed 100 gallons or 800 pounds in any 12-month period. 
(d)  A limited exclusion from regulated substance activity inventory reporting and handling restrictions pursuant to section 22-253 is hereby authorized for regulated substances which are cleaning agents, provided such cleaning agents are packaged for personal or household use or are present in the same form and concentration as a product packaged for use by the general public, and provided the aggregate inventory of such cleaning agents shall not exceed 100 gallons or 800 pounds at any time. In no case shall regulated substances claimed under the exclusion include hydrocarbon or halogenated hydrocarbon solvents. 
(e)  A limited exclusion from regulated substance activity inventory reporting and handling restrictions pursuant to section 22-253 is hereby authorized for medical and research laboratory uses in the wellhead protection overlay zone; provided, however, regulated substances shall be stored, handled or used in containers not to exceed five gallons or 40 pounds of each substance and the aggregate inventory of regulated substances shall not exceed 250 gallons or 2,000 pounds. 
(f)  An exclusion from regulated substance activity inventory reporting and handling restrictions pursuant to section 22-253 is hereby authorized for the transportation of regulated substances through the wellhead protection overlay zone provided that the transporting vehicle is in compliance with the applicable township ordinances and federal and state laws and regulations, and provided that the regulated substance is fueling the transporting vehicle or the transporting vehicle is in continuous transit, making deliveries, or is stopped for a period of time not to exceed ten hours. 
(g)  A limited exclusion from regulated substance activity inventory reporting and handling restrictions pursuant to section 22-253 is hereby authorized for owners and occupants of single-family or two-family residences; provided, however, the storage and use of regulated substances are related to the maintenance of the residence or vehicles under control of the occupant and provided waste regulated substances are appropriately and legally disposed of. 
(Ord. No. 110, art. 11, 11-8-2000)  
Sec. 22-253. - Storage, use and other handling restricted. 
No person shall place, deposit or permit to be deposited, store, process, use, produce, dispose of, transport or discharge (referred to in this division as "handle") any regulated substance on public or private property within the wellhead protection overlay zone, except as provided by law, statute, ordinance, rule or regulation and except as allowed for limited quantities pursuant to section 22-252. 
(Ord. No. 110, art. 9, 11-8-2000)  
Sec. 22-254. - Activity inventory reports. 
(a)  Except as provided in section 22-252, any owner or occupant of any land in the wellhead protection overlay zone at the effective date of Ordinance No. 110 shall file a regulated substance activity inventory report, which shall consist of a copy of the MIOSHA material safety data sheets or a hazardous substance reporting form available at the township. The report shall be filed within 180 days of the effective date of Ordinance No. 110 and at 24-month intervals thereafter. 
(b)  Except as provided in section 22-252, any new owner or occupant of any land in the wellhead protection overlay zone shall file a regulated substance activity inventory report prior to receipt of a certificate of occupancy and at 24-month intervals following the date of occupancy. For purposes of this article, the term "new" shall be defined as subsequent to the effective date of Ordinance No. 110. 
(c)  Where a person owns, operates or occupies more than one location, regulated substance activity inventory reports shall be made for each location. 
(Ord. No. 110, art. 10, 11-8-2000)  
Sec. 22-255. - Spills, leaks or discharges. 
(a)  Any person with direct knowledge of a spill, leak or discharge of a regulated substance within the wellhead protection overlay zone shall, if such spill, leak or discharge escapes or has potential to escape containment or contacts a non-impervious ground surface and is not immediately and completely remediated, give notice to the township fire department. The notification shall include, at a minimum, the location of the incident, name and telephone number, date and time thereof, type of substance, concentration and volume, and control or corrective action taken. Such notification shall in no way alleviate other local, state and federal reporting obligations as required by law. Notice to the township shall be provided within one hour of the spill, leak or discharge. 
(b)  Any person who spills, leaks or discharges such substance shall be liable for any reasonable expense, loss or damages incurred by the township in response to such an incident, in addition to the amount of any fines imposed on account thereof under state and federal law. Such person shall document and maintain sufficient records so as to reflect accurately the circumstances related to any such incident and develop and implement procedures to substantially eliminate the likelihood of reoccurrence of such spills, leaks or discharges as soon as practicable following the incident, but no later than 180 days after the incident. 
(c)  The township shall post signs in conspicuous places advising residents and transporters of regulated substances of the existence of the wellhead protection overlay zone and of the notification procedures in the event of a spill or accidental discharge. 
(Ord. No. 110, art. 12, 11-8-2000) 
 
  
Secs. 22-256—22-299. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - SOIL EROSION AND SEDIMENTATION CONTROL 
 
Sec. 22-300. - Adoption of rules by reference. 
Part 91 Soil Erosion and Sedimentation Control of the Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act and the Administrative Rules promulgated under Part 91 are adopted by reference. A copy of Part 91 and the Rules shall be on file at the building department of the township. Each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of such rules and regulations are adopted and made part hereof as if fully set out in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 129, 12-10-2014)  
Sec. 22-301. - Municipal enforcing agency. 
The building department of the township shall become the municipal enforcing agency in regard to Part 91, Soil Erosion and Sedimentation Control of the Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act, Public Act No. 451 of the Public Acts of 1994, as amended (Part 91) being MCL 324.9101 et seq. and Administrative Rules promulgated by the state department of environmental quality as amended, within the municipal limits of the township. 
(Ord. No. 129, 12-10-2014)  
Sec. 22-302. - Permit and inspection fees. 
Soil erosion permit and inspection fees shall be established by the township board of trustees and shall bear a reasonable relationship to the cost, including overhead, of the service or act. The following fee schedule is applied to soil erosion permit and inspection fees: 
(1)  Residential/single lot permits: 
a.  Annual plan review and inspection fee: $250.00. 
b.  Additional inspections/re-inspections: $100.00 per inspection. 
c.  Bond: $500.00. 
(2)  Commercial permits: 
a.  Plan review fee: $250.00. 
b.  Annual inspection fee: $1,500.00. 
c.  Additional inspections/re-inspections: $100.00 per inspection. 
d.  Bond: $5,000.00. 
(Ord. No. 129, 12-10-2014)  
Sec. 22-303. - Fees and bonds. 
Fees for plan examination, permits and inspections and required bond amounts which may become due and payable under this chapter shall be determined by resolution of the township board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 129, 12-10-2014)  
Sec. 22-304. - Appeals. 
Any applicant who is aggrieved by an administrative determination by the building department, pursuant to this chapter, may appeal such determination to the township supervisor or designee, which shall afford a hearing to the applicant within 30 days following the written submission of such an appeal. The township supervisor or designee shall render its decision following such hearing, which decision shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 129, 12-10-2014)  
Sec. 22-305. - Penalty. 
Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is responsible for a civil infraction and shall be subject to the provisions of a civil fine as provided for in Part 91, Soil Erosion and Sedimentation Control of the Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act, Public Act No. 451 of the Public Acts of 1994, as amended, being MCL 324.9121 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 129, 12-10-2014)  
Chapter 26 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 10; emergency services, ch. 18; fires in parks, § 34-35. 
 
Sec. 26-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Fire department means all personnel, facilities and equipment utilized for the prevention of fires and the protection of persons and property from exposure to the damages of fires and explosions. 
Governing body means the township, an authority created under state law, or any other governmental or intergovernmental body authorized to administer and govern the fire department under state law by agreement or otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 95.001, §§ 1.5, 1.6, 12-12-2001) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.
