(4)  Allowances for changes in pipe size in gravity sewers. Maximum flow velocity for pipe flowing full shall be maintained by matching 0.80 of the diameter depth above invert for pipe size increases. 
(5)  Allowances for direction change in gravity sewers. Provide a drop of 0.10 feet in the downstream sewer invert for a direction change of 30 degrees or greater to compensate for velocity head loss of the incoming flow. 
(f)  Basis of design-low pressure sanitary sewer. 
(1)  A low pressure sanitary sewer system consists of individual grinder pump stations at each building site, connecting to a common pressurized sewer to convey domestic waste to an acceptable outlet. 
(2)  Delineation shall be shown between the proposed pressure sewer system and any other sanitary sewer system within or in relation to the development. 
(3)  Submissions for review shall include a tabulation of occupancy (usage) types and the conversion of these into terms of equivalent single-family units. The tributary area, in acres, may be used to calculate dwelling units based on density allowed in the zoning ordinance. The adopted "schedule of unit assignment factors" shall be used to convert the different occupancy types to equivalent single-family units. 
(4)  Property owners will be required to use a contractor approved by the township to connect to the low pressure sewer, grinder pump installation, and the installation of the sewer lead. 
(5)  Connections to the low pressure sewer shall be initiated through the township building department. 
(6)  Property owners shall be required to use the approved township grinder pumps when connecting to the low pressure sewer. 
(g)  Depth of sewers. 
(1)  No sanitary sewer shall have less than five feet of cover. 
(2)  In general, gravity sanitary sewers shall have a minimum depth of ten feet from top of curb (or centerline if uncurbed) to the invert of sewer. The sewer shall have sufficient depth to serve a standard depth basement by gravity. 
(h)  Special backfill requirements. 
(1)  Granular material meeting the requirements for MDOT granular material, Class II, shall be required for full depth backfill of trenches, above a horizontal line one foot above the pipe, under existing or planned road surfaces, pavements, curbs, driveways, parking areas and sidewalks, and where the trench edge is within three feet of the edge of existing or planned pavements. 
(2)  Backfill shall be compacted to a minimum of 90 percent maximum dry density from above the pipe to 18 inches below grade installed in six-inch layers. Compaction shall be 95 percent of maximum dry density for top 18 inches of trench. The compaction results will be determined by a Modified Proctor Test, ASTM Designation D-1557. Frozen material is prohibited. These requirements should be observed for areas that are within a one-on-one influence of roadway. 
(3)  Building lead trenches shall have compacted granular backfill within the entire street right-of-way where sidewalks are required. Compacted granular backfill shall be provided between all utility crossings. 
(i)  Building leads. 
(1)  Unless otherwise approved, construction of building leads from a gravity sanitary sewer to the easement, right-of-way, and/or property line, for each fronting parcel in which the sewer is designed to serve, shall be included with the construction of the sanitary sewer. 
(2)  Where construction of building leads to the property line is not required concurrently with gravity sanitary sewer construction, a wye branch with riser, and water-tight stopper or plug, shall be installed for every lot or building site which the sewer is designed to serve. 
(3)  For service leads beyond the right-of-way, cleanouts shall be installed in accordance with the local plumbing codes and in no case greater than 100 feet measured from the main line public sanitary sewer or at any bend 45 degrees or greater. 
(4)  Minimum size for building leads shall be six inches in diameter, SDR 23.5. 
(5)  Minimum slope for building leads shall be one-eighth inches per foot (1.00 percent). 
(j)  Manholes—Gravity sewer. 
(1)  Location. Manholes shall be constructed at every change in sewer grade, alignment, or pipe size, and at the end of each sewer line. Generally maximum distance between manholes shall be as follows: 
Diameter of Sewer 
(inches) 	Maximum Manhole Spacing 
(feet) 
8—21 	400 
24—30 	450 
36—42 	500 
 
(2)  Monitoring manholes are required for all nonresidential connections to the sanitary sewer system. 
(3)  Drop connections. 
a.  Internal drop connections are required at manholes where the outlet pipe is 18 inches or more below the inlet pipe. Inverts shall be matched at the flow line whenever possible if 18 inches or less. 
b.  Generally, drop connections are discouraged and will be considered only if other alternatives are not acceptable. External drop connections are not permitted. 
(k)  Air release valves (ARV), intermediate flushing connections (IFC), branched flushing connections (BFC) and terminal flushing connections (TFC)—Low pressure and forcemain sewer. 
(1)  Air release valves shall be located at all high points in low pressure and force main sewers. 
(2)  Intermediate flushing connections in low pressure and force main sewers shall be located so as not to allow more than 1,000 feet between structures. Intermediate flushing connections may also be required at significant low points. 
(3)  Branched flushing connections shall be located at places where the low pressure sewer branches off. 
(4)  Terminal flushing connections shall be located at the ends of the low pressure and force main sewer systems. 
(l)  Stubs. Where future connections to a manhole are anticipated, stubs or blind drop connections, with watertight bulkheads, shall be provided. Stubs shall be ten feet minimum in length. Deeper sewers should allow for one-on-one excavation for future connections (20-foot sewer — 20-foot stub). 
(Ord. No. 106A, § 5.2, 12-12-2007)  
Sec. 42-203. - Final acceptance. 
(a)  Construction observation shall be required as described in section 42-157. This includes construction of all sanitary structures, pipe installation, pumps, and testing. 
(b)  All sewers shall be flushed and cleaned followed by air testing in accordance with all local, state and federal regulations. Videotaping of the sewer shall be conducted and reviewed to assure the sewer is acceptable. 
(c)  A set of approved record drawings, an approved bill of sale, and a copy of any recorded easement that was required for construction, shall be submitted to the township prior to final acceptance of the sanitary sewer. 
(Ord. No. 106A, § 5.3, 12-12-2007)  
Secs. 42-204—42-210. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 6. - STORMWATER MANAGEMENT 
 
Sec. 42-211. - Generally. 
The management of increased stormwater which results from the development of vacant land or expansions to existing facilities will be considered as a critical component of all development plans which are submitted to the township for approval. The intent of this standard is to provide guidelines for the sound management of stormwater runoff and to provide sufficient flexibility for design professionals to develop innovative solutions that protect the resources of the township while meeting the objectives of water quality preservation and flood control. 
All storm sewer systems and its appurtenances shall be designed to the current standards of the township, the county drain commissioner, the county road commission, the state department of transportation, and other agencies having jurisdiction over the storm sewer. Additionally, the standards set forth in chapter 22, articles III and IV, shall be adhered to. 
The use of natural drainage features, shallow swales and landscape areas shall be incorporated into the drainage planning for a site whenever possible. The objective is to achieve a functional and aesthetically pleasing development that minimizes the use of extensive enclosed storm drains and large obtrusive stormwater detention or retention basins while providing for the proper management of stormwater runoff. 
Development plans must present a unified design that, as a minimum, provides the following protections: 
(1)  The design must show that the development will not cause any impact to downstream properties or upstream properties. Both the rate of stormwater discharge, and the volume of stormwater discharge must be considered. 
(2)  The development plan shall be fitted to the topography and soil to create the least erosion potential and to effectively accommodate the increased runoff caused by changed soil and surface conditions during and after development. 
(3)  The design must demonstrate the use of best management practices for minimizing erosion and controlling sedimentation and other pollutants through all phases of construction. 
(4)  The design must demonstrate that proposed buildings or other permanent structures on and adjacent to, a proposed development are and will remain safe from flooding. 
(Ord. No. 106A, § 6.1, 12-12-2007)  
Sec. 42-212. - Soil erosion and sedimentation control. 
Under the Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act, Act No. 451, Part 91, of the Public Acts of 1994, the developer shall submit an erosion control plan to the county drain commissioner, soil erosion control division. The soil erosion and sedimentation control permit must be issued by the OCDC prior to any earth moving operations. The methods used for soil erosion control must be in accordance with the current Oakland County Erosion Control Manual and Specifications. 
An approved National Pollution Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permit where applicable, will be required prior to the commencement of any earth moving operations. 
To provide effective erosion and sedimentation control, practical combinations of the following technical principles shall be applied to the erosion control aspects of the plan: 
(1)  Under Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act, Act No. 451, Part 91, of the Public Acts of 1994, the developer shall submit an erosion control plan to the county drain commissioner for permit issuance. An approved soil erosion permit from the county drain commissioner, as well as the National Pollution Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permit where applicable, shall be required prior to the commencement of any earthmoving operations. 
(2)  The permittee shall be responsible for maintaining temporary erosion control devices during all phases of construction. 
(3)  The smallest practical area of land shall be exposed at one time during development. 
(4)  When land is exposed during development, the exposure shall be kept to the shortest possible period of time. 
(5)  Temporary vegetation and/or mulching shall be used to protect critical areas exposed during development. 
(6)  Temporary sedimentation basins (debris basins or silt traps) shall be installed and maintained to remove sediment from runoff waters from land undergoing development. 
(7)  Mud mats shall be installed at construction access points to provide a buffer area where vehicles can deposit mud and sediment prior to leaving the site, to control erosion from surface runoff, and to help control dust. 
a.  Sediment basins for construction purposes shall be separated from permanent stormwater detention or retention basins. 
b.  Basins shall be designed in accordance with the current county drain commissioner's standards for sedimentation basin design. 
c.  Construction runoff shall be directed to the basin in a controlled manner through mass grading techniques, diversion berms/swales, enclosed storm sewers or any combination thereof that would limit runoff velocities and provide for the least potential for erosion of the site. 
(8)  Areas set aside on the site for equipment storage, laydown, fuel, lubricants, chemical compounds and material stockpiles shall be contained in such a manner as to prevent any leakage or spillage from contaminating the surrounding soils and groundwater, and from entering any stormwater management system or existing surface waters. 
(9)  Filters shall be provided at catch basins and culvert inlet points to prevent the accumulation of sedimentation into storm sewers for both new and existing systems. 
(10)  Adequate dust control shall be maintained at all times. Surface streets adjacent to the site must be cleaned of any deposits on a daily basis. 
(11)  On larger projects or when phasing is involved, the developer may be required to provide alternate construction drives to the site to avoid damage to newly constructed streets. All construction drives shall be approved by the township. 
(12)  Permanent vegetation and stormwater structures shall be installed as soon as practical in the development. 
(13)  Whenever feasible, natural vegetation shall be retained and protected. 
(14)  Riprap shall be required at all storm sewer outlet points and prior to entering pipe entrances to detention or retention basins. The minimum width of the riprap shall be a minimum two times the outside diameter of the pipe. The riprap shall extend from the bottom of the basin around to the top of the pipe. Two types of materials to be used may include: 
a.  Eight-inch diameter to 15-inch diameter fragmented limestone or other suitable rock underlain with geotextile fabric. Cobblestone, broken concrete or grouted rip rap is not preferred. Larger diameter outlets may require larger riprap as velocity and flow condition dictate. 
b.  Gabions installed per the manufacturer's specifications. 
(15)  A bar screen is required for all pipe outlets and inlets eight-inch diameter and larger. 
(Ord. No. 106A, § 6.2, 12-12-2007)  
Sec. 42-213. - Stormwater management basins and pretreatment systems. 
On-site stormwater detention or retention is necessary for all developments in the township (including private roads) whenever runoff is increased. Waiver of this requirement may be considered by the planning commission upon submittal of a request for waiver, and report stating the reasons why detention or retention should not be necessary. Such report shall include maps, charts, and calculations prepared by a professional engineer registered in the state. The report and the request shall be subject to review and recommendation by the township engineer. 
Generally speaking, detention basins temporarily store storm runoff for a period of time in which the runoff is released through a positive outlet, at a controlled rate. Retention basins do not have a positive outlet, so that the stored runoff will percolate into the existing soils. 
Infiltration (recharge) systems that store and release runoff through permeable soils to the groundwater may be allowed under specific circumstances and with the review and approval of the township engineer. 
In cases where the requirements for detention/retention basins have been waived, stormwater pretreatment (in the form of permanent debris and sedimentation control systems) will be required. 
(1)  Detention basins. 
a.  Detention basins may only be used when the design shows that there is an adequate positive outlet for the stormwater, and where the increased volume of stormwater will not damage downstream property owners. Construction drawings must include sufficient off-site information to demonstrate the existence of an adequate outlet. 
b.  Water originating from off-site is not required to be detained in the on-site detention basin. Stormwater originating from off-site should be diverted around the detention basin whenever practical, and where the diversion will not increase the erosion of soils. 
c.  Detention basins shall be designed so that the resulting stormwater discharge from the developed site does not exceed the agricultural rate of discharge from the site. The township has defined an agricultural rate of stormwater runoff as 0.20 cubic feet per second per acre; or the capacity of the existing storm drainage facilities downstream of the detention basin outlet, whichever is less. 
d.  The volume of detention provided must be equal to or in excess of that calculated by the county drain commissioner's Simplified Detention Basin Design Procedure for a 100-year frequency storm. The volume of sediment storage is in addition to the volume required for detention. 
e.  The maximum water level shall be controlled by gravity outlets. The use of pumps for dewatering is not allowed. 
f.  Detention basin volumes shall not include volumes below the invert of outlet pipe(s). An additional one foot of volume below the outlet pipe invert is required to be incorporated into the design for sediment storage. 
g.  Detention basins shall be provided with an overflow spillway or storm sewer structure set at the high water levels capable of passing a 100-year frequency storm. The overflow spillway shall be located so not to cause potential damage to adjacent properties. To protect the surface from eroding overflow spillways shall be constructed with natural materials such as mesh or other approved materials. The edges of the surface shall have headers of the same or similar materials to prevent undercutting by the stormwater overflow. 
h.  A minimum of one foot of freeboard around the entire basin shall be provided above the design high water elevation. 
i.  All open detention basis having side slopes steeper than one foot vertical on four feet horizontal shall be fenced, except where their design is an integral part of the landscape, and where the township determines that depth and location are not hazardous. Fences shall be four feet high ornamental, vinyl coated chain link or approved equal fencing. Gates shall be 12 feet wide with double opening. The maximum side slopes of the basins shall be one foot vertical on four feet horizontal, with a four-foot minimum shoulder inside the fence. Refer to subsection q. for wet pond slope requirements. 
j.  Detention basins specifically designed for a location within yard setback areas shall be approved as to their concept and location by the planning commission. 
k.  The bottom of detention basins shall have a minimum slope of one percent (1.0%) to the outlet for dewatering purposes unless designed as a wet basin. 
l.  Detention basins are prohibited within a floodplain, defined as the area of land adjoining a river, stream, watercourse, lake or other body of water which will be inundated by a 100-year frequency flood event and where evidence exists that such flood has occurred, or would have occurred in the past given the land configuration. 
m.  Stormwater detention in paved parking lots is strictly prohibited. 
n.  Underground detention will be considered on a case-by-case basis with the following conditions: 
1.  Provisions must be made in the design for the collection and removal of sediment and debris accumulated in the system. All applicable health and safety requirements shall also be incorporated in the design of systems that require access by inspection or maintenance personnel. 
2.  Detailed shop drawings are required for underground detention systems, including pertinent engineering calculations and soils information. 
o.  Detention in wetland areas will be considered with the following conditions: 
1.  If in a regulated wetland, an MDEQ permit is required. 
2.  A permanent pretreatment system for the removal of sediment is required prior to outletting to the wetland. 
3.  Calculations indicating what the water elevation will rise to during the design storm event will be required. The design must show that properties adjacent to the wetland area will not be negatively impacted by the increase in stormwater runoff. Consideration must be given to future developments in the immediate area that could also use the wetland for stormwater management purposes. 
p.  The entire detention basin must be seeded or sodded. 
q.  Detention basins designed as a wet pond: 
1.  Shall have lowest overflow outlet elevation a minimum of eight feet above the pond bottom. 
2.  Side slopes higher than four feet below outlet shall be no steeper than one foot vertical to four feet horizontal. 
3.  Side slopes lower than four feet below the outlet shall be no steeper than one foot vertical to three feet horizontal. 
4.  All slopes above water surface shall be topsoiled seeded, and repeated as necessary until permanent vegetation is established or as requested. 
(2)  Retention basins. 
a.  If a gravity outlet cannot be provided, then the stormwater holding facility shall be designed as a retention basin with a volume equal to or in excess of the volume of stormwater runoff from two consecutive 100-year frequency storms including the volume of sediment storage. The stormwater storage volume shall be calculated by: 
Volume = 16,500 × 2 × total tributary acres × weighted runoff coefficient. 
b.  Off-site tributary areas: Retention basins must be sized for stormwater that originates off-site and which cannot be bypassed around the proposed retention basin to a site where the stormwater originally flowed to. In such cases, the retention basin must be sized using the following design parameters: 
Tributary acres: On-site area plus the off-site area. 
Runoff coefficient: Weighted C factor of the entire tributary area that considers the existing off-site conditions, and the proposed on-site improvements. 
c.  One foot of freeboard shall be provided around the entire basin above the design high water elevation. 
d.  All open retention basins having side slopes steeper than one foot vertical on four feet horizontal shall be fenced, except where their design is an integral part of the landscape, and where the township determines that depth and location are not hazardous. Fences shall be six feet high ornamental, plastic coated chain link or approved equal fencing. Gates shall be 12 feet wide with double opening. The maximum side slopes of the basins shall be one foot vertical on four feet horizontal, with a four-foot minimum shoulder inside the fence. 
e.  Retention basins are prohibited within a floodplain. 
f.  Retention of stormwater in parking lots is strictly prohibited. 
g.  The retention basin volume shall not include volumes below existing groundwater table or permanent water elevation. The retention basin design must demonstrate that the soils are capable of providing necessary infiltration. A soils report shall be submitted. 
(3)  Infiltration (recharge) systems. 
a.  An infiltration system will be considered if the design engineer can demonstrate that all of the following conditions exist: 
1.  An adequate positive outlet is not available or it is not possible to construct an off-site drainage system to convey basin discharge to the nearest outlet, and the installation of a retention basin is not feasible or practical. 
2.  The natural underlying soils are well-drained (hydrologic groups A or B) and the ground is suitable for percolation. 
3.  The underlying soils and ground water table have the ability to move water away from the site for the area and volume being drained. 
4.  Permanent pretreatment system upstream of inlet point to prevent any material from potentially clogging the infiltration medium (both surface and subsurface). 
5.  An overflow for a 100-year storm must be provided. 
6.  Infiltration system can be easily accessed for maintenance and replacement if necessary. The use of perforated storm pipe under pavements is discouraged. 
7.  There must be a method for determining a failure in the infiltration system. The system cannot be designed such that a failure in the infiltration system results in short circuit to the emergency overflow without on-site ponding. 
b.  The following information shall be supplied and/or incorporated in the design of infiltration systems: 
1.  Soil boring logs/sieve analysis/geotechnical report indicating type and properties of both surface and subsurface soils, suitability of surface soils for infiltration, capability of subsurface soils to conduct seepage to the underlying groundwater table, and flow from the system under mounding conditions at the maximum infiltration rate. Conditions greater than six inches/hour percolation rate will not be allowed. 
2.  Computed percolation rate and infiltration/exfiltration calculations. 
3.  Drainage area map, including any off-site contributing areas and emergency overflow route in the event of system failure. 
4.  Construction methods to prevent compacting the surface soils which may reduce the infiltration capacity of the soils. 
(4)  Permanent pretreatment systems. 
a.  Permanent pretreatment systems shall be sized for a "first flush" depth of 0.5 inches of runoff from the entire drainage basin area of the project. Permanent systems are required when discharging to an existing lake, stream, waterway or wetland. 
b.  Pretreatment can be in the form of open basins or engineered treatment systems. 
1.  Open basins shall be designed with minimum side slopes of one vertical to four horizontal, one foot of freeboard above design stormwater elevation, emergency sodded overflow, and outlet control devices. 
2.  Design calculations, plans and shop drawings for pre-fabricated engineered treatment systems shall be certified by a professional engineer licensed in the state. 
3.  Horizontal velocities through the system shall be minimized to prevent turbid flows and allow particles to settle in the pretreatment system. 
c.  Permanent pretreatment facilities will not be allowed within a floodplain. 
(5)  Maintenance of stormwater management basins and pretreatment facilities commercial, industrial and office sites. The proprietor shall maintain the stormwater management basins and permanent pretreatment facilities in proper working order at all times. 
(Ord. No. 106A, § 6.3, 12-12-2007)  
Sec. 42-214. - Grading and surface drainage. 
For all new subdivisions, site plans, private roads, and other development proposals within the township, a grading plan shall be submitted for review and approval. This standard establishes the minimum requirements for the design of grading and surface drainage in the township. 
(1)  Design considerations. 
a.  The grading plan shall be designed to insure that if a failure occurs in any storm drainage system, stormwaters will drain to an approved outlet thru overland swales without flooding buildings or adjacent properties. 
b.  Positive drainage of all yard areas is required for all residential developments. In special cases involving extreme vertical relief and wooded areas, isolated undrained potholes will be considered. These undrained areas must be provided with an easement for surface drainage and retention which will encompass the stormwater storage level for two 100-year frequency storms plus one foot of freeboard. 
c.  Generally, residential lot drainage shall be split at the building; drainage from the front of the building shall drain to the road and drainage from the rear of the building shall drain to the rear lot line. Rear to front surface drainage shall be avoided and will only be permitted under extreme topographic conditions. If rear to front drainage is permitted, only the drainage from the rear of the specific lot is allowed. 
d.  Rear to front lot drainage shall have protective drainage swales around the building. The high point of the swale shall generally be located a minimum distance of 20 feet off the rear of the building and one foot below the building brick ledge grade. 
e.  Side yard swales shall be a minimum of 0.5 feet below the building brick ledge grade of the building and located a minimum of ten feet away from the building. 
f.  Rear-yards shall be drained with swales and shallow ditches unless topographic features prevent surface drainage. 
g.  Meet existing ground at the exterior property boundaries. Construct an intercepting swale to prevent drainage onto adjacent property or lots. 
h.  All building footing drains and sump pumps shall discharge into enclosed storm systems outside of the road right-of-way if available. When footing drains or sump pumps are discharged onto the ground surface, the point of discharge shall generally be directed away from side lot lines and road right-of-way and not intensify stormwater to adjacent property. 
i.  In residential development with poor draining soils or high groundwater table, an enclosed drainage system for footing drains/sump pumps discharge is required. (See underdrain/sump pump collection systems). 
(2)  Slope requirements. 
a.  Protective perimeter slope: A minimum slope of five percent is required for areas within ten feet of building perimeter. 
b.  Minimum ground slope for any portion of the site shall be two percent. 
c.  Drainage swales along side and rear property lines, and the protective swale around buildings shall have a two percent slope. Rear yard swales shorter than 300 feet may have a minimum slope of one percent. 
d.  Maximum ground slope for any graded portion of the site shall be one foot vertical to four horizontal. Refer to Section 7.4C of the zoning ordinance for berm requirements. 
(Ord. No. 106A, § 6.4, 12-12-2007)  
Sec. 42-215. - Storm sewers and open drains. 
The following details and specifications shall be required for developments utilizing storm sewers and/or open drains to convey runoff from the site. All such storm drainage systems must outlet to either a detention basin, retention basin, infiltration system, or pretreatment facility as outlined in section 42-213 of this article prior to discharging to any natural or man-made water course, wetland, drain or other body of water. 
This section of the design standards establishes the minimum requirements for the design of storm drainage systems in the township. In general, the design engineer shall follow the storm drainage standards set forth from the OCDC. 
(1)  Storm sewer capacity. Sufficient capacity shall be provided in the storm sewer system to allow existing runoff from upstream drainage to "pass through" the proposed storm sewer system. 
a.  When a storm sewer is designed to provide capacity for upstream areas, the hydraulic gradient shall remain in the pipe. For storm sewer designed to take on-site drainage only, the hydraulic gradient must be no higher than one foot below storm structure rim elevations. 
b.  When the hydraulic gradient is above the top of the sewer pipe the design elevation of the hydraulic gradient shall be indicated on the profile at each manhole. 
c.  If the heights of the hydraulic gradient exceed two feet above the top of pipe, rubber gaskets at pipe joints shall be used. 
(2)  Hydraulics and hydrology. 
a.  Storm drainage systems shall be designed for a minimum of a ten-year storm. To determine the stormwater runoff, the rational method shall be used (Q = CIA). Where: 
Q = peak rate of runoff in cubic feet per second 
A = area in acres 
C = runoff coefficient for drainage area 
I = average rainfall intensity in inches per hour for a given time of concentration 
b.  The formula for rainfall intensity (I) shall be determined by using the formula: 
I = 175/(T + 25), where T is the time of concentration in minutes. For residential areas, the initial T shall usually be 20 minutes; for commercial and office areas, the initial T shall be 15 minutes or less. 
c.  Runoff coefficients shall be determined for each individual drainage area. Drainage area coefficient determination shall generally be based on the following: 
	Surface 	C 
BY TYPE 	Agricultural/grass 	0.15 
	Impermeable 	0.85 
	Basins and wetland 	1.00 
BY USE 	Residential 	0.35 
	Multiple housing 	0.55 
	Commercial/industrial 	0.75 
 
The above runoff coefficients are minimum. Actual site design may require an increase in runoff coefficient. A weighted runoff coefficient can be used (provide calculations). Coefficients proposed for a project are subject to review and approval by the township engineer. 
d.  An overland flood route for a 100-year storm frequency shall be provided and shown on the plans. A minimum freeboard of one foot shall be provided from any building's exterior finished grade (brick ledge) to the 100-year flood elevation. 
e.  In Manning's formula, n = 0.013, shall typically be used for hydraulic calculations. 
f.  Minimum design velocity shall be 2.5 feet per second and maximum design velocity shall be ten feet per second, with the pipe flowing full. 
g.  Allowable pipe slopes: 
Pipe Diameter 
(inches) 	Minimum Slope 
(feet per 100 feet) 
12 	0.32 
15 	0.24 
18 	0.18 
21 	0.14 
24 	0.12 
27 	0.10 
30 	0.09 
36 	0.08 
42 	0.06 
48 	0.05 
54 	0.04 
60 	0.04 
 
h.  For changes in pipe size, the maximum flow velocity for full pipe flow shall be maintained by continuity of the 0.80 diameter depth above invert. 
i.  A drop of 0.10 feet in the downstream sewer invert shall be provided for direction changes of 30 degrees or greater to compensate for velocity head loss of the incoming flow. 
j.  All road catch basin and inlet leads shall be laid on a minimum slope of one percent. 
k.  Wherever differences in manhole pipe invert elevations exceed two feet, a two-foot sump shall be provided to prevent channel erosion. 
(3)  Sewer pipe. 
a.  The minimum pipe size for storm sewers, catch basin leads and inlet leads shall be 12 inches in diameter. 
b.  Rear yard under drain system with no inlets: eight-inch perforated plastic pipe. 
c.  All storm sewer shall have a minimum of four feet of cover. 
d.  Storm sewers shall generally be located on the opposite sides of streets from water mains. Storm sewers shall be located ten feet from the right-of-way line in the public right-of-way. 
e.  A minimum ten feet horizontal separation from outside of pipes is required between storm sewer and water mains. 
f.  Granular material meeting the requirements for MDOT granular material, Class II, compacted to 95 percent maximum density, shall be required for full depth backfill of trenches under existing or proposed road surfaces, pavements, curbs, driveways, parking areas, and sidewalks, and where the storm sewer is within a one-on-one influence of the edge of existing or proposed pavements. Compaction testing shall be performed by an independent laboratory. 
g.  Storm sewer leads shall have compacted granular backfill within the entire street right-of-way beneath all existing and proposed pavement, and between all utility crossings. 
(4)  Manholes. 
a.  Manholes shall be located at: 
1.  Points where the sewer changes direction. 
2.  Points where the size of the sewer changes. 
3.  Points where the slope of the sewer changes. 
4.  The junction of sewer lines. 
5.  Street intersections or other points where catch basins or inlets are to be connected. 
6.  The end of the sewer line. 
b.  Maximum distance between manholes shall be as follows: 
Diameter of Sewer 
(inches) 	Maximum Manhole Spacing 
(feet) 
8—15 	350 
18—30 	400 
36—48 	500 
54—60 	550 
66—72 	650 
78 and larger 	1,000 
 
(5)  Catch basins, inlets, and end-sections. 
a.  Size. All inlet/rear-yard catch basins are to be four feet in diameter. 
b.  Catch basins shall be located: 
1.  At the radius returns of street intersections. A maximum distance of 150 feet is allowed when drainage is required to go around a corner between a high point and a corner catch basin. 
2.  At maximum intervals of 400 feet along a continuous slope. 
3.  At all low points in streets, swales and ditches, where applicable. 
4.  At a location to provide a maximum of 800 feet of drainage from two directions. 
c.  Standard rear yard basins shall be provided at all low points in easements. All catch basins shall be located within four feet of lot corners. A minimum of 12-foot side yard easements to the street shall be included at all rear yard basins. 
d.  All catch basins and inlets located at low points in poor draining soils shall have a minimum of two ten-foot runs of six inches perforated pipe with pea gravel bedding and backfill. Other trench collecting underdrains may be required, as required by the township engineer. 
e.  Catch basin leads may tap directly into sewers 48 inches in diameter and larger. 
f.  End-sections or headwalls shall be placed at all culverts and pipe inlets or outlets. 
g.  A prefabricated bar screen shall be used on all storm sewer openings 18 inches in diameter and larger. The bar screens shall be constructed according to an approved separate enlarged detail in the drawings and shall be designed to be sturdy, permanent easily maintained, non-clogging and shall have clear openings of no more than six inches. 
(6)  Underdrain/sump pump systems. 
a.  Where the proposed ground surface slope is less than two percent), supplementary drainage shall be provided by an underdrainage system. 
b.  Place underdrain at a minimum grade of 0.50 percent. 
c.  Trench for underdrain shall have adequate depth to provide gravity flow of sump pump discharge lines to underdrain, and shall have a minimum depth of three feet from the property line. 
d.  Install four-foot diameter inlets at 400-foot maximum intervals along the underdrain and located three feet from side lot lines. 
e.  Install a two-inch PVC capped tee at each lot for the sump pump with overflow device. 
f.  Show the underdrain system with sump pump on the storm sewer plan, with a dimension to the nearest lot line for each sump pump tee. 
g.  The sump pump collector system may be combined with the underdrain system, as noted above. 
h.  Minimum pipe material shall be eight-inch PVC constructed with a minimum of 3.0 feet of cover and 0.50 percent. 
i.  Eight-inch lines must not be used for the collection of surface runoff and therefore structures on these size lines must have solid covers. 
(7)  Open drain requirements. 
a.  Open drains shall have slope protection (rip-rap) at bends with radius of 500 feet or less and other points as designated by the township engineer. 
b.  The drain bottom and slopes, to the hydraulic gradient line, shall be sodded. The remainder of the drain shall be seeded. The township will not approve the work until all turf is established. 
c.  Specific drain cross-section and velocity control measures will be approved by the township engineer on an individual basis. 
(Ord. No. 106A, § 6.5, 12-12-2007)  
Sec. 42-216. - Easements. 
(a)  All easements shall be for access for maintenance and/or inspection of stormwater management facilities. 
(b)  Easements for storm sewers and open ditches shall be as specified in chapter 22, article III. The easement must be large enough to accommodate a slope of one horizontal to one vertical from the sewer invert to the edge of easement, but shall have a minimum width of 12 feet, centered upon the sewer or ditch. 
(c)  An easement shall be provided for the pretreatment system to allow access for maintenance and/or inspection. 
(d)  When drainage is required to flow across an adjacent lot, a 12-foot wide stormwater easement, centered on the drain, must be provided. This easement shall be dedicated to the homeowners association with restriction against use or occupation of easements by the property owners and/or by other utilities in any manner that would restrict storm system maintenance or repair operations. 
(e)  A written description and drawing of the easement(s) in a clear manner shall be prepared by the designing engineer and be presented to the township. The township engineer shall review the easement documents for compliance with all township standards and ordinances and provide approval or disapproval. 
(f)  Easements for possible extensions shall be provided to the property lines at locations designated by the township engineer. 
(g)  The horizontal alignment of sewers that are not proposed to generally follow street, drive, or parking area pavements, shall parallel property lines or building lines. 
(Ord. No. 106A, § 6.6, 12-12-2007)  
Sec. 42-217. - Maintenance. 
(a)  A maintenance agreement per chapter 22, article III, to provide the means and assurance that maintenance of stormwater management facilities, is required for all projects. 
(b)  In no instance shall any property owner, block, redirect, impede, or alter any existing or proposed stormwater runoff. 
(Ord. No. 106A, § 6.7, 12-12-2007)  
Sec. 42-218. - Final acceptance. 
(a)  All sewer systems shall be subject to a final inspection prior to acceptance of the system by the township engineer. 
(b)  A set of approved record drawings and a copy of all recorded easements that were required for and following construction are required for final acceptance of the storm sewer. 
(Ord. No. 106A, § 6.8, 12-12-2007)  
Secs. 42-219—42-230. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 7. - PAVEMENTS AND WALKWAYS 
 
Sec. 42-231. - Generally. 
This standard establishes the minimum requirements for pavement and pedestrian walkways installed within the township to provide public health, safety, and general welfare of the township. The most current township zoning ordinance shall be adhered, in particular Article 8, Access, Circulation, Parking, and Loading and Article 11, Private Roads, and article III of this chapter. All pavements that are within an additional jurisdiction shall meet the requirements established by said governing agency, such as, but not limited to the road commission for the county (RCOC), the state department of transportation (MDOT), and federal regulations for ADA requirements. 
(Ord. No. 106A, § 7.1, 12-12-2007)  
Sec. 42-232. - Private roads. 
The design of private roads shall conform to the township zoning ordinance, Article 11, Private Roads, and the following standards: 
Design requirements: 
(1)  Soil borings are required to be taken near the beginning and terminus of the proposed private road and at intervals not to exceed 500 feet in between. 
(2)  A soils report prepared by a qualified soils consultant shall be provided along with the private road plans. 
(3)  The applicant shall remove all unsuitable soil including muck, peat and marl, as well as brush, trees, tree stumps, and similar materials from the full width of the roadway, including the shoulders and ditches. 
(4)  The maximum grade allowed on any surface type is six percent. 
(5)  The minimum longitudinal grade on any roadway, except parking areas, shall be: 
a.  Six-tenths of a percent for concrete pavement. 
b.  One percent for hot mix asphalt pavement. 
(6)  Road grades in excess of six percent shall be approved by the township planning commission upon the recommendation of the township's consultants. At the intersection of two roadways, however, the maximum grade shall be three percent for a distance of 100 feet from the point of intersection. 
(7)  The intersection radii in residential developments shall be a minimum 25 feet. 
(8)  The intersection radii in industrial developments shall be minimum 35 feet. Radii for commercial developments will be evaluated on a case-to-case basis. 
(9)  The minimum length of vertical curves shall be 100 feet for grade changes greater than two percent. 
(10)  The minimum radius in horizontal alignment is 250 feet. When reverse curves are used provide a minimum 100 feet tangent. 
(11)  All dead-end roads shall terminate in a cul-de-sac turn-around with a minimum radius of 60 feet. This requirement may be waived or modified by the planning commission in the case of private roads having a boulevard cross section and/or more than one travel lane in each direction, and where it can be demonstrated to the satisfaction of the township engineer and fire chief that safe and efficient circulation will be maintained. 
(12)  Sight distances on horizontal and vertical curves and at intersections shall be a minimum of 260 feet measured at a point ten feet from the edge of the traveled way at a height of 42 inches to an object height of 42 inches. RCOC specifications shall be applied. 
(13)  Road and sidewalk cross sections, materials, and dimensioning shall meet the minimum requirements of the most current township pavement detail sheet. 
(14)  Approaches to any sites from roads under the jurisdiction of the RCOC or the MDOT shall be designed according to their criteria. Approval of these improvements by the above agencies must be obtained and furnished to the township engineer prior to township approval of the paving plans. Passing lanes and acceleration/deceleration lanes are required by the township on connections to all paved roads under RCOC or MDOT standards. 
(Ord. No. 106A, § 7.2, 12-12-2007)  
Sec. 42-233. - Public streets. 
All streets within public right-of-way shall be designed according to the criteria and specifications of the RCOC or MDOT. 
(Ord. No. 106A, § 7.3, 12-12-2007)  
Sec. 42-234. - Parking lots. 
The design of parking lots shall conform to the township zoning ordinance, Article 8, Access, Circulation, Parking, and Loading, and the following standards: 
(1)  Design requirements. 
a.  Soil borings are required to be taken at intermittent intervals of the proposed private parking lot and not to exceed 100 feet in between. 
b.  A soils report prepared by a qualified soils consultant shall be provided along with the paving plans. 
c.  The applicant shall remove all unsuitable soil including muck, peat and marl, as well as brush, trees, tree stumps, and similar materials from the full width of the parking lot, including the curbs and approaches. 
(2)  Parking lot classifications. 
a.  Class A: Light duty driveways and small parking lots with less than 40 stalls. This cross section is not suitable for heavy refuse truck pick-up or delivery services. In areas where this service is used, the Class B cross section should be used for routing to and from the service area. 
b.  Class B: Parking lots containing more than 40 stalls, light to medium truck traffic, typical for commercial lots. 
c.  Class C: Industrial lots, heavy truck uses, some commercial lots, bus routes. 
d.  Class D: Parking areas where extremely heavy truck traffic is encountered should be designed on a per case basis by a qualified professional engineer. 
(3)  Parking lot design requirements. 
a.  In parking areas the minimum grade allowed on any surface is one percent. 
b.  Parking lots shall be of the size, configuration, stripping, and space size as required by Article 8 of the township zoning ordinance. 
c.  Parking lot pavement cross sections, materials, and dimensioning shall meet the minimum requirements of the most current township pavement detail sheet. 
d.  Curbing is required around all parking lot perimeters and internal parking lot islands per the Section 8.7.D of the zoning ordinance. 
e.  HMA curbs will not be permitted. 
(Ord. No. 106A, § 7.4, 12-12-2007)  
Sec. 42-235. - Approaches. 
All drives and approaches within public right-of-way shall be designed according to the criteria and specifications of the RCOC or MDOT. The design of drives and approaches shall conform to Article 8, Access, Circulation, Parking, and Loading, of the township zoning ordinance and the following standards: 
Approach design requirements: 
(1)  Approach cross sections, materials, and dimensioning shall meet the minimum requirements of the most current township pavement detail sheet. 
(2)  Approaches shall have adequate flares to provide a safe turning radius. 
(3)  Heavily traveled industrial drives shall be designed by a qualified professional engineer. 
(4)  For residential approaches constructed on an existing curbed street, the curb and gutter shall be entirely removed or cut horizontally. 
(5)  When an MDOT Type "M" approach is constructed on an existing curbed street, the curb and gutter must be entirely removed. The extent of the removal shall extend to the nearest joint past the spring line of the new curb. 
(6)  Commercial and industrial approaches shall meet MDOT standards. 
(Ord. No. 106A, § 7.5, 12-12-2007)  
Sec. 42-236. - Sidewalks and safety pathways. 
This standard establishes the minimum requirements for pathways, sidewalks and sidewalk repair in the township. Sidewalks and/or safety pathways shall be required as set forth in Ordinance No. 67A, article III of chapter 46, and article III of this chapter. As used in this section, the terms sidewalk and safety path shall be used according to the "subclassifications" set forth in article III of this chapter. 
(1)  Sidewalk design requirements. 
a.  Where sidewalks/safety paths are proposed, they shall be indicated on the site plan as set forth in Ordinance No. 67A. 
b.  Sidewalk shall be five feet wide and generally located one foot inside the existing or proposed right-of-way line of public streets. A width of eight feet is required in areas with above average pedestrian traffic and along major streets. 
c.  Sidewalk transverse slopes shall meet the requirements of the township pavement standard detail sheet. Longitudinal grades shall not exceed one inch per foot. 
d.  ADA barrier free access ramps are required at all crossings. 
e.  Sidewalk alignment shall match adjoining or existing sidewalk where possible. The alignment shall integrate the natural features, yet maintain safety. 
f.  Sidewalk cross sections, materials, and dimensioning shall meet the minimum requirements of the most current township pavement detail sheet. 
(2)  Safety pathway design requirements. The inclusion of a safety path may be required as part of proposed development. The developer shall review article III of this chapter which regulates the development, construction, maintenance, and signage of safety paths. 
(3)  Repair requirements. 
a.  Sidewalk flags shall be replaced when one or more of the following conditions exist: stubber, crack, drainage problem, holes, scaling, slope, reverse pitch, and thin walk. 
b.  Replacement shall correct the problem and installation requirement shall be per design requirements. 
(4)  Performance guarantee. A performance guarantee for safety paths and sidewalks shall be as set forth in article III. 
(Ord. No. 106A, § 7.6, 12-12-2007)  
Sec. 42-237. - Inspection and final acceptance. 
(a)  The contractor shall notify the township engineer 48 hours before the conclusion of each step in the pavement construction. Inspections will be made at a minimum: 
(1)  Prior to the installation of the subbase. 
(2)  After the installation of the subbase. 
(3)  After final grading and drainage is complete of the subbase. 
(4)  During pavement installation. 
(b)  Testing will be required on materials used and installed for quality assurance as noted in the specifications. 
(c)  The applicant shall provide weigh slips which certify the quantity and class of material used for subbase and aggregate used for the road and shoulder surfaces. 
(d)  All public road systems shall be subject to a final inspection and approval by the road commission for the county prior to acceptance of the system by the township or issuance of any certificate of occupancy. 
(e)  A set of approved record drawings, together with copies of all material certifications, density testing reports, concrete cylinder test reports and any recorded easement shall be submitted to the township prior to final acceptance. 
(Ord. No. 106A, § 7.7, 12-12-2007)  
Sec. 42-238—42-250. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 8. - RESTORATION AND LANDSCAPING 
 
Sec. 42-251. - Generally. 
Article 7, Landscaping, Screening, Fences, and Walls, in the township zoning ordinance provides minimum standards for the design and use of landscaping, greenbelts, and screening, and for the protection and enhancement of the township's environment. The restoration and landscaping standards elaborate on the ordinance providing minimum safety and design criteria for restoration and landscaping to assure resident wellbeing and longevity of the installed landscaping and restoration. These landscape provisions are intended to apply to landscaping as required by Ordinance No. 67A. 
(Ord. No. 106A, § 8.1, 12-12-2007)  
Sec. 42-252. - Planting. 
(a)  Design requirements. 
(1)  Tree quantities, placement, and type shall meet the township zoning ordinance requirements and shall be approved by the township planning commission. 
(2)  The township zoning ordinance shall govern any deviations from the landscape plans. 
(b)  Installation. 
(1)  All plant material shall be installed in a sound workman like manner in accordance with ANLA guidelines and shall conform to the American Standard for Nursery Stock ANSIZ60.1 and be: 
a.  Nursery grown under climatic and in soil conditions similar to those in the locality of the project. 
b.  State department of agricultural inspected and approved. 
c.  No. 1 grade with straight, unscarred trunks, and well developed uniform crowns on trees. 
d.  The minimum acceptable sizes of plants measured before pruning with branches in normal position shall conform to measurements specified. 
(2)  Tree stakes, guy wires, and tree wrap if necessary are to be removed by the developer after two-year guarantee period. 
(3)  All landscaping costs shall be included as a part of the performance guarantee for the project. 
(4)  All plant material shall be subject to inspection and approval by the township planner. 
(5)  All plant tags shall remain until inspection and approval. 
(6)  All landscape areas shall have proper drainage that prevents excess water from standing on lawn areas or around trees and shrubs. 
(Ord. No. 106A, § 8.2, 12-12-2007)  
Sec. 42-253. - Lawn restoration. 
Disturbed areas shall be restored to original or better condition and per Section 7.5(C)(7) of the zoning ordinance. In addition, slope conditions will also determine the method of restoration. 
(Ord. No. 106A, § 8.3, 12-12-2007)  
Sec. 42-254. - Completion and maintenance. 
(a)  Upon completion and installation of the landscaping, the developer shall request final landscape inspection from the township. 
(b)  A certificate of occupancy will be issued only after completion of the landscape plan or the developer provides a cash deposit, letter of credit, or certified check to ensure installation of required landscaping. 
(c)  Planting materials shall be maintained in a healthy growing condition, neat and orderly in appearance for a period of two years following acceptance by township. Developer shall replace without cost to the township, any dead or unacceptable plants as determined by the township planner at any time during the guarantee period. 
(d)  If any plant material dies or becomes diseased, it shall be replaced within 30 days of written notice from the township or within an approved extended time period. 
(e)  All required irrigation systems must be maintained in working order and operated to ensure growth of the lawn and landscape areas. 
(f)  Overspray from irrigation on walkways and roadways shall not occur. 
(Ord. No. 106A, § 8.4, 12-12-2007)  
Sec. 42-255. - Walls. 
Article 7, Landscaping, Screening, Fences, and Walls, of the township zoning ordinance should be met. 
(1)  Walls a total height of four feet or higher shall require a seal of a registered engineer. 
(2)  Boulder walls shall have a maximum three feet vertical to one foot horizontal side slopes. 
(3)  Drawings shall show cross sections, heights, foundations, drainage, and proposed materials. 
(4)  It shall be the full responsibility of the design engineer to ensure that the retaining wall system selected for a given location is appropriate and assure stability. 
(5)  At the discretion of the township or township engineer soil bores and a geotechnical report with a detailed slope stability analysis may be requested for proposed retaining walls. 
(6)  Proper drainage shall be implemented in the retaining wall system. 
(7)  Living walls i.e. walls consisting of plant material, shall be reviewed on a site specific basis. 
(Ord. No. 106A, § 8.5, 12-12-2007)  
Chapter 46 - SUBDIVISIONS AND OTHER DIVISIONS OF LAND[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference— Any ordinance dedicating, accepting or vacating any plat or subdivision saved from repeal, § 1-11(12); buildings and building regulations, ch. 10; environment, ch. 22; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 42; utilities, ch. 62; waterways, ch. 66; zoning, app. B. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 46-1—46-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - ACREAGE DIVISIONS 
 
Sec. 46-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. Terms not defined in this article shall have the meaning as set forth in the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.). 
Accessible, in reference to a parcel, means that the parcel meets one or both of the following requirements: 
(1)  Has an area where a private driveway provides vehicular access to an existing private road or public road and meets all applicable location standards of the state transportation department or county road commission under Public Act No. 200 of 1969 (MCL 247.321 et seq.), or has an area where a private driveway can provide vehicular access to an existing private road or public road and meet all such applicable location standards. 
(2)  Is served by an existing easement that provides vehicular access to an existing private road or public road and that meets all applicable location standards of the state transportation department or county road commission under Public Act No. 200 of 1969 (MCL 247.321 et seq.), or can be served by a proposed easement that will provide vehicular access to an existing private road or public road and that will meet all such applicable location standards. 
Acreage division means the splitting, dividing, or separating of a parcel or tract of land into parts, by or for the purpose of selling or leasing that land for more than one year, or for building or development upon that land, where the resulting parcels are not, or will not, be owned by the same persons, or where the applicant seeks from the township a separate tax identification number for a resulting parcel of land, and the splitting or separation of that land is not pursuant to a procedure regulated under either article III of this chapter or the site condominium regulations of section 2227 of the zoning ordinance. 
Acreage split committee means a committee composed of the township zoning compliance official and three members of the township planning commission. 
Applicant means a person who may hold any divisible interest in land, whether recorded or not, and who is seeking approval for a division or partition pursuant to this article. 
Conceptual plan means the conceptual plan drawing or amended plan drawing required for lot division. 
Conceptual plan meeting means the consideration of a conceptual plan drawing or amended plan drawing at a regular or special meeting of the township acreage split committee. 
County thoroughfare road means a county road which is under the maintenance and supervision of the county road commission and serves as a thoroughfare for access to other private and public roads. 
Development site means any parcel or lot on which exists or which is intended for building development other than the following: agricultural use involving the production of plants and animals useful to humans, including forages and sod crops, grains, feed crops, and field crops, dairies and dairy products, poultry and poultry products, livestock, including breeding and grazing of cattle, swine, and similar animals, berries, herbs, flowers, seeds, grasses, nursery stock, fruits, vegetables, Christmas trees, and other similar uses and activities, and forestry use involving the planting, management, or harvesting of timber. 
Exempt split and exempt division mean the partitioning or splitting of a parcel or tract of land by the proprietor thereof, or by his heirs, executors, administrators, legal representatives, successors or assigns, that does not result in one or more parcels of less than 40 acres or the equivalent. For purposes of this definition, the term "40 acres or the equivalent" means either 40 acres, a quarter-quarter section containing not less than 30 acres, or a government lot containing not less than 30 acres. 
Existing easement means a dedicated easement or fee interest recorded with the county register of deeds which grants to a parcel, resulting from an acreage division, the right to cross an adjacent parcel or property in order to provide ingress and egress to a private road or public road. The easement shall have a minimum width of 66 feet as required for a public road right-of-way or as required for a private road right-of-way by the zoning ordinance. 
Private driveway means any piece of privately owned and maintained property which is used for access by vehicular traffic to a single parcel of private property and is not open to or normally used by the public. 
Private road means the improved area of a private road right-of-way designed and constructed pursuant to township requirements for private roads and providing the principal means of vehicular access to the abutting properties. 
Private road right-of-way means an area consisting of a minimum width of 66 feet, or a width otherwise approved by the township as provided for in this article or in the zoning ordinance, in which there is presently a private road, or where a private road is planned for construction in the future, as required by the township's ordinances. 
Proposed easement means a document, meeting all the recording requirements of the county register of deeds, for the purpose of conveying a dedicated easement or fee interest which grants to a parcel, resulting from an acreage division, the right to cross an adjacent parcel or property in order to provide ingress and egress to a private road or public road. The easement shall have a minimum width of 66 feet as required for a public road right-of-way or as required for a private road right-of-way by the zoning ordinance. 
Public road means the improved area of a public road right-of-way under the jurisdiction of the county road commission or state department of transportation. 
Public road right-of-way means an area consisting of a minimum width of 66 feet, or a width otherwise under the jurisdiction of the county road commission or state department of transportation, in which there is presently a public road or where a public road is planned for the future. 
Resulting parcels means parcels of land created as a result of the land division accomplished by this article. 
Road frontage means the minimum dimension as designated by the zoning ordinance. 
Zoning ordinance means the township zoning ordinance, Ordinance No. 67. 
(Ord. No. 104A, art. III, 11-10-1999) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 46-32. - Intent of article. 
This article is intended to provide for the health, safety and welfare of the residents and the property owners of the township by regulating the division and parceling of land within the township which is not otherwise subject to the platting procedures or requirements of article III of this chapter or other ordinances. It is apparent that adequate public or private roads are essential to ensure adequate access to individual parcels of real property by both the purchasers of those parcels and by emergency service vehicles. Requiring the construction of adequate private roads as part of the acreage division process is essential to the public health, safety, and welfare. The purpose of this article is to ensure adequate provision for ingress and egress to individual parcels of real property and structures thereon for vehicular traffic and utilities, to provide adequate access for emergency services and emergency service vehicles, and to provide rules and regulations for the orderly development of land as provided for in the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.). This article is further intended to ensure that parcels resulting from a division of land have sufficient area to conform with public health requirements for septic or other on-site waste treatment systems where the parcels are not served by a public sanitary sewer system. Further, this article is intended to ensure that parcels resulting from a division of land have sufficient area to accommodate a residential structure of a size conforming with the setback and minimum floor area requirements of the zoning ordinance for the zoning district where the parcel resulting from a division is located. 
(Ord. No. 104A, art. II, 11-10-1999; Ord. No. 104A.001, art. I, 10-11-2000)  
Sec. 46-33. - Compliance with article; exemptions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to subdivide or partition any parcel of land (acreage division) except in accordance with this article. The following, however, shall be exempted from approval and review pursuant to this article: 
(1)  A parcel proposed for subdivision through a recorded plat pursuant to the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.). 
(2)  A lot in a recorded plat proposed to be divided in accordance with the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.). 
(3)  An exempt split as defined in this article, as long as it is accessible. 
(4)  Other partitioning or splitting that results in parcels of 20 acres or more if each is not accessible and the parcel was in existence on March 31, 1997, or resulted from exempt splitting under the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.). 
(5)  A split accomplished pursuant to the site condominium regulations of section 2227 of the zoning ordinance. 
(b)  Any real property division which has not been approved by the township under the terms of this article and is not otherwise exempted or set forth in subsection (a) of this section will not be considered a valid division of such property, and any parcel of real property which has not received approval by the township pursuant to the provisions of this article will not be placed on the township tax rolls as a separate and individual parcel of property, nor shall building permits be issued for construction upon parcels resulting from a division not approved under this article. 
(Ord. No. 104A, art. IV, § 1, 11-10-1999)  
Sec. 46-34. - Land division authorization requirements. 
Under this article, a parcel of real property shall be partitioned or divided if it complies with or otherwise does not violate the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.) and article III of this chapter and also meets the following criteria: 
(1)  Approval by the acreage split committee pursuant to this article and compliance with all application and procedural requirements of this article are required. 
(2)  The resulting parcel shall have a width not less than that required by the zoning ordinance for the applicable zoning district. However, a resulting parcel intended for utility uses as defined under the zoning ordinance need not comply with the minimal width required for the applicable zoning district. 
(3)  The resulting parcel shall have an area not less than that required by the zoning ordinance for the applicable zoning district, except that the minimum resulting parcel area shall be no less than one acre in all zoning districts unless the resulting parcel shall have immediate access to a public sanitary sewer system. In addition, if the parcel is located in a residential district, the resulting parcel shall have sufficient area to conform with the building setback and the minimum floor area requirements of the zoning ordinance. However, a resulting parcel intended for utility uses as defined in the zoning ordinance need not comply with the minimal area required for the applicable zoning district. 
(4)  The resulting parcel shall have a depth-to-width ratio in conformance with the zoning ordinance for the applicable zoning district. However, a resulting parcel intended for utility uses as defined in the zoning ordinance need not comply with the depth-to-width ratio for the applicable zoning district. 
(5)  Every resulting parcel shall be accessible as defined under this article. 
(6)  For any parcel that does not meet the requirement of subsection (5) of this section for accessibility, and/or that does not meet the requirements of section 2207 and section 2217C2 of the zoning ordinance, the parcel may be split if it meets all of the other requirements of state law and of this article and other ordinances of the township, if the person seeking the split records a notice on the title at the office of the county register of deeds, which notice shall contain the written statement set forth below in this subsection, and the person seeking the split furnishes a copy of the recorded notice to the township, with proof of payment of the recording fee therefor. The notice shall state: "Notice is hereby given that the real property herein described is not a buildable parcel, and is not accessible as required in Charter Township of Oxford Ordinance No. 104A, Ordinance 67, and/or as defined in the Land Division Act, 1967 PA 288, MCL 560.101 to 560.293, until such time as the lot abuts a public road or an approved private road as required by Oxford Township Ordinances." This subsection shall not be interpreted as granting or creating a right to a variance from the requirements of the zoning ordinance or any other township ordinance. 
(7)  Any resulting parcel that is a development site shall have adequate easements for public utilities from the parcel to existing public utilities. 
(Ord. No. 104A, art. IV, § 2, 11-10-1999; Ord. No. 104A.001, art. II, 10-25-2000; Ord. No. 104A.002, art. I, 3-14-2001; Ord. No. 104A.003, arts. I, II, 1-23-2002)  
Sec. 46-35. - Initial review of application by zoning compliance official. 
(a)  Application materials. An applicant for an acreage division regulated by this section must submit to the township zoning compliance official a completed application form provided by the township. The applicant shall submit a base application fee that has been set by resolution of the Charter Township of Oxford Board of Trustees, which fee is nonrefundable. The applicant may also be required to deposit an amount into an escrow account to be drawn upon in the event review is required by the township planner, township attorney and/or township engineer. An additional deposit may further be required to be paid into escrow in the event the initial set escrow is exhausted. Any unused amount paid into escrow shall be returned to the applicant following final action on the acreage division application by the acreage split committee. The completed application must contain the following materials and information, along with such other information determined necessary by township board resolution. 
(1)  Proof of ownership. Written verification and proof of ownership of the parcel in question in the form of a policy of title insurance or a commitment for such policy, or by a warranty deed, quit claim deed and its associated warranty deed, land contract, or other legal document of conveyance, which identifies the owners of both the parcel of property proposed for division and the parent parcel of property. If the applicant is not the owner of the property or does not own full title to the property, the applicant must also submit documentation indicating all owners of the property in question along with written verification and proof of their ownership, and written authorization from those owners seeking the acreage division. 
(2)  Conceptual plan drawing. A drawing of the proposed acreage division, drawn to a scale of one inch equals 50 feet where the original unsplit parcel is ten acres or less, and one inch equals 100 feet for original parcels exceeding ten acres, which shall include the following information: 
a.  Dimensions of the existing parcel and proposed resulting parcels. 
b.  Location of the existing buildings and structures, including setbacks from all existing and proposed lot lines. 
c.  Location of existing public and private easements. 
d.  Location of existing and proposed easements and rights-of-way for public and private roads and utilities. 
e.  Location of proposed home or building sites, including all setbacks. 
f.  The proposed utilities and existing layout for water, sewer, gas and electrical utilities as applicable. 
g.  A location map drawn to a scale of at least one inch equals 2,000 feet, showing the location of the proposed acreage division in relation to the surrounding properties and land uses in the township. 
In regard to subsections (a)(2)b through e of this section, the conceptual plan drawing shall either show the required items or, if the items are not present, include an affirmative statement that the items do not exist and/or are not proposed. 
(b)  Application review and meeting. Upon receipt of the applicant's application and materials, the zoning compliance official may submit one copy of the application and plan to the township's planning consultant, attorney and engineer for their review. An initial meeting may be arranged by the zoning compliance official with the applicant, and may include the township planning consultant, township engineer, and township attorney for the purpose of reviewing the proposed acreage division and roads, rights-of-way, easements, and all information required for the application and conceptual plan drawing. If the township planning consultant, engineer or attorney is used, the applicant shall pay into an escrow account an amount to cover their cost as provided by this section. This discretionary meeting may be held for the purpose of providing recommendations to the applicant prior to submission of the proposed acreage division plan to the acreage split committee for its review and decision. 
(c)  Amendment of plan drawing. The applicant may amend the plan drawing to reflect the recommendations of the zoning compliance official and resubmit the application in compliance with this article. 
(d)  Determination of exclusion from platting provisions. The zoning compliance official shall determine whether the proposed acreage division is excluded from the platting provisions of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.) and article III of this chapter. The application for acreage division cannot proceed under this article unless the division is excluded from the platting procedures of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.) and article III of this chapter. The zoning compliance official may consult with other officials, including county officials, to make this determination. 
(Ord. No. 104A, art. V, 11-10-1999; Ord. No. 104A.004, art. 1, 5-14-2008)  
Sec. 46-36. - Preliminary approval. 
As soon as the zoning compliance official has completed initial review of the application and made other determinations as required by section 46-35, the official shall submit the application to the acreage split committee for its review for preliminary approval under this article. The acreage split committee shall grant or deny preliminary approval in writing. If preliminary approval is denied, the applicant must be provided reasons in writing for the denial. 
(Ord. No. 104A, art. VI, 11-10-1999)  
Sec. 46-37. - Surveyed site plan submission. 
Once preliminary approval has been granted, the applicant shall provide the acreage split committee with four copies of a surveyed site plan prepared by a registered surveyor or civil engineer which contains a minimum of the following survey information: 
(1)  The legal description and illustration of each existing easement or proposed easement for vehicular access and utility easements, if any. 
(2)  The legal description and illustration of the outside boundaries of the land being divided, including gross and net acreage. 
(3)  The legal description and illustration of each resulting parcel following division, including gross and net acreage. 
(4)  Proposed names for all private roads. 
(5)  If the township's wetland inventory map indicates the presence of wetlands on any resulting parcel, then a wetland consultant's report delineating such wetlands shall be provided. 
(Ord. No. 104A, art. VII, 11-10-1999; Ord. No. 104A.005, art. I, 6-9-2010)  
Sec. 46-38. - Acreage split committee substantive review. 
The acreage split committee shall review the application, the conceptual plan drawing and the surveyed site plan at a regular or special meeting of the acreage split committee. The acreage split committee may seek the assistance of the township planner, engineer, or attorney if necessary during review of the application. If such assistance is obtained, the applicant shall pay into an escrow account an amount to cover the cost of review by the township's planner, engineer or attorney as provided in section 46-35(a). The acreage split committee's review of the application, conceptual plan, and surveyed site plan drawing shall be based upon the following standards: 
(1)  Compliance with article. The proposed acreage division shall comply with the requirements of this article concerning road access, lot width, lot width/depth ratios, and area. 
(2)  Calculation of dimensions and area. In determining whether the surveyed site plan complies with the requirements of this article, all dimensions in the plan shall be exclusive of any public or private road rights-of-way or of existing easements or proposed easements. Utility easements for gas, electric, and telephone service intended to serve the individual parcel under consideration should not be excluded from the minimum parcel area. 
(2A)  Wetlands as defined in chapter 22, article IV, shall be excluded from calculation of a proposed resulting parcel's area for the purposes of determining whether the proposed resulting parcel complies with the minimum parcel area requirement; provided, however, that a proposed acreage division in which one or more proposed resulting parcel(s) lack sufficient parcel area solely because of the presence of wetlands may be approved if it meets all other requirements of Michigan law and this and other ordinances of the township, if the applicant records a notice on title at the county register of deeds for each such proposed resulting parcel, which notice shall contain the written statement set forth herein below, and the person seeking the split furnishes a copy of the recorded notice to the township, with proof of payment of the recording fee therefor. The notice shall state: Notice is hereby given that the real property herein described is presumed to be unbuildable under state law and/or township ordinance due to the presence of wetlands. This section shall not be interpreted as granting or creating a right to a variance from the requirements of Ordinance No. 67 (or any amendments thereto) or any other township ordinance. 
(3)  Survey approval by township assessor. The township assessor shall review the legal descriptions and illustrations contained in the site plan survey, and determine whether the legal descriptions are sufficient and in accordance with the standards used by the county department of equalization. 
(Ord. No. 104A, art. VIII, 11-10-1999; Ord. No. 104A.005, art. II, 6-9-2010)  
Sec. 46-39. - Variances.
