If some aspect of the applicant's proposed acreage division (shown by the surveyed site plan) fails to conform with the zoning ordinance concerning parcel width, parcel depth-to-width ratio, parcel area and road accessibility, the acreage split committee shall cease review of the proposed acreage division and shall not resume review of the proposed acreage division until and unless the applicant shall have obtained an appropriate variance from the township zoning board of appeals pursuant to the appropriate procedures of the zoning ordinance. An applicant's application for an acreage split shall not be considered complete if the proposed acreage division does not comply with the zoning ordinance as it pertains to a resulting parcel's width, depth-to-width ratio, area, and road accessibility and the applicant has not obtained a variance pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. No. 104A, art. IX, 11-10-1999)  
Sec. 46-40. - Acreage split committee final approval. 
Following receipt and review of the applicant's application, surveyed site plan and any comments or recommendations of the township planner, engineer or attorney, the acreage split committee shall grant the acreage division if it complies with this article or deny the proposed acreage division within 45 days from the date a complete application is received. The application shall be considered complete provided that the applicant has complied with all requirements of sections 46-33 and 46-34, has submitted all items required in section 46-35, has submitted a surveyed site plan as required in section 46-37 and does not require a variance from the zoning ordinance pursuant to section 46-39. The acreage split committee must state specific reasons for its finding to deny the acreage division. 
(Ord. No. 104A, art. X, 11-10-1999)  
Sec. 46-41. - Compliance with other ordinances. 
Final approval of an acreage division under this article does not constitute a determination that a resulting parcel is in compliance with other ordinances or regulations. 
(Ord. No. 104A, art. XI, 11-10-1999)  
Sec. 46-42. - Applicability of zoning ordinance. 
This article hereby incorporates by reference those provisions of the zoning ordinance that apply specifically to standards for a resulting parcel's width, area, depth-to-width ratio and road dimensions. Other provisions of the zoning ordinance shall have no application. 
(Ord. No. 104A, art. XII, 11-10-1999)  
Sec. 46-43. - Issuance of building permit. 
(a)  Verification of proper acreage division. Prior to the issuance of any building permit for construction upon a parcel of real property which has been divided pursuant to this article, the person applying for the building permit must first obtain verification of a proper acreage division from the township zoning compliance official. To obtain this verification, the applicant must provide the following to the zoning compliance official: 
(1)  Written verification and evidence of the approval of the division of real property by the township; 
(2)  A tax identification number (Sidwell Number) which has been assigned to each particular parcel of property to be built upon; 
(3)  A recorded copy of the survey, with legal description and drawings of the parcel of property; and 
(4)  A recorded copy of the legal document which establishes the applicant's ownership interest in the property, namely a warranty deed, quit claim deed, land contract, or other written evidence of ownership and title. 
(b)  Verification of adequate road access. No building permit shall be issued for construction upon a parcel of real property which has been divided pursuant to this article unless that parcel abuts and has access to a public road, or a private road approved and constructed in accordance with standards set forth in the zoning ordinance. 
(c)  Verification of adequate water supply and sewage treatment. No parcel less than one acre shall be issued a building permit unless the parcel has all of the following: 
(1)  Public water or city, county or district health department approval for the suitability of an on-site water supply under the same standards as set forth for lots under rules prescribed by the state department of environmental quality. 
(2)  Public sewer or city, county or district health department approval for on-site sewage disposal under the health department standards as set forth for lots under rules prescribed by the state department of environmental quality. 
(Ord. No. 104A, art. XIII, 11-10-1999)  
Secs. 46-44—46-70. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - LAND DIVISIONS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 46-71. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. All terms as defined in the Land Division Act shall control in this article unless indicated to the contrary in this article. 
Clerk means the clerk of the township. 
Commission means the planning commission of the township. 
Date of filing means: 
(1)  For tentative approval of the preliminary plat, the date of the initial planning commission meeting at which the proprietor presents the preliminary plat for consideration. 
(2)  For final approval of the preliminary plat, the date on which the proprietor files, with the clerk, the tentatively approved preliminary plat and a certified list of all authorities required for approval. 
(3)  For approval of the final plat, the date on which the proprietor files, with the township clerk, the original and the necessary prints of the final plat. 
Division means the partitioning or splitting of a parcel or tract of land by the proprietor thereof or by his heirs, executors, administrators, legal representatives, successors, or assigns for the purpose of sale, or lease of more than one year, or of building development, that results in one or more parcels of less than 40 acres or the equivalent, and that satisfies the requirements of sections 109 and 109 of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.108 and MCL 560.109 respectively). The term "division" does not include a property transfer between two or more adjacent parcels, if the property taken from one parcel is added to an adjacent parcel, and any resulting parcel shall not be considered a building site unless the parcel conforms to the requirements of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.) or the requirements of township ordinances. 
Easement means a grant by the owner of the use of land by the public, a corporation, or persons, for specific uses and purposes, to be designated as a "public" or "private" easement, depending on the nature of the use. 
Exempt split means the partitioning or splitting of a parcel or tract of land by the proprietor thereof or by his heirs, executors, administrators, legal representatives, successors, or assigns that does not result in one or more parcels of less than 40 acres or the equivalent. For a property transfer between two or more adjacent parcels, if the property taken from one parcel is added to an adjacent parcel, and any resulting parcel shall not be considered a building site unless the parcel conforms to the requirements of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.) or the requirements of this article or township ordinances. 
Improvements means grading, street surfacing, curb and gutter, sidewalks, crosswalks, water mains and lines, sanitary sewers, storm sewers, culverts, bridges, utilities, and other additions or modifications to the natural state of land which increases its value, utility or habitability. 
Lot means a measured portion of a parcel or tract of land which is described in a proposed or recorded plat. 
Major streets or thoroughfare plan means that part of the master plan which sets forth the location, alignment and dimensions of existing and proposed streets and thoroughfares. 
Master plan means the comprehensive land use plan for the township, including graphic and written proposals indicating the general locations recommended for the streets, parks, schools, public buildings, zoning districts, and all physical developments of the township, and includes any unit or part of such plan separately adopted, and any amendments to such plan or parts thereof duly recommended by the planning commission and adopted by the township board. 
Municipal engineer and engineer mean the consulting engineers of the township. 
Parcel and tract mean a contiguous area or acreage of land which can be described as provided for in the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.). 
Parent parcel and parent tract mean a parcel or tract, respectively, lawfully in existence on the effective date of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.), March 31, 1997. 
Plat means a map or chart of a subdivision of land. 
(1)  Preliminary plat means a map showing the salient features of a proposed subdivision submitted to an approving authority for purposes of preliminary consideration prepared in conformance with the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.). 
(2)  Final plat means a map of all or part of a subdivision providing substantial conformance to the preliminary plat of the subdivision prepared in conformance with the requirements of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.) and this article, and suitable for recording by the county register of deeds. 
Procedures guide means a guide for the platting of land in the township, including petition forms for platting , available from the clerk and consisting of a general guideline to proprietors. 
Proprietor and owner mean a natural person, firm, association, partnership, corporation or combination of any of them, which may hold any ownership interest in land, whether recorded or not. 
Secretary means the secretary of the township planning commission. 
Street means any dedicated avenue, boulevard, road, lane, parkway, viaduct, alley, or other way which is an existing state, county, or municipal roadway; or a street, as defined in this subsection, or way, on a plat duly filed and recorded in the office of the of the county register of deeds. A street, as defined in this subsection, includes the land between the right-of-way lines whether improved or unimproved and may comprise pavement, shoulders, gutters, sidewalks, parking areas and lawns. 
Alley means a minor service street used primarily to provide secondary vehicular access to the rear or side of properties otherwise abutting upon a street. 
Boulevard street means a street developed in two two-lane one-way pavements separated by a median. 
Collector street means a street intended to serve as a major means of access from minor streets to major thoroughfares which has considerable continuity within the framework of the major thoroughfare plan. 
Cul-de-sac street means a short minor street having one end permanently terminated by a vehicular turnaround. 
Major thoroughfare means an arterial street of great continuity which is intended to serve as a large volume trafficway for both the intermediate township area and region beyond, and may be designated in the township's major thoroughfare plan as a major thoroughfare, parkway, expressway or equivalent term to identify those streets comprising the basic structure of the street plan. 
Marginal access street means a minor street paralleling and adjacent to a major thoroughfare which provides access to abutting properties and protection from through traffic. 
Minor street means a street of limited continuity used primarily for access to abutting residential properties. 
Turnaround means a short boulevard street permanently terminated by a vehicular turnaround. 
Subdivision means the partitioning or splitting of a parcel or tract of land by the proprietor thereof or by his heirs, executors, administrators, legal representatives, successors, or assigns for the purpose of sale, or lease of more than one year, or of building development, that results in one or parcels of less than 40 acres or the equivalent, and that is not exempted from the platting requirements, of the Land Division Act by sections 108 and 109 thereof (MCL 560.108 and MCL 560.109, respectively). The term "subdivision" or "subdivided" does not include a property transfer between two or more adjacent parcels, if the property taken from one parcel is added to an adjacent parcel; and any resulting parcel shall not be considered a building site unless the parcel conforms to the requirements of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.) and the requirements of this article. 
Tract means two or more parcels that share a common property line and are under the same ownership. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 0200, 10-14-1998; Ord. No. 103.003, 8-10-2011) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 46-72. - Purpose of article. 
The purposes of this article are to provide for the orderly growth and harmonious development of the community; to secure adequate traffic circulation through coordinated street systems with relation to major thoroughfares, adjoining subdivision and public facilities; to achieve individual property lots and parcels of maximum utility and livability; to secure adequate provisions for water supply, drainage and sanitary sewerage and other health sites and other public facilities; to provide a reasonable and proper basis for the design and construction of residential, commercial or industrial projects having site improvements, including sanitary sewer, storm drainage, water main, site grading and paving; and to provide logical procedures for the achievement of these purposes. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 0102, 10-14-1998)  
Sec. 46-73. - Scope of article and Land Division Act. 
(a)  Subdivisions. Any subdivision of land as defined in this article or in the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.) is subject to the platting requirements of this article and the Land Division Act. 
(b)  Divisions. A division of land is not subject to the platting requirements of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.) and of this article. 
(1)  A division, together with any previous divisions of the same parent parcel or parent tract, shall result in a number of parcels not more than the sum of the following: 
a.  For the first ten acres or fraction thereof in the parent parcel or parent tract, four parcels. 
b.  For each whole ten acres in excess of the first ten acres in the parent parcel or parent tract, one additional parcel, for up to a maximum of 11 additional parcels. 
c.  For each whole 40 acres in excess of the first 120 acres in the parent parcel or parent tract, one additional parcel. 
(2)  For a parent parcel or parent tract of not less than 20 acres, the division may result in a total of two parcels in addition to those in subsection (b)(1) of this section if one or both of the following apply: 
a.  Because of the establishment of one or more new roads, no new driveway accesses to an existing public road for any of the resulting parcels set forth in subsection (b)(1) of this section or this subsection (b)(2) are created or required. 
b.  One of the resulting parcels under subsection (b)(1) of this section and this subsection (b)(2) comprises not less than 60 percent of the area of the parent parcel or parent tract. 
(3)  A parcel of 40 acres or more created by the division of a parent parcel or parent tract shall not be counted toward the number of parcels permitted under subsection (b)(1) and subsection (b)(2) of this section if the parcel is accessible as defined in the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.). 
(4)  A parcel or tract created by an exempt split or a division is not a new parent parcel or parent tract and may be further partitioned or split without being subject to the platting requirements of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.) or this article if all of the following requirements are met: 
a.  Not less than ten years have elapsed since the parcel or tract was recorded. 
b.  The partitioning or splitting results in not more than the following number of parcels, whichever is less: 
1.  Two parcels for the first ten acres or fraction thereof in the parcel or tract plus one additional parcel for each whole ten acres in excess of the first ten acres in the parcel or tract. 
2.  Seven parcels or ten parcels if one of the resulting parcels under this subsection comprises not less than 60 percent of the area of the parcel or tract being partitioned or split. 
3.  The partitioning or splitting satisfies the requirements of section 109 of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.109). 
(5)  A parcel or tract created under the provisions of subsection (b)(4) of this section may not be further partitioned or split without being subject to the platting requirements of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.) and this article, except in accordance with the provisions of subsection (b)(4). 
(6)  Although a division is not subject to the platting requirements of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.) or of this article pursuant to subsection (b) of this section, a division is subject to the procedural and other requirements of article II of this chapter and of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.). 
(c)  Exempt splits. 
(1)  An exempt split is not subject to the platting requirements of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.) or of this article. 
(2)  An exempt split or other partitioning or splitting of a parcel or tract that only results in parcels of 20 acres or more in size is not subject to approval under this article if the parcel or tract is not accessible and one of the following applies: 
a.  The parcel or tract was in existence on March 31, 1997. 
b.  The parcel or tract resulted from an exempt split or other partitioning or splitting under this section. 
(3)  The proprietor shall provide the purchaser of a parcel resulting from an exempt split or other partitioning or splitting under subsection (c)(1) of this section with the following written statement before closing: "This parcel is not accessible as defined in the Land Division Act, 1967 PA 288, MCL 560.101 to 560.293." 
(Ord. No. 103, § 0300, 10-14-1998)  
Sec. 46-74. - Compliance with applicable regulations. 
The approvals required under the provisions of this article shall be obtained prior to the installation of any subdivision or project improvements within the township, in public streets, public alleys, public rights-of-way and public easements, or under the ultimate jurisdiction of the township. All subdivision or project improvements within the public easements or under the ultimate jurisdiction of the township shall comply with all of the provisions and requirements of this article, the land improvement ordinance, or any other related ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 0700, 10-14-1998)  
Sec. 46-75. - Fees. 
(a)  All fees as provided in this section shall be paid by the proprietor at the time of submission of the respective plats or plans. 
(b)  The following fees shall be charged for examination of engineering and improvement plans for the land proposed to be subdivided: 
(1)  Preliminary plat: $550.00 lump sum for up to 15 lots, plus $15.00 for each lot over 15. 
(2)  Engineering plan review: 
a.  Grading: $350.00 lump sum for up to 15 lots, plus $15.00 for each lot over 15. 
b.  Drainage: $575.00 lump sum for up to 15 lots, plus $50.00 for each lot over 15. 
c.  Sanitary sewer: $375.00 lump sum for up to 15 lots, plus $25.00 for each lot over 15. 
b.  Water main: $375.00 lump sum for up to 15 lots, plus $25.00 for each lot over 15. 
b.  Water supply and wells: $550.00 lump sum for up to 15 lots, plus $5.00 for each lot over 15. 
b.  Pumping Station: $550.00 lump sum for up to 15 lots, plus $5.00 for each lot over 15. 
b.  Water booster station: $550.00 lump sum for up to 15 lots, plus $5.00 for each lot over 15. 
(c)  The following review fees shall be charged for examination and inspection of plats, land proposed to be subdivided, and related expenses: 
(1)  Sketch plan: $200.00 plus $5.00 per acre. 
(2)  Preliminary plat review (tentative and final): $350.00 plus $20.00 per acre. 
(3)  Final plat review: $250.00 plus $5.00 per acre. 
(d)  The applicant shall be required to deposit in escrow a fee for attorney review equal to a lump sum of $450.00 for up to 40 lots, plus $5.00 for each lot over 40 lots, for each set of preliminary plat and final plat documents submitted. The fee shall be applied to cover only services actually rendered at the hourly rate charged to the township, and any balance will be refunded to the applicant. 
(e)  If the actual reasonable cost to perform the reviews described in subsections (b)—(d) of this section exceeds the fees set forth in subsections (b)—(d) of this section, the township may require the applicant to pay an additional amount equal to the difference between such fees and the actual reasonable cost of review. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 0900, 10-14-1998; Ord. No. 103.002, arts. 1, 2, 3, 5-22-2002)  
Sec. 46-76. - Variances. 
The township board may authorize a variance from this article when, in its opinion, undue hardship may result from strict compliance. In granting any variance, the township board shall prescribe only conditions that it deems necessary to or desirable for the public interest. In making its findings, as required in this section, the township board shall take into account the nature of the proposed use of land and the existing use of land in the vicinity, the number of persons to reside or work in the proposed subdivision and the probable effect of the proposed subdivision upon traffic conditions in the vicinity. No variance shall be granted unless the township board finds that: 
(1)  There are special circumstances or conditions affecting the proprietor so that the provisions of this article would deprive the applicant of the reasonable use of his land. 
(2)  The variance is necessary for the preservation and enjoyment of a substantial property right of the petitioner. 
(3)  The granting of the variance will not be detrimental to the public welfare or injurious to other property in the territory in which the property is situated. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 1300, 10-14-1998)  
Sec. 46-77. - Violations and penalties. 
Any person, persons, firm, or corporation who violates any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, may be punished by a fine not exceeding $500.00 or by imprisonment in the county jail for a period not to exceed 90 days, or both such fine and imprisonment at the discretion of the court. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate violation 
(Ord. No. 103, § 1000, 10-14-1998)  
Secs. 46-78—46-100. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - SUBDIVISION PROCEDURE 
 
Sec. 46-101. - Generally. 
The preparation of a subdivision for platting shall be carried out through two phases: preliminary plat and final plat, all in accordance with the procedures in this division. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 0400, 10-14-1998)  
Sec. 46-102. - Initial investigation. 
(a)  Prior to the preparation of a preliminary plat, it is suggested that the proprietor investigate the procedures and standards of the township with reference to this article and the master plan as they affect the area in which the proposed subdivision is located. The proprietor should not submit the preliminary plat at this time. 
(b)  The proprietor should concern himself with the following factors: 
(1)  The proprietor should secure a copy of the zoning ordinance, this article, the petition to plat land (refer to procedures guide), and other similar ordinances or controls relative to the subdivision and improvement of land so as to make himself aware of the requirements of the township. 
(2)  Whether the area for the proposed subdivision is properly zoned for the intended use. 
(3)  An investigation should be made of the adequacy of existing schools. 
(4)  An investigation should be made of the adequacy of public open spaces, including schools and playgrounds, to serve the proposed subdivision. 
(5)  The relationship of the proposed subdivision with respect to major thoroughfares and plans for widening of major thoroughfares shall be investigated by the proprietor. 
(6)  Standards for sewage disposal, water supply and drainage of the township shall be investigated by the proprietor. 
(c)  It is recommended that a pre-application meeting be held for the project prior to submission of the preliminary plat. The purpose of the meeting is to conduct an informal review of the proprietor's concept plan for the preliminary plat. 
(1)  The meeting may be requested by the proprietor by submitting a written request to the chairperson of the county plat board and submitting copies of a concept plan for the preliminary plat to the township and to each officer or agency entitled to review the preliminary plat, including the road commission for the county, the county water resources commissioner, the state department of transportation (if abutting a state trunk line highway), the state department of environmental quality, and the county health department. 
(2)  The meeting shall take place not later than 30 days after the written request and concept plan are received. The meeting shall be attended by the proprietor, representatives of each officer or agency entitled to review the preliminary plat, including the county road commission, the county drain commissioner and the county health department, as well as a representative of the township. Representatives of the state department of transportation if abutting a state trunk line highway) and the state department of environmental quality, as well as the township engineer and township planner, shall be informed of the meeting and may attend. 
(3)  In the absence of a pre-application meeting, it is recommended that the proprietor meet with members of the township departments concerned with the standards of this article. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 0401, 10-14-1998; Ord. No. 103.003, 8-10-2011)  
Sec. 46-103. - Preliminary plat. 
The procedure for the preparation and review of a preliminary plat requires tentative and final approval as follows: 
(1)  Tentative approval. 
a.  Filing. 
1.  Ten copies of a valid and complete preliminary plat of the proposed subdivision, together with the petition and supporting data as required by any "procedures guide for petition to plat land in Oxford Township" and the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.), shall be filed with the township clerk. The township clerk shall retain one copy of the plat for the clerk's records and forward the balance of the plats to the planning commission. 
2.  The preliminary plat shall be prepared in accordance with the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.) and in accordance with the requirements of this article. 
3.  The proprietor shall deposit the sum required to cover costs of reviewing all engineering plans and layout, said deposit to be made at the time the preliminary plat is submitted to the clerk. 
b.  Identification and description . The preliminary plat shall include: 
1.  The proposed name of the subdivision. 
2.  Location by section, town and range or by other valid legal description. 
3.  Names and addresses of the proprietor and the planner, designer, engineer or surveyor who designed the subdivision layout. The proprietor shall also indicate his interest in the land. 
4.  Scale of plat; one inch equals 100 feet is the minimum acceptable scale. 
5.  Date. 
6.  North point. 
c.  Existing conditions. The preliminary plat shall include the following: 
1.  An overall area map at a scale of not less than one inch equals 2,000 feet showing the relationship of the subdivision to its surroundings, such as section lines and/or major streets or collector streets, shall be provided. 
2.  The boundary line of the proposed subdivision, section or corporation lines within or adjacent to the tract and overall property dimensions. 
3.  Property lines of contiguous adjacent tracts of subdivided and unsubdivided land shown, including roadways up to 300 feet in relation to the tract proposed for subdivision, including those of areas across abutting roads with those unplatted landowners being designated by name. 
4.  Location, widths, and names of existing or prior platted streets and private streets, and public easements within or adjacent to the tract being proposed for subdivision, including those located across abutting roads. 
5.  Location of existing sewers, water mains, storm drains and other underground facilities within or adjacent to the tract being proposed for subdivision. 
6.  Location of major stands of trees within the tract proposed for subdivision, as well as a written description of such stand of trees, including types of trees. 
7.  Existing topography drawn at contours with an interval of at least two feet in elevation, except, if the grade exceeds five percent, the contour interval shall be five feet. Topography shall be based on USGS datum. Benchmarks for the work shall be indicated on the plat. The contours shall extend a minimum of 150 feet beyond the boundary of the plat. 
8.  The school board or school board superintendent of the school district having jurisdiction in the area concerned shall be informed and made aware of the proposed preliminary plat by the proprietor. A copy of the letter to the school board or school board superintendent shall be submitted to the township clerk with the preliminary plat. 
d.  Proposed conditions . The preliminary plat shall include the following: 
1.  The layout of streets, indicating proposed street names, right-of-way widths, and connections with adjoining platted streets and also the widths and location of alleys, easements and public walkways. 
2.  Lot layout, numbers, and dimensions, and lot areas in square feet, including building setback lines showing dimensions. 
3.  An indication of parcels of land intended to be dedicated or set aside for public use or for the use of property owners in the subdivision. 
4.  An indication of the ownership and existing and proposed use of any parcels identified as "excepted" in the preliminary plat. If the proprietor has an interest in or owns any parcel so identified as "excepted," the preliminary plat shall indicate how this property could be developed in accord with the requirements of the existing zoning district in which it is located and with an acceptable relationship to the layout of the proposed preliminary plat. 
5.  Proposed preliminary plats with direct access to major and secondary thoroughfares shall provide acceleration and deceleration lanes where traffic safety so requires as determined by the township board. Such paving standards shall be determined by the road commission for the county and the state department of transportation (MDOT). 
6.  An indication of the required underground utilities to the proposed subdivision line (refer to section 46-163(a)). 
7.  An indication of system for sewage to the proposed subdivision line (refer to section 46-163(b)). 
8.  An indication of system proposed for water supply to the proposed subdivision line (refer to section 46-163(c)). 
9.  An indication of drainage, including any retention basins, and point of outlet at the proposed subdivision line (refer to section 46-163(d)). 
10.  In the case where the proprietor wishes to subdivide a given area, but wishes to begin with only a portion of the total area, the preliminary plat shall include the proposed general layout for the entire area. The part which is proposed to be subdivided first shall be clearly superimposed upon the overall plan in order illustrate clearly the method of development which the proprietor intends to follow. Each subsequent plat shall follow the same procedure until the entire area controlled by the proprietor is subdivided. 
11.  If the subdivision is proposed to be developed under a planned residential development or planned unit development pursuant to the zoning ordinance, it shall meet the planned residential development or planned unit development requirements, as applicable, of the zoning ordinance. 
e.  Planning commission review and tentative approval. 
1.  Before the planning commission acts on the tentative preliminary plat, the preliminary plat shall be submitted to the municipal engineer, municipal planner, and all affected departments for review and recommendation. 
2.  With consideration of the comments and recommendations received from the engineer, planner and from municipal departments, the commission shall act on the preliminary plat in due course to ensure that the plat is reviewed and decided upon by the township board within 60 days after the date of filing if a pre-application meeting was held, and 90 days if a pre-application meeting was not held. However, the proprietor may agree to an extension in writing of the time required for approval by the commission and the township board. The planning commission shall not act on a preliminary plat without holding a public hearing upon the proposed plat. Not less than 15 days before the date of the hearing, notice of the date, time, and place of the hearing shall be sent to the proprietor and to any other person listed as a notice recipient on the plat at the address set forth on the plat by mail, and shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the township. Similar notice shall be mailed to the owners of land immediately adjoining the proposed platted land. 
3.  Should the commission approve the preliminary plat, it shall notify the township board of this action in a written report and forward the report, together with all accompanying data, to the township board for review. 
4.  Should the commission find that the preliminary plat is not acceptable, the secretary shall record the reason in the official minutes and forward a written report, together with all accompanying data, to the township board and recommend that the township board disapprove the preliminary plat. 
f.  Tentative approval by township board . 
1.  The township board will not review a preliminary plat until it has received the review and recommendations of the commission, providing the commission acts within the appropriate time. Following the receipt of such recommendations, the township board shall consider the preliminary plat at such meeting that the matter is placed on the regularly scheduled agenda. The township board shall take action on the preliminary plat within 60 days after the date of filing if a pre-application meeting was held, or within 90 days of the date of initial filing of the plat as described in subsection (1)a. of this section if a meeting was not held. 
2.  Should the township board tentatively approve the preliminary plat, it shall record its approval on the plat and return one copy to the proprietor. 
3.  Should the township board tentatively approve the preliminary plat with conditions, it shall record its approval on the plat and return one copy to the proprietor. The conditions of approval shall be recorded in the minutes of the meeting. 
4.  Should the township board disapprove the preliminary plat, it shall promptly notify the proprietor, in writing, stating the reasons for disapproval. In addition, the reasons for disapproval shall be included in the minutes of the meeting. 
5.  Tentative approval shall not constitute final approval of the preliminary plat. 
6.  No earth movement, installation or construction of any improvements shall be made at this time. 
7.  Tentative approval by the township board shall confer upon the proprietor, for a period of one year from the date, approval of lot sizes, lot orientation and street layout. Such tentative approval may be extended if applied for by the proprietor and granted by the township board in writing. 
8.  If tentative approval is granted, the proprietor shall submit copies of a preliminary plat to the each agency required according to Sections 112 through 119 of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.112—560.119). 
9.  If tentative approval is granted, then the proprietor may proceed to the final preliminary plat approval process as governed by section 46-103(2). 
(2)  Final approval by township board. 
a.  The proprietor shall file a valid final preliminary plat, as tentatively approved by the township board, with the township clerk together with a certified list of all authorities required to approve the preliminary plat in Sections 112 to 119 of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.112—560.119), and copies of the preliminary plat as approved by the required authorities. Upon receipt of such items, the township clerk shall forward the plat to the municipal engineer and planner, as well as to all affected township departments for their review and recommendations. Such review shall be submitted to the clerk within ten days of receipt. The clerk shall then submit the final preliminary plat and the comments and recommendations of all township departments, consultants and all required agencies to the township board. 
b.  The proprietor shall deposit the sum required to cover the costs of reviewing all engineering plans and layout, said deposit to be made at the time the preliminary plat is submitted for final approval to the clerk. 
c.  The township board shall take action at its next regular meeting or within 20 days of the date of filing, reviewing the final plat for compliance with the tentatively approved preliminary plat. The township board shall grant final preliminary plat approval if the submitted plat is in substantial compliance with the tentatively approved preliminary plat, and shall reject the final preliminary plat if the submitted plat does not conform substantially to the tentatively approved preliminary plat. 
d.  The clerk shall promptly notify the proprietor of approval or rejection, in writing. If the plat is rejected, reasons shall be given and shall be recorded in the minutes pertaining thereto. The minutes of the meeting shall be open for inspection. 
e.  Final approval of the preliminary plat shall confer upon the proprietor for a period of two years from date of approval, the conditional right that the general terms and conditions under which preliminary approval was granted will not be changed. The two-year period may be extended if applied for by the proprietor and granted by the township board, in writing. Written notice of the extension shall be sent by the township board to other approving authorities. 
f.  No earth movement, installation or construction of any improvements shall be made before the proprietor has met the following conditions: 
1.  Final approval by township board of the preliminary plat. 
2.  Approval by the municipal engineer of engineering plans, which shall include the planned setback of structures, public water and sewer plans, plans for road construction, lot grading and runoff pattern, and the location of all utilities. 
3.  Deposits required under division 4 of this article have been received by the township. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 0402, 10-14-1998; Ord. No. 103.003, 8-10-2011)  
Sec. 46-104. - Final plat. 
The procedure for preparation and review of a final plat shall be as follows: 
(1)  Preparation. 
a.  The final plat shall comply with the provisions of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.) and this article. 
b.  The final plat shall conform substantially to the preliminary plat as approved and it may constitute only that portion of the approved preliminary plat which the proprietor proposed to record and develop at the time; provided, however, that such portion conforms to this article. 
c.  The proprietor shall submit as evidence of title to the clerk, an abstract of title certified to date with the written legal opinion thereon, or, at the option of the proprietor, a policy of title insurance for examination, in order to ascertain whether or not the proper names appear on the plat. 
d.  The proprietor shall submit proof that all property taxes and special assessments have been paid on the property. 
(2)  Review . 
a.  Twelve paper prints and one electronic copy of the final plat shall be filed by the proprietor with the clerk and such sums of money as the township board may require in this article, or by other ordinances, shall be deposited. The final plat shall have been processed in accordance with Sections 162 through 165 of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.162—560.165), prior to submission to the township for its review. 
b.  The final plat shall be reviewed by the township clerk and municipal planner, as to compliance with the approved preliminary plat and by the municipal engineer as to compliance with the plans for utilities and other improvements. 
c.  A true copy of the final plat shall be provided to each agency required according to Sections 142 through 167 of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.142—560.167). 
d.  The township clerk, municipal planner and municipal engineer shall notify the township board of their recommendations for either approval or rejection of the final plat within ten days of its date of filing. 
e.  The township board shall review all recommendations and take action on the final plat at its next regular meeting or at a meeting called within 20 days of its date of filing in accord with the procedures of Sections 166 and 167 of the Land Division Act (MCL 560.166—560.167). The township board shall approve or reject the plat, instructing the clerk to notify the proprietor of the decision and to record the reasons for the decision in the minutes of the meeting. A copy of the minutes shall be sent to the county plat board. 
f.  Upon approval of the final plat by the township board, the subsequent approvals shall follow the procedure set forth in the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.). One print of the final plat shall be forwarded to the clerk, one to the planning commission, and one to the building department. 
g.  Placing of required monuments and lot corner markers may be waived by the township board for a period of one year from the date of approval of the final plat by the township board, provided that: 
1.  Monuments or other markers, adequately witnessed, shall be in place at all angles and at all ends of curves in the boundaries of the subdivision. 
2.  The proprietor shall have delivered to the clerk cash or a certified cheek, or irrevocable bank letter of credit running to the township, whichever the proprietor selects, in an amount equal to $100.00 per monument remaining to be placed, plus $50.00 per lot corner marker remaining to be placed. In no case shall the deposit be less than $100.00. 
3.  Such cash, certified check or irrevocable bank letter of credit shall be returned to the proprietor upon receipt of a certificate by a surveyor that the monuments and markers have been placed as required within the time specified. If the proprietor defaults, the township board shall promptly require a surveyor to locate the monuments and markers in the ground as certified on the plat at a cost not to exceed the amount of the security deposited and shall pay the surveyor. Any unexpended balance of the deposit shall then be returned to the party from whom it was received. 
h.  In lieu of the proprietor having installed improvements, the township board shall require of the proprietor, as a condition of final plat approval, a deposit in the form of cash, certified check, or irrevocable bank letter of credit, whichever the proprietor selects, running in favor of the township, for the improvement of public places, other than roads and streets, and the installation of any required public sanitary sewer, water supply, and drainage facilities, to ensure the completion of such improvements and facilities within a length of time agreed upon from the date of approval of the final plat by the township board. The township board shall rebate to the proprietor as the work progresses amounts of any cash deposits equal to the ratio of the work completed to the secured project. The amount of work completed shall be determined by the township board, and shall take into consideration certification of inspections and the township board may retain an amount necessary to ensure that such improvements and facilities will be placed in service and certified complete. 
i.  Three copies of the proposed subdivision restrictions shall be furnished to the township board. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 0403, 10-14-1998; Ord. No. 103.003, 8-10-2011)  
Secs. 46-105—46-130. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - DESIGN STANDARDS 
 
Sec. 46-131. - Generally. 
The subdivision design layout standards set forth in this division are development guides for the assistance of the proprietor. All final plans must be reviewed and approved by the township board in accordance with this article and all other township ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 0500, 10-14-1998)  
Sec. 46-132. - Streets. 
(a)  Generally . Streets shall conform to at least all minimum requirements of the general specifications and typical cross sections as set forth in the design layout standards of this article, and other conditions set forth by the township board and the county road commission. 
(b)  Location and arrangement. 
(1)  The proposed subdivision shall conform to the various elements of the master plan and shall be considered in relation to the existing and planned major thoroughfares and collector streets, and such part shall be platted in the location and width indicated on such insofar as possible. 
(2)  The street layout shall provide for continuation of local or collector streets in the adjoining subdivisions or the proper projection of streets when adjoining property is not subdivided, or conform to a plan for a neighborhood unit adopted by the commission. 
(3)  The street layout shall include minor streets so laid out that their use by through traffic shall be discouraged. 
(4)  Should a proposed subdivision border on or contain an existing or proposed major thoroughfare, the commission may require marginal access streets, reverse frontage or such other treatment as may be necessary for adequate protection of residential properties and to afford separation and reduction to traffic hazards. 
(5)  Should a proposed subdivision border on or contain a railroad, expressway or other limited access highway right-of-way, the commission may require the location of a street approximately parallel to and on each side of such right-of-way at a distance suitable for the development of an appropriate use of the intervening land such as for parks and residential districts. Such distances shall be determined with due consideration of the minimum distance required for approach grades to future grade separation. 
(6)  All entrances to subdivisions of 80 lots or more shall be boulevard streets and designed in accordance with county road commission specifications ("rules and regulations for plat development" or any amendments or replacements thereof). 
(c)  Right-of-way widths; maximum length of cul-de-sac streets . Street right-of-way widths and maximum lengths of cul-de-sac streets shall conform to the requirements of the county road commission. 
(d)  Street geometrics. Street grades, vertical and horizontal street curves and sight distances shall comply with the standards of the county road commission. 
(e)  Street intersections. Streets shall be laid out so as to intersect as nearly as possible at 90 degrees. Curved streets, intersecting with major thoroughfares and collector streets, shall do so with a tangent section centerline 50 feet in length, measured from the right-of-way line of the major or collector thoroughfare, where such minor streets are on a curve with a radius of at least 400 feet which tangent does not make a 90-degree intersection with the thoroughfare being intersected. 
(f)  Grading and centerline gradients . Grading and centerline gradients are required and shall be in accordance with the land improvement ordinance. 
(g)  Street jogs. Street jogs with the centerline offsets of less than 125 feet shall be avoided. 
(h)  Truck wells. Truck wells, and receiving and shipping depots shall be so located as to provide adequate vehicular movement on the site and shall not face directly onto a public right-of-way unless at least 100 feet from the right-of-way, and shall be subject to the review of the county road commission. 
(i)  Driveways. All driveway and private roadways accessing directly upon a state highway shall have the approval of the state department of transportation, and those accessing onto county roads, shall have the approval of the county road commission. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 0501, 10-14-1998; Ord. No. 103.003, 8-10-2011) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 42.  
Sec. 46-133. - Easements. 
(a)  Location of utility line easements shall be provided along the front or side lot lines as necessary for utility lines. Easements shall give access to every lot, park or public grounds. Such easements shall be a total of not less than 12 feet wide, six feet from each parcel. 
(b)  Recommendations on the proposed layout of telephone and electric company easements should be sought from all of the utility companies serving the area. It shall be the responsibility of the proprietor to submit copies of the preliminary plat to all appropriate public utility agencies. 
(c)  Easements three feet in width shall be provided where needed along side lot lines and front lot lines so as to provide for streetlight dropouts. Prior to the approval of the final plat for a proposed subdivision, a statement shall be obtained from the appropriate public utility indicating that easements have been provided along specific lots. A notation shall be made on the final plat indicating as follows: "The side lot lines between lots (indicating lot numbers) are subject to streetlight dropout rights granted to the Detroit Edison Company." 
(d)  Drainage easements, when required by the municipal engineer, the county public works commissioner or the county road commission, shall be shown on the plat. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 0502, 10-14-1998)  
Sec. 46-134. - Lots. 
Lots within subdivisions shall conform to the following standards: 
(1)  Size and shape. The lot size, width, depth, and shape and placement of structures thereupon in any subdivision proposed shall conform to the zoning ordinance. 
(2)  Arrangement. 
a.  Every lot shall front or abut an approved private street or a public street. 
b.  Residential lots of less than one acre abutting major thoroughfares or collector streets, where marginal access streets are not desirable or possible to attain, shall be platted with reverse frontage lots, or with side lot lines parallel to the major traffic streets, or shall be platted with extra depth and extra building setback to permit additional distances between buildings and such trafficway. 
c.  Lot splits. All lot splits within a subdivision shall be decided as follows: 
1.  An application for a lot split shall be filed with the clerk on a form supplied by the township. 
2.  A public hearing shall be held. 
3.  Notice of the public hearing shall be mailed by first class mail to all owners of parcels in the subdivision. 
4.  Expenses of the hearing notice shall be borne by the proponent of the lot split. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 0503, 10-14-1998)  
Sec. 46-135. - Natural features. 
The natural features and character of lands shall be preserved wherever possible. Due regard must be shown for all natural features, such as natural hills, slopes and large trees, natural groves, watercourses and similar community assets that will add attractiveness and value to the property if preserved. The preservation of drainage and natural stream channels must be considered by the proprietor and the dedication and provision of adequate barriers (dams, bulkheads, retaining walls, etc.), where appropriate, shall be required. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 0505, 10-14-1998)  
Sec. 46-136. - Floodplains. 
Any areas of land within the proposed subdivision which lie either wholly or in part within the floodplain of a river, stream, creek or lake, or any other areas which are subject to flooding or inundation by stormwater, shall require specific compliance with the Land Division Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.) and the zoning ordinance, and review by the department of environmental quality, as determined by the municipal engineer. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 0506, 10-14-1998)  
Secs. 46-137—46-160. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - IMPROVEMENTS 
 
Sec. 46-161. - Generally. 
(a)  The improvements set forth under this division are to be considered as the minimum acceptable standard. All those improvements for which standards are not specifically set forth shall have such standards set in accordance with the zoning ordinance or other township ordinances. 
(b)  Prior to the undertaking of any improvements, the proprietor shall deposit with the clerk cash, a certified check or an irrevocable bank letter of credit, whichever the proprietor selects, or a surety bond acceptable to the township board, to ensure faithful completion of all improvements within the time specified. The township board shall rebate to the proprietor as the work progresses amounts of any cash deposits equal to the ratio of the work completed to the entire project. The amount of work completed shall be determined by the township board, and the township board shall take into consideration certification of inspections and the township board may retain an amount necessary to ensure that such improvements will be placed in service and certified complete. 
(c)  Improvements shall be provided by the proprietor in accordance with the standards and requirements established in this division and/or any other such standards and requirements which may, from time to time, be established by ordinances of the township. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 0600, 10-14-1998; Ord. No. 103.003, 8-10-2011)  
Sec. 46-162. - Streets. 
All streets and appurtenances thereto, including private streets to which platted streets connect, shall be constructed with details and specifications approved by the county road commission and the township board. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 0601, 10-14-1998) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 42.  
Sec. 46-163. - Utilities. 
(a)  Requirements for underground wiring. The proprietor shall make arrangements for all local distribution lines for telephone, electric, television and other similar services distributed by wire or cable to be placed underground entirely throughout the area subdivided for residential use, except for main supply and perimeter feed distribution lines which serve areas outside the subdivided area, and except for surface facilities related to underground service, such as aboveground closures or terminals, and such wires, conduits or cables shall be placed within private easements provided to such service companies by the proprietor or within dedicated public ways; provided that overhead local distribution lines within such residential area may be permitted upon written recommendation from the commission, upon advisement from the municipal planner or municipal engineer, and the approval by the township board that overhead lines will not constitute a detriment to the health, safety, general welfare, plat design and character of the subdivision. All such facilities placed in dedicated public ways shall be planned so as not to conflict with other underground utilities. All such facilities shall be constructed in accordance with standards of construction approved by the state public service commission. 
(b)  Sewage disposal. A sanitary sewer system, including all appurtenances, shall be required in all subdivisions outside of the township sanitary sewer district in R1 zoning and all subdivisions in which such subdivision, including successive phases thereof, consists of 50 lots or more and contains any lot which is less than an acre in area, except that this requirement is waived if an alternative method of sewage disposal has been approved by appropriate county and state authorities. 
(c)  Water supply. In the event of the non-existence or non-availability of a municipal water supply, a subdivision water supply, as determined by the municipal engineer, shall be installed by the proprietor in all subdivisions where such subdivision, including successive phases thereof, consists of 50 lots or more and contains any lots which are less than one acre in area. All new subdivision developments, however, within the water district, as defined in section 62-31, where such subdivisions, including successive phases thereof, consist of 15 lots or more shall connect to the water supply system as defined in section 62-31. 
(d)  Storm drainage system. An adequate storm drainage system, including necessary storm sewers, stormwater retention basins, catchbasins, manholes, culverts, bridges and other appurtenances, shall be built in all subdivisions at the expense of the proprietor and maintained at the expense of the owners of record in the subdivision. Adequate provisions shall be made for proper drainage of stormwater runoff from residential rear yards. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 0602, 10-14-1998) 
Cross reference— Utilities, ch. 62.  
Sec. 46-164. - Sidewalks. 
(a)  Sidewalks shall be constructed in accordance with the township's design standards and construction specifications manual adopted by section 42-1, subject to the exceptions and additional requirements contained in this section. 
(b)  A sidewalk shall be located along all public streets abutting a subdivision unless a safety path is required by the township's safety path plan. For all other streets within the subdivision, a sidewalk shall be required on both sides of the street. 
(c)  In those instances where no good purpose will be served by the provision of sidewalks, the township board may waive some or all of the requirements of this section after review and recommendation by the planning commission. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 0603(1), 10-14-1998; Ord. No. 103.001, 10-10-2001) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 42.  
Sec. 46-165. - Public walkways. 
The township board may require public walkways in certain locations not in street rights-of-way. The surface of the walkways shall be paved. Planting pockets for trees and shrubs may be required by the township board. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 0603(2), 10-14-1998)  
Sec. 46-166. - Fences and other screening. 
Fences and other improvements may be required if the commission or the township board determines them necessary to screen or protect the adjacent properties or the properties being developed. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 0602(3), 10-14-1998)  
Sec. 46-167. - Streetlights. 
If the owner desires to provide street or area lighting for the development, the electric wires shall be underground. All construction costs shall be at the expense of the proprietor. All maintenance and usage shall be at the expense of the owners of record in the subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 0603(4), 10-14-1998)  
Sec. 46-168. - Street trees. 
Street trees shall be provided on both sides of all public streets in conformance with this section. 
(1)  Spacing. Street trees shall be spaced generally 50 feet on center, with a minimum of one street tree per lot. For purposes of calculating the required number of street trees, one street tree shall be required for every 50 lineal feet of lot frontage. 
(2)  Size. Street trees shall be three-inch caliper minimum at the time of planting. 
(3)  Location. Street trees shall be located generally between the sidewalk and road (back of curb or edge of pavement for streets with open drainage). 
(4)  County specifications. Where applicable, all street tree locations shall be in accordance with county road commission specifications. 
(5)  Ground cover. All right-of-way areas are to be grass (seeded or sod). 
(Ord. No. 103, § 0603(5), 10-14-1998)  
Chapter 50 - TAXATION[1]

Cross reference— Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money or authorizing the issuance of bonds or other instruments of indebtedness saved from repeal, § 1-11(3); any ordinance levying, imposing or otherwise relating to taxes saved from repeal, § 1-11(13); administration, ch. 2; finance, § 2-111 et seq.; businesses, ch. 14. 
 
Sec. 50-1. - Tax exemption and fee in lieu of taxes for certain housing projects. 
(a)  Findings. 
(1)  It is acknowledged that it is a proper public purpose of the state and its political subdivisions to provide housing for its elderly persons of low and moderate income and to encourage the development of such housing by providing for a service charge in lieu of property taxes in accordance with the State Housing Development Authority Act of 1966 (MCL 125.1401 et seq.). The township is authorized by such act to establish or change the service charge to be paid in lieu of taxes by any or all classes of housing exempt from taxation under the act at any amount it chooses not to exceed the taxes that would be paid but for such act. 
(2)  It is further acknowledged that such housing for elderly persons of low or moderate income is a public necessity, and as the township will be benefitted and improved by such housing, the encouragement of such housing by providing certain real estate tax exemptions therefor is a valid public purpose. 
(3)  The township acknowledges that Hope Seniors Non-Profit Housing Corporation, a Michigan nonprofit corporation (referred to in this section as the "sponsor"), has offered, subject to receipt of a federally aided or authority-aided mortgage or advance, to erect, own and operate a housing development identified as Oxford Seniors Apartments (referred to in this section as the "development"), MSHDA Development No. 883, on certain property located in the township, to serve elderly persons of low and moderate income. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Authority means the state housing development authority. 
Contract rents means the rent payable to the owner of a qualified housing project under the owner's contract for the project, including the portion of the rent payable by the tenant as well as that payable under any governmental subsidy. 
Elderly means those persons 62 years of age or older or who otherwise qualify pursuant to the rules and regulations or practices of HUD or the authority for residency in an elderly housing project. 
Elderly housing project means a specific parcel of property, or divisible portion thereof, improved for rental to a low or moderate income individual which qualifies as an elderly housing project under the rules and regulations or standard practices of HUD or the authority to the extent it is occupied by the elderly or held for rental exclusively to the elderly. 
HUD means the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development. 
Mortgage loan means a loan made by the authority or insured by HUD to the sponsor for the construction and permanent financing of an elderly housing project. 
Utilities means fuel, public water, public sanitary sewer service and/or electrical service. 
(c)  Class of housing projects. It is determined that the class of housing projects to which the tax exemption shall apply and for which a service charge shall be paid in lieu of such taxes shall be elderly housing projects which are financed or assisted pursuant to Public Act No. 346 of 1966 (MCL 125.1401 et seq.). It is further determined that Oxford Senior Apartments is of this class. 
(d)  Exemption granted; payment in lieu of taxes. 
(1)  That portion of an elderly housing project exclusively and especially designated for and occupied by elderly persons of low and moderate income developed and constructed upon a parcel of land within the township sufficient for the operation of such project (but no larger) shall be exempt from all property taxation upon commencement of construction and continuing as long as the mortgaged loan insured by HUD or assisted or financed by the authority remains outstanding and unpaid and as long as HUD or the authority has any interest in such property, and shall be subject to a service charge in lieu of such property taxes in an amount equal to zero percent of contract rents of the preceding calendar year, exclusive of utility charges paid by tenants or the project. 
(2)  Notwithstanding subsection (1) of this subsection, in no event shall the service charge, at any time, be less than the property taxes upon the subject property for the tax year prior to the date when construction was commenced. 
(e)  Collection procedures. The service charge in lieu of taxes as determined under this section shall be payable in the same manner as general property taxes are payable in the township, except that the annual payment shall be paid on or before July 1 of each year. The entire tax collection procedure provided by the General Property Tax Act (MCL 211.1 et seq.) shall be effective with respect to such payment, including, but not by way of limitation, the provisions providing for interest and penalties on late payments, return of delinquent taxes and the sale of lands for delinquent taxes. 
(f)  Contractual effect of provisions. Notwithstanding the provisions of section 15a(5) of Public Act No. 346 of 1966 (MCL 125.1415a(5)) to the contrary, a contract between the township and the sponsor naming HUD or the authority as a third-party beneficiary thereunder to provide tax exemption and accept payments in lieu thereof pursuant to the provisions of this section is effectuated by this section. 
(Ord. No. 81, §§ 2—7, 1-8-1992; Ord. of 4-8-1992)  
Sec. 50-2. - Application fee for redevelopment tax abatements or tax exemptions. 
(a)  Purpose. It is the purpose of this section to impose license application fees to help defray the costs incurred by the township when the township processes applications for tax exemptions or abatements which have been filed pursuant to Public Act No. 198 of 1974 (MCL 207.551 et seq.), the Commercial Redevelopment Act (MCL 207.651 et seq.), and/or the Technology Parks Development Act (MCL 207.701 et seq.). 
(b)  Definition. In this section, the term "statute providing tax abatements or tax exemptions to certain facilities" shall mean the acts referred to in subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  Universal application fee. Notwithstanding any other requirements imposed by state laws or regulations, each application to the township for tax abatement or tax exemption pursuant to a statute providing tax abatement or tax exemption shall not be received for filing by the township clerk unless the application is accompanied by a nonrefundable application fee of $1,000.00. 
(d)  Additional application fee where resultant tax benefit would exceed $20,000.00. 
(1)  If the tax exemption or tax abatement sought by a single application made pursuant to a statute providing tax abatement or tax exemption would, if granted, result in a tax benefit of $20,000.00 or more to the applicant, such application shall not be received for filing by the township clerk unless the application is accompanied by a license application fee of $2,500.00, which fee shall be in addition to the fee set forth in subsection (c) of this section. This additional application fee shall be maintained by the township in a separate account, and shall be used by the township to defray actual township costs resulting from the application, including review of matters relating to the application by professional consultants and staff employed by the township. 
(2)  Upon the payment by the township of any costs resulting from the application, the township clerk shall send a notice to the applicant setting forth the amount of the payment made and the name and address of the payee. The applicant shall thereafter remit to the township, within five days of the date of such notice, payment of an additional fee equal to the amount of the payment set forth in the notice. The additional fee shall be deposited in the account maintained for the application. Any balance remaining in the account after completion of the application process will be returned to the applicant. 
(e)  Multiple abatement or exemption requests on single application. A single application containing multiple abatement and/or exemption requests shall be considered as multiple applications for the purpose of determining fees set forth in this section. A fee in the amount established by resolution shall be imposed for each request, and an additional fee in the amount established by resolution shall be imposed for each request which would, if granted, result in a tax benefit of $20,000.00 or more to the applicant. 
(f)  Payment of fees to be made by certified check. Payment of all fees set forth in this section must be made by certified check made payable to township clerk. 
(Ord. No. 86, §§ 1—6, 11-14-1992)  
Chapter 54 - TELECOMMUNICATIONS[1]
