Any lot or area designated as a free public parking lot shall be restricted to 24 consecutive hours of parking with certain rules and regulations as designated by resolution of the township board. All time limits will be posted in the parking area and will be authorized and subject to change by resolution of the township board. 
(Ord. No. 70, § 3, 7-20-1989)  
Chapter 62 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 10; businesses, ch. 14; environment, ch. 22; stormwater drainage and land improvement control, § 22-61 et seq.; public water supply protection, § 22-191 et seq.; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 42; electric and gas supply franchises, § 42-31 et seq.; subdivisions, ch. 46; improvements to utilities in subdivisions, § 46-163; telecommunications, ch. 54. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 62-1—62-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - WATER SYSTEM 
 
Sec. 62-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Abandoned well means a well which is no longer used, or a well which is in such disrepair that its continued use for the purpose of obtaining potable groundwater is impractical, or a well which is a threat to groundwater resources, or a well which is or may be a health or safety hazard. 
As-built plans means engineering drawings prepared after installation of a water system which shall show a statement by a registered engineer or surveyor certifying this to be "as-built plans" and shall include, but not be limited to, length of mains, supply pipes and services pipes where applicable, their locations with respect to property lines, joints used and mechanical, electrical and structural details for pumps, wellhouses and a minimum of two witnesses to hydrants, valves and other necessary appurtenances and other parts of the water supply system and be of sufficient detail to comply with standards of the county water resources commissioner's ("OCWRC") office and to enable the township engineer to insert the water system changes into the current township hydraulic model. 
Base connection charge means that charge by the township for the connection of any premises or structure to the water supply system, and is equal to the base fee for one residential equivalent unit times the number of residential equivalent units assigned a premises or structure use as established from time to time by the township board by resolution. 
Charges for water supply services and charges mean the amount charged to each premises in the township connected to the system for water supply services, which may include those charges as set forth in section 62-41(a) and as may be established from time to time by the township board by resolution in an equitable manner to cover the costs of the water supply service. 
Contaminant is a biological, chemical, physical, or radiological component in water that is or may become injurious to public health, safety, or welfare. 
County means County of Oakland, Michigan. 
County connection charge means a charge by the OCWRC office paid coincident to the payment of the base connection charge at the time of connection to the water system. This charge is based upon water line size as well as costs associated with turning water on and off for a premises or structure. 
Cross connection means a temporary or permanent connection or arrangement of piping (link) between a potential source of pollution and a potable water supply through which a backflow could occur. 
Developer means the proprietor of multiple structures or multiple premises, and includes proprietors of a subdivision, condominium subdivision, shopping center, office building, apartments, industrial structures, manufactured housing, etc. 
Engineering standards ordinance means the township engineering design standards ordinance set forth in section 42-1 of this Code. 
Groundwater is subsurface water in a zone of saturation. 
Main and water main mean those pipes, other than supply pipes and service pipes, used for conveying or distributing water. 
Premises means that entity of use within a structure consisting of a separate ownership or tenancy, and shall also mean that use where no structure exists, but to which water supply service is made available to real property, including areas of landscape. 
Remote meter reader means a water meter placed upon a structure obtaining water from the public water system which collects consumption, diagnostic, and status data from the water meter and transfers that data to a central database for billing, troubleshooting, and analyzing. 
Residential equivalency unit, REU and unit mean that measure of potential water consumption equal to the quantity ordinarily consumed by occupants of a residence by a single family of average size. The number of units assigned to any premises or type of premises by the township board is designed to represent the potential water consumption thereof as a multiple of the quantity ordinarily consumed by occupants of a residence by a single family of average size as determined from time to time by the township board by resolution. 
Service pipe means a pipe extending from the property line or curb cock or valve into the premises supplied with water. 
State means the State of Michigan. 
Structure means a building to which water supply service is made available. 
Structure requiring potable water is a structure where the use of potable water is needed or intended including those used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or other purposes requiring the need for the use of potable water. 
Supply pipe means a pipe tapped into a main and extending thence to and including the curb cock or valve at the property line. 
Township means the Charter Township of Oxford, Oakland County, Michigan, and where the township has assigned its authority, it may include the assignee of the township. 
Usage charge means that charge as determined by the township board for the volume of water used by premises and, in the case of no usage, a minimum charge as established by the township board by resolution. 
Water booster station means a facility within the water supply system that is utilized to increase water pressure at certain designated points within the water supply system. 
Water district means that portion of township designated by resolution of the township board which is serviced or is to be serviced by the water supply system. The establishment of the water district does not constitute a representation that the township will extend the water supply system to this area. 
Water supply services means the transportation, distribution and sale of water to the premises or structure(s) connected, directly or indirectly, to the water supply system. 
Water supply system, water system and system mean collectively all plants, wells, well houses, storage tanks, pumps, work, properties and instrumentalities, as they shall from time to time exist, which are used or useful in connection with the obtaining of a water supply and/or the distribution of water by the township, including all extensions, enlargements and improvements thereto which are owned and operated by the township directly or through contract with the county. 
(Ord. No. 105.A, art. I, 8-9-2000; Res. of 2-8-2017) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 62-32. - Penalties. 
Unless stated otherwise in this article, violations of this article are a municipal civil infraction. 
(Ord. No. 105.A, § 12.3, 8-9-2000; Res. of 2-8-2017)  
Sec. 62-33. - Variances to article. 
(a)  The township board may grant a variance from the requirements of this article. Such a variance from the terms of this article shall not be granted by the township board unless and until: 
(1)  An applicant submits a written request to the township water and sewer committee for a variance from the requirements of this article and otherwise demonstrates that compliance with the terms of this article is impracticable and the premises is otherwise serviced by an existing source of water that conforms with the requirements of the county health division and/or state department of environmental quality ("MDEQ"). 
(b)  The township water and sewer committee shall make an investigation of the written application and may consult with the township engineer and other professionals pursuant to that investigation. The water and sewer committee shall make a recommendation to the township board upon a variance request after a public hearing, with notice delivered or mailed, with proof of mailing retained, to the applicant and the owners of property within 300 feet of the subject property. 
(c)  The township water and sewer committee shall make findings of fact based upon competent evidence that the requirements of subsection (a)(1) have been met. 
(d)  The township water and sewer committee shall further make a finding that the reasons set forth in the application justify the granting of a variance. 
(e)  The township water and sewer committee shall further make a finding that the granting of the variance will be in harmony with the general purpose and intent of this article and will not be detrimental to the public welfare. 
(f)  In recommending any variance, the township water and sewer committee may prescribe appropriate conditions and safeguards in conformity with this article. Violation of such conditions and safeguards, when made a part of the terms under which the variance is granted by the township board, shall be deemed a violation of this article and punishable under applicable provisions of this article. Conditions imposed shall meet all of the following requirements: 
(1)  Be designed to protect natural resources, the health, safety and welfare, and the social and economic well being of those who will use the premises under consideration, and the community as a whole; 
(2)  Be related to the valid exercise of the township's powers, and purposes which are affected by the premises; 
(3)  Be necessary to meet the intent and purpose of this water ordinance. 
(g)  Any variance granted by the township board pursuant to this section shall only continue as long as a source of water, in existence at the time the variance request was granted, continues to comply with the standards of the county health division and/or MDEQ. Should the source of water not comply, the variance shall terminate. 
(h)  The township board shall be the final ruling governmental body pertaining to any and all variance requests, including REU assignment factors and/or calculations. 
(Ord. No. 105.A, art. XIII, 8-9-2000; Ord. No. 105B.001, 11-21-2006; Res. of 2-8-2017)  
Sec. 62-34. - Organization and management; disposition of revenue. 
(a)  The operation, maintenance and management of the system shall be under the supervision and control of the township board. The township may collect revenues for the use of the system. The township board may designate another party or other parties, including but not limited to the OCWRC office, to perform the necessary labor and functions in the day-to-day operation and/or maintenance of the system as well as to provide for the collection of all revenues for the operation, maintenance and improvement of the system. The township board shall have the authority to accept such systems as gifts, as obtained by contract or otherwise, from any person, and may assign all or any part of the authority contained in this article or deed or transfer to the county, the system or any part thereof. 
(b)  To the extent that the township collects any revenue from the collection of usage charges or base connection charges, these revenues shall be received into the township water fund. 
(c)  Revenues received into the water fund are hereby pledged for the following purposes: 
(1)  First, an amount shall be directed, if necessary, each quarter, to an account designated "Operations and Maintenance" in a sum sufficient to provide for the payment for the next quarter of all current expenses for administration and operation of the system and such current expenses for the maintenance thereof as may be necessary to preserve the system in good repair and working order. 
(2)  Once sufficient funds have been directed to the operations and maintenance account to pay the current expenses for administration and operation of the system pursuant to subsection (c)(1), remaining funds shall then be directed, if necessary, on a quarterly basis, to a second account, designated "Indebtedness and Bond Redemption," in a sufficient amount to pay any outstanding general indebtedness and/or bond obligations. 
(3)  Out of the remaining revenues in the water fund, there shall be set aside in any quarter, after meeting the requirements for the operations and maintenance account and the indebtedness and bond redemption account, if necessary, all remaining revenues into a third account for the purpose of making improvements, enlargements, extensions and repairs to the system, including but not limited to construction of new well houses, elevated storage towers, water booster stations, property acquisitions, etc., which account shall be designated "Improvement Account." 
(d)  No disbursements shall be made from the water fund except to the accounts as provided in this section. 
(e)  All monies in the water fund of the system shall be deposited with a bank designated by the township board. 
(Ord. No. 105.A, art. II, 8-9-2000; Res. of 2-8-2017)  
Sec. 62-35. - Extension of system. 
(a)  Extension of or changes in water mains may be initiated by the township board or by petition from property owners. The township board may refuse to grant the petition, or may grant the petition, and may prescribe the terms and conditions upon which the petition will be granted and may require the written acceptance of such terms and conditions by the petitioners. The work will be done at the expense of the property owners unless otherwise stipulated by the township board, and any and all extensions shall be subject to the provisions of this article. Plans submitted by a petitioning property owner shall be sufficiently detailed to determine whether the extension of the water system is compatible with the water system master plan as defined by the township's hydraulic model. The plans shall conform with the engineering standards ordinance (chapter 42, article IV of the Oxford Charter Township Code of Ordinances). 
(b)  The water system and all water lines, including the supply line and associated appurtenances from the curb cock box upstream in the system, are under the exclusive control of the township board, and all persons other than authorized agents and employees of the township are forbidden to disturb, tap, change, obstruct access to or interfere with them in any way. 
(c)  Any person installing water mains and associated appurtenances at his own expense shall first submit complete plans and specifications, prepared, signed and sealed by a registered civil engineer, for such work, to the township engineer for review and approval, and upon installation such shall be inspected and approved by the township engineer and required county and state agencies before such water mains and appurtenances are put in operation. All construction and extensions of any water main and appurtenances shall conform to the construction standards and guidelines as set forth in the engineering standards ordinance (chapter 42, article IV of the Oxford Charter Township Code of Ordinances). Any extension of the water main shall conform with the master plan for the water system as prepared by the township engineer, and any extension shall be constructed in a manner that will facilitate practicable extension of the water system as determined by the township engineer. Unless already paid and deposited under the requirements of the township zoning ordinance or other township ordinances, a person installing a water main shall deposit into an escrow account an amount sufficient to cover the projected cost of reviewing plans and specifications. The escrow amount shall be set forth in appendix A. 
(d)  Any person whose property lies outside of an unincorporated portion of the township desiring to connect to the water system will be subject to one (1) times the normal connection fees and one (1) times the normal quarterly billing rate. Such parties outside the unincorporated township interested in connecting to the water system shall prior to connection obtain a written franchise agreement as required by the state constitution from the governmental body in which the property is located permitting the township to provide water services to the property. The proposed connection shall be submitted to the township board for review and a decision within the sole discretion of the township board. The owner of the property shall pay into escrow an amount to cover the township's costs for negotiating and reviewing the terms of the franchise agreement with the governmental body in which the property is located. 
(e)  If any new structure occurs within an area for which connection to the water supply system is practicable, such structure shall be required to connect to the water supply system. The determination of practicability will take into consideration the application of associated costs of connection, and location of the structure with respect to the defined water district, and this determination shall be the responsibility of the township board; provided, however that all new subdivision developments within the water district where such subdivisions, including successive phases thereof, consist of 15 lots or more, as defined by section 46-163(c), shall, where capacity exists, connect to the water supply system. 
(f)  No premises shall be granted a certificate of occupancy or be allowed to connect to the water system until the township has received and has approved (pursuant to review by the township engineer) as-built construction drawings for that specific portion of the water system that was constructed for the purpose of providing water service to that premises. 
(Ord. No. 105.A, art. III, 8-9-2000; Res. of 2-8-2017)  
Sec. 62-36. - Service pipes, supply pipes and connections. 
(a)  Before any connection shall be made to any water main, application for such connection shall be made in writing to the township by the owner of the premises to be served, with payment made as established by the township board at appendix A and a connection permit secured. Such applications shall be made on forms provided by the township. By application, the owner, user and/or applicant for a water connection permit by such application agrees to abide by all provisions of this article, water system related rules and regulations of the township board, and county standards and specifications in all respects. The application must be accompanied by the fees specified by township board resolution, which will be returned and the application shall not be granted. The township board, by resolution, may establish rules and regulations related to applications for water service, fees related to installation of such service (including but not limited to engineering review fees, administrative fees, inspection fees, and tapping fees), and the requirements relating to supply pipes, service pipes, gate valves, meter connections, water supply pipes, and the connection thereof. 
(b)  Except as may otherwise be required or allowed by the county, all new meter installations shall have a remote reading register. The cost of this shall be included in the charge for installation of supply pipe and meters, referred to as the "county water connection charge." 
(c)  Except for fire hydrants, water shall be taken and used only through metered water service pipes under the supervision of the township where township water service is available, and no connection through which water may pass from one property to another shall be permitted even though the ownership of both properties shall be the same. 
(d)  Excessive or unnecessary use or waste of water, whether caused by carelessness or by defective or leaky plumbing or fixtures, is strictly prohibited. For disregard of or repeated violation of this requirement, after five days' written notice from the township, the water may be turned off by the township; provided, however, if in the sole judgment of the township the excessive use of water is so substantial that five days' notice would result in a significant loss of water, no prior notice is required. 
(e)  No unauthorized person shall interfere in any way with the supply pipe installed by the township. No unauthorized person is permitted to turn water on or off at the curb cock. 
(f)  All township water used on any premises where a meter is installed must pass through the meter. No bypassing of the meter will be permitted. 
(g)  The refusal or neglect of the owner to equip the premises with the service pipe connections, utilities and/or fixtures as approved by the township shall be sufficient grounds for discontinuance of township water supply to the premises or structure. 
(h)  Those structures connected to private water wells, which wells have developed contamination by any contaminant above the acceptable safe drinking water levels adopted and/or established by the state department of environmental quality, shall, where practicable, connect to the water supply system at such time as the township board determines the water supply system is available to such structure and the existing well shall be deemed abandoned at such time as the connection to the water system occurs. Upon connection to the water supply system, each private and public water well servicing such premises or structures shall be disconnected and abandoned in accordance with the applicable laws and regulations of the state, county and township to prevent contamination of the water supply system. 
(i)  All premises or structures which are on a private or public well shall connect to the water supply system, where available, at such time as the private or public well is abandoned for that premises of structure. The private or public well shall be abandoned in accordance with the standards of the county drain commissioner and/or county health division. Findings: the presence of arsenic contaminants in drinking water constitutes a health hazard requiring the filtration and treatment of all such water in order for it to be potable. By reason of private water wells sampled in the township in 2006 showing arsenic levels above the maximum concentration levels (MCL), through the requirements of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and the county, the township constructed a water treatment plant, the purpose of which was the removal of arsenic contaminants from the water provided by the water system. 
As a matter of public health the owner of a structure requiring potable water shall be required to connect such structure to and obtain water from the water system if the connection is practicable when a new structure is constructed which is not connected to an existing structure which has a potable water supply and, in the case of existing structures requiring potable water, upon the private well servicing that structure becoming abandoned. 
(j)  Upon connection to the water system, the water well on the premises used or previously used for obtaining potable water shall be abandoned in accordance with the applicable laws and regulations of the state, county and township to prevent contamination of the water supply system. 
(Ord. No. 105.A, art. IV, 8-9-2000; Res. of 2-8-2017)  
Sec. 62-37. - Meters. 
(a)  All service connections except separate fire connections shall be metered and shall pay for water at the rate established by the township board by resolution. In no case will water be supplied, except for temporary use with township approval, without the installation of a meter to the premises to be serviced and at other than the established water rate. 
(b)  The supply pipe meter and remote reader shall remain the property of the township or its designated agent and will at all times remain under its control, and subject to the rules and regulations established from time to time by the township board by resolution. 
(c)  The owner of any premises where a meter is installed shall be held responsible for its care and protection from freezing or damage or interference by any person. 
(d)  All persons are forbidden to interfere with or move a water meter from any service connection without first receiving permission from the township. No person shall remove or break any seal on meters or bypass valves. 
(e)  If a meter should fail, it shall be the responsibility of the premises owner to have the meter repaired or replaced within 90 days. If a meter has failed to operate, the premises shall be billed at a rate equal to the greatest water use measurement of that meter taken over the preceding four quarterly billing periods. 
(Ord. No. 105.A, art. V, 8-9-2000; Res. of 2-8-2017)  
Sec. 62-38. - Fire hydrants. 
(a)  Fire hydrants are provided for the use of the township or by such persons as may be specially authorized by the township. 
(b)  No unauthorized person shall open or cause to be opened any fire hydrant without first securing a permit as required by the OCWRC office and without paying to the county drain commissioner the appropriate fee based upon the estimated water usage from the fire hydrant. Proof that the OCWRC office permit has been obtained shall be presented to the township building inspector before the fire hydrant is opened. 
(c)  No person shall in any manner obstruct or prevent free access to or place or store temporarily or otherwise any object, material, snow debris, automobile, or structure of any kind within a distance of 20 feet of any hydrant. Any such obstruction when discovered may be removed at once by the township board or its duly authorized agent at the expense of the person responsible for the obstruction. 
(d)  The township board may establish, by resolution, rules and regulations relating to the maintenance, use, operating, and moving of fire hydrants, lines, and line connections. 
(e)  The township fire department and such other authorized persons shall pay for the water to be used by them at a fixed annual amount as determined by the township board by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 105.A, art. VI, 8-9-2000; Res. of 2-8-2017)  
Sec. 62-39. - Addition of fluoride to water. 
Pursuant to section 12721 of the Public Health Code (MCL 333.12721), the addition of the chemical fluoride to the public drinking water supply of the township by any person is a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 30, § 1, 6-13-1973; Res. of 2-8-2017)  
Sec. 62-40. - Use of water; premises with multiple occupancy; discontinuance of service. 
(a)  No person shall take or use township water from premises other than his own or of which he has possession, and no person shall sell or give away township water from his premises for any purpose except as approved by the township. Under no circumstances will any person be entitled to free water without the express written permission of the township board. 
(b)  Where there is one ownership of a structure that is occupied by two or more distinct family premises or where a business structure is occupied by two or more premises, a single charge for water will be made against the owners of the structure for the whole; provided, however, that where a structure or structures under one ownership consists of several premises, the premises may be served by more than one water service supply pipe and meter upon approval of the township. In multiple meter installations, no master meter will be allowed. When more than one meter is served by one water service supply pipe, all the meters served by the service must operate from a manifold type arrangement. 
(c)  Where a structure was originally serviced as a single premises and was fitted with one service pipe, but is divided into separate ownership, each premises must be connected to the main by separate service pipes and be separately metered, all of which must occur within 30 days after such division. 
(d)  Two or more structures not under common ownership shall not share a common service pipe. 
(e)  Water may be turned off from any premises against which charges stand delinquent for 30 days. Notification of delinquency shall be given the owner of the premises concurrent with the late billing together with a warning of the turn-off date if billing continues to remain unpaid. Where so turned off, the water will not be turned on again until all charges have been paid in full together with late charges, additional penalty sums and the charges for turning the water service on and off, which amount shall be established by appendix A. 
(f)  Where the water has been turned off by the authorized agent of the township for any reason, only authorized personnel shall turn it on again. When this requirement is violated the water may be turned off at the curb cock, in which case the owner or occupant shall, before it is again turned on, pay in advance the charges made by the township board for turning the water off and turning it on again. These charges shall be set forth in appendix A. 
(Ord. No. 105.A, art. VII, 8-9-2000; Res. of 2-8-2017)  
Sec. 62-41. - Water rates and payments. 
(a)  Generally. Water rates and charges to be charged for water supplied and use of the water supply system shall be established by resolution of the township board and shall be subject to necessary increases or decreases to provide sufficient funds on an equitable basis in order to maintain and operate the system in an efficient manner, keep it in good repair, contribute to capital costs and to maintain an adequate reserve for improvements and replacements. These township rates and charges include: 
(1)  Base connection charge. The charge for connection to the system by a given structure or premises will be determined by multiplying a base fee as established by resolution of the township board by the number of residential equivalent units assigned to the type of use of the premises or structure as also determined by resolution of the township board, with the process for that determination being set forth in subsection (h) of this section. 
(2)  Usage charge. That charge as determined by the township board by resolution for the volume of water used by a premise(s) and in all cases no usage charge shall be less than a minimum charge as established by the township board by resolution. 
(3)  Escrow fee. There shall be required an escrow fee for a sufficient amount to cover the cost of professional services, including those of the township engineer, utilized for the purpose of reviewing plans and specifications associated with extension of the water system as set forth in appendix A. 
(4)  Inspection and approval fees. Those fees identified in section 62-42 and appendix A. 
(5)  County connection charge. In addition, the county charges a county connection charge which charge is based upon water line size as well as charges for turning water on and off for a premises or structure. 
(6)  Debt service charge. A charge as determined by the township board by resolution from time to time to assist in bond debt reduction, the proceeds of which may be applied as provided for in subsection 62-34(c). 
(b)  Payment of charges for water supply services. 
(1)  The use of water from the water supply system at any new construction shall only be permitted upon the payment of required charges identified in subsection (a) of this section to the township. The use of water from the water supply system shall not be permitted and the township shall not accept payment on a connection charge until the basement and/or foundation of a new construction has been inspected and approved by the township. At such time as the basement and/or foundation of a new construction has been inspected and approved, the township will accept payment for a connection fee and allow the use of water from the water supply system at the new construction. 
(2)  At the time a person or entity obtains final approval of a site plan pursuant to Zoning Ordinance No. 67A for any new construction, requiring a site plan the township will conditionally reserve the required number REUs of capacity in the water supply system for that new construction for as long as the site plan for the new construction remains valid and capacity is available. For all other construction that does not require a site plan under Zoning Ordinance No. 67A, at the time a person or entity pays for and obtains a building permit for any new construction, the township will conditionally reserve the required number REUs of capacity in the water supply system for that new construction. To continue this reservation, the person or entity must obtain inspection and approval of the completed basement and/or foundation of the construction by the township within 90 days of the date the building permit was issued. If the person or entity does not obtain said inspection and approval within 90 days, the township will have no further obligation to reserve the number of REUs of capacity for the construction. The person or entity shall pay for such reserved capacity at the water rates at the time of payment as established by the township board. 
(3)  Change in premise use. Where a structure consists of multiple premises and there is a change in the use of a premises within a structure, which new use will have a greater number of residential equivalency units assigned to it under the unit factor chart as adopted by the township board, where there is a separate meter for the premises a new connection charge shall be paid for that premise equal to the base connection charge for the new use of the premise less the cumulative base connection charges previously paid for that premises and where there is not a separate meter for the premises and the premises receives its water supply through a common meter to the structure, which structure has multiple premises, a new base connection charge shall be paid for the premises equal to the sum of all base connection charges for all the premises serviced by a common meter given the new use less the cumulation of base connection charges previously paid for all premises within the structure served by a common meter. 
(4)  Inspection and approval fees. Those fees as provided for in appendix A. 
(c)  Usage charges. Usage charges shall be billed and collected quarterly or more often as determined by resolution of the township board. Failure to receive a bill shall not excuse failure to pay the bill when due. In the absence of a township board resolution to the contrary, bills shall be dated as of the first day of a month and shall be due and payable, without discount, as of the last day of that month which shall be indicated on the face of the bill. Interest/penalty at the rate of ten percent shall be payable to the township on all charges for water usage services that are not paid when due. 
(1)  Payment of connection and usage charges and all interest and penalties thereon shall be the personal obligation of the owner of the premises served. Usage charges and all interest and penalties thereon are also the personal obligation of the occupant of the premises served. In addition to the township's other collection rights and remedies contained in this article, the township may enforce these personal obligations by action in a court of competent jurisdiction for a money judgment. 
(2)  As security for the collection of connection and usage charges and all other rates, assessments, interest, penalties and charges for the provision of water supply services to or for a premises, the township shall have a lien upon the premises, effective immediately upon the provision of the water supply services, which except as otherwise provided in this article, shall be enforceable as provided in subsection 62-41(d) and in connection with any sale or transfer of the premises. 
(d)  Provisions. All connection and usage charges and any interest or penalties thereon that have been delinquent for six months or more as of September 1 of each year, plus a surcharge of five percent, shall be certified to the township board for collection on the tax rolls, and upon township board approval, shall be entered by the township supervisor on the next tax roll against the premises to which the charges, interest and penalties relate, to be collected and enforced in the same manner as provided by law for the collection of taxes. 
(e)  Lien for unpaid charges. The lien provided for in subsection (c)(2) of this section and enforcement of that lien as provided in subsection (d) of this section shall not apply to usage charges for water supply services provided to a premises after and for the period of time described in a written notice the township receives from the owner of the premises that: 
(1)  Includes a notice that an identified tenant is responsible for the charges; 
(2)  Indicates the period of time that the tenant will be responsible for the charges, corresponding to the term of the tenancy; 
(3)  Indicates whether there is a written lease or rental agreement with the tenant; 
(4)  Includes a copy of any written lease or rental agreement; and 
(5)  Includes an affidavit of the premises owner, signed under oath and attesting to the truth of all information provided in the notice. Upon receiving such a notice, the township shall deliver or mail, with proof of mailing retained, a written notice to the owner of the premises and identified tenant that water supply services to the premises will be discontinued unless a cash deposit equal to the average annual charge for services, with a minimum use of 1 MCF (1,000 cubic feet) as security for the payment of charges to the operator of the system. This deposit will also include all miscellaneous expenses and assessments such as IPP (Industrial Pretreatment Program), capital charge, etc. In the event that quarterly payments for services provided are not received, the amount due will be paid from the funds on deposit. Once the funds on deposit are exhausted, service will be shut off. Service will not be established until any unpaid balance is paid in full and another deposit equal to four times the average quarterly charge has been paid. The township's notice shall be given in the same manner and include and be subject to the same notices, rights and possible hearing as provided for in subsection 62-40(e). 
(f)  Special agreements. Nothing in this section shall be construed to limit the authority of the township board to contract for the construction of a water supply system or any part thereof where the terms of the contract may be different from the provisions of this section. No prior contract entered into between the township and another person for the construction of any part of the water supply system shall be considered as a precedence in the future. 
(g)  Installment and deferred payment for base connection charge. 
(1)  An owner of a structure or premises may pay the base connection charge in order to connect to the water supply system by installment payments over a five-year period provided the following conditions, in the opinion of the township supervisor, are met: 
a.  The structure or premises seeking to connect to the water supply system was in existence prior to the time connection to the water supply system became practicable and was previously served by an independent source of water supply, i.e., water well, which has become incapable of serving the structure or premises, and the owner of the structure or premises meets the following criteria: 
1.  The structure or premises qualifies as a homestead for the owner as defined under the state's general property tax laws at MCL 211.1 et seq. 
2.  The owner(s) of the structure or premises has a gross annual income of $30,000.00 or less. 
3.  The owner has been a resident of Michigan for five years or more and a citizen of the United States. 
3.  The owner has owned the structure or premises for five years or more. 
5.  The owner is 65 years old or older or is a totally and permanently disabled person, blind person, paraplegic, quadriplegic, serviceman, veteran, widow or widower as these persons are defined at MCL 206.501—MCL 206.532, or qualifies for the homestead poverty exemption pursuant to MCL 211.7u. 
b.  The applicable interest rate will be 5 3/10 percent at the time of connection to the water supply system. 
c.  An owner of an existing structure, who has this home declared as a 100 percent principal residence exemption as determined by the township assessor, may pay the base connection charge in order to connect to the water supply system by installment payments over a three-year period, upon the written opinion of the township supervisor. The owner will be responsible for paying one-third of the base connection charge upon obtaining a permit to connect to the water supply system. The remaining two-thirds are to be paid over equal yearly installments over a two-year subsequent period. The applicable interest rate will be five and three-tenths percent at the time of obtaining a permit to connect to the water supply system. This section does not apply to any new residential, commercial or industrial construction. 
(2)  In the event the structure or premises qualifies to pay the base connection charge by installment payment as set forth in subsections (g)(1)a. and b. of this section, the following shall apply: 
a.  The structure or premises shall make one installment payment each year in a pro-rata proportion of the total charge as calculated over five years (for subsection (g)(1)a. of this section) or three years (for subsection (g)(1)b. of this section). The installment payment shall be due on March 1 of each successive year. Interest shall be charged against the outstanding balance. Each installment payment shall be applied against the outstanding interest first with the balance applied against principal. 
b.  Each installment payment for the base connection charge shall constitute a lien as of March 1 of each successive year and any installment payment delinquent for six months or more shall be certified annually to the township supervisor who shall enter same upon the next township tax roll against the premises or structure and said unpaid installment payment shall be collected and said lien shall be enforced in the same manner as provided for the collection of taxes assessed upon such roll and the enforcement of the lien thereon. Such installment payment as shall be delinquent for six months shall be certified annually by the township board to the township supervisor on or before October 1, of each year for failure of the property owner to pay the installment payment on or before March 1, of the same year. The treasurer of the township shall certify as delinquent such assessment to the Oakland County Treasurer's Office. 
(3)  An owner of any premises against which a water connection charge has been levied who is 65 years of age or older or who is totally and permanently disabled, a citizen of the U.S., a resident of this state for five or more years, and the sole owner of said premises for five or more years, is eligible for the deferment of payment of the base connection charge, under state law. Application for this deferred payment is to be made in accordance with state law, being Public Act No. 225 of 1976, MCL 211.761 et seq. This provision shall not be more restrictive than is allowed by state law as it may be amended from time to time. 
(h)  Residential equivalent units. The determination of residential equivalent units to be assigned for a premises for which connection to the water supply system is required or requested shall be as provided in this section. 
(1)  Except for single family residences with a unit factor of one, the building official shall make a written determination of the Units to be assigned to each premises for which connection to the water supply system is required or requested. The determination shall be based on the existing and intended or proposed uses of the premises as disclosed in property owner petitions and connection permit applications under this section, permit or approval requests under other township ordinances and other township records. The township engineer's determination, which shall identify the use categories from the unit factor schedule that were utilized, manner in which they were applied and the resulting unit factor assignments and required connection charges, shall be delivered or mailed to the premises owner and petitioner or permit applicant (as applicable.) 
(2)  The township engineer's written determination under subsection (h)(1) of this section shall include a written notice that the determination will be final unless a written request for review by the water and sewer committee ("petition") is filed with the township clerk within 30 days of the notice and of the right to submit additional information to or to meet with the township engineer regarding the determination. The submission of additional information to and/or a meeting with the township engineer shall not extend the time for filing a petition or require any additional written notice or determination by the township engineer. However, based on such additional information and/or meeting, the township engineer may modify the initial determination by an amended written determination and notice. 
(3)  Upon the timely submission of a petition, the township shall deliver or mail a written notice to the requesting party and owner of the affected premises ("petitioners"), providing the date, time, location and procedure for the water and sewer committee meeting when the review request will be initially considered. 
(4)  In considering a petition, the water and sewer committee may request additional information from the township engineer, petitioners or other persons, and may adjourn its hearing from time to time. The water and sewer committee shall keep a written record of its proceedings and all information considered, and upon completing its hearing, shall render a recommendation to the township board on the petition, recommending that the board affirm or modify the township engineer's determination. 
(5)  The township shall deliver or mail a written notice to the petitioners of a water and sewer committee recommendation under subsection (h)(4) of this section, that includes the information required by subsection (h)(1) of this section. 
(6)  Upon receipt of the water and sewer committee's recommendation, the township board shall deliver or mail a written notice to the requesting party and owner of the affected premises ("petitioners"), providing the date, time, location and procedure for the township board meeting when the review request will be initially considered. 
(7)  In considering a petition, the township board shall review and consider the recommendation and record of the water and sewer committee proceedings. The township board shall not be required to review or consider information that was not presented to the water and sewer committee, and may adjourn its hearing from time to time. Upon completing its hearing the township board shall render a decision on the petition which may accept, reject or modify the water and sewer committee recommendation, and shall be the final township decision. The township shall deliver or mail written notice of the decision to the petitioners. 
(8)  The provisions of this subsection (h) of this section shall apply to changes in the use of a premises under subsection (b)(3) of this section. 
(i)  Connection of premises for fire suppression. Any premises that connects to the water supply system solely for the purposes of fire suppression shall pay a fee for such connection as determined by resolution of the township board, and shall pay for the usage, if any, of water from such connection at the rate set forth for water usage generally by resolution of the township board; including, regardless of actual usage or lack thereof, any capital usage charge (calculated as if the premises had one REU), but excluding any other minimum usage charge in the event that no water is used in a given billing period. Any such premises shall have a meter installed by the OCWRC office to measure any such usage and shall pay any costs incurred or fees required for such installation by the OCWRC office. 
(Ord. No. 105.A, art. XII, § 12.7, 8-9-2000; Ord. No. 105B.002, art. I, 8-22-2007; Ord. No. 105B.003, art. 1, 5-14-2008; Ord. No. 105B.004, arts. 1, 2, 5-14-2008; Res. of 2-8-2017; Ord. No. 105.B.008, art. 1, 11-8-2017)  
Sec. 62-42. - Inspections and inspectors; payment of costs of locating shut-off valve. 
(a)  Should it become necessary for the customer to have the township locate the curb cock shut-off valve and the valve is not readily located by electronic surface probing as customarily used by the county, the cost of locating this curb cock shut-off valve shall be the responsibility of the customer and shall be considered a charge for water supply services under this article. 
(b)  New water services shall be subject to an inspection by the township or an appointed agent of the township and shall have passed the inspection prior to being placed in service. An inspection and approval fee, as established by appendix A, shall be payable at the time of the inspection. 
(c)  All new water systems, extensions of the water supply system and/or major construction and/or repair of the system shall be subject to appropriate inspections as deemed necessary by the township and shall have passed such inspections prior to being placed in service. The inspection costs shall be borne by the developer or contractor of the new water system, extension of an existing system and/or major construction and/or repair. 
(d)  Any person performing inspections under this article whose duty it may be to enter upon private property to make inspection and examination of the pipes, fixtures or attachments used in connection with the water supply from the water supply system will be provided with such credentials as the township board may deem proper to identify them as authorized agents of the township and/or county. No person shall be entitled to enter upon any private property unless he carries and exhibits such credentials. The type of credentials required shall be determined by appendix A. 
(e)  Upon the presentation of credentials verifying the person is lawfully there on behalf of the township for the purposes provided for in this section, the displayer of such credentials shall have free access at all reasonable hours to any private property, including structures and premises supplied with water, for the purpose of making any inspection of the entire water supply and plumbing system upon such private property. No person shall refuse to admit any such authorized person. In case any authorized person shall be refused admittance, or, once being admitted, shall be hindered or prevented in making such examination, the township board may turn off the water to such premises or structure after giving 24 hours' notice to the owner or occupant. 
(f)  No unauthorized person shall have or wear or exhibit any credentials of the township. It shall be the duty of each and every authorized person, upon termination of their authority, to surrender and deliver to the township at its office all credentials of the township board. 
(Ord. No. 105.A, art. IX, 8-9-2000; Res. of 2-8-2017)  
Sec. 62-43. - Contamination or pollution of water supply. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or undertake such actions as will cause any source of possible contamination or pollution to the water supply system as may be determined by the township engineer or consultant, and in no event shall such occur within a radius of 200 feet from any of the municipal water wells, except for special conditions as deemed appropriate by the state department of environmental quality. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to do any act, or to allow to be done any act, that may contaminate or pollute or contribute to the contamination or pollution of the water supply wells or water supply system. 
(Ord. No. 105.A, art. X, 8-9-2000; Res. of 2-8-2017)  
Sec. 62-44. - Temporary shut-off of service. 
Should it become necessary for the township board to shut off water from any section of the system because of accidents, for the purpose of making repairs or in case of construction, the township will endeavor to give timely notice to the consumers affected thereby, and shall, so far as practical, use its best efforts to prevent inconvenience and damage arising from any such causes. However, failure to give such notice will not render the township responsible or liable for damages that may result therefrom, or from any other cause. 
(Ord. No. 105.A, § 12.1, 8-9-2000; Res. of 2-8-2017)  
Sec. 62-45. - Restriction of water use authorized. 
(a)  Whenever the supervisor of the township, based upon the recommendation of the township engineer, or the county, determines the supply or pressure demands for water cannot be accommodated, general welfare is likely to be endangered or conditions within the water supply system are likely to endanger the general welfare of inhabitants of the township, the supervisor shall, with the assistance of the township engineer, make such finding and prescribe emergency regulations which shall apply in the township for all properties connected to the township water supply system, which may include the following: 
(1)  Sprinkling of lawns and landscaping and all outdoor water use shall only be allowed for properties with even-numbered addresses on even-numbered dates within a month and for property with odd-numbered addresses on odd-numbered dates within a month. 
(2)  Sprinkling of lawns and landscaping and all outdoor water use shall not be allowed. 
(b)  The township supervisor shall cause these regulations to be posted at the township offices and through such other means as may be reasonably calculated to provide notice, including the publication of notices in newspapers, and through posting, broadcast and telecast. 
(Ord. No. 105.A, art. XI, 8-9-2000; Res. of 2-8-2017)  
Sec. 62-46. - Temporary restriction of water use for customers of Great Lakes Water Authority. 
(a)  This section shall apply only to those premises receiving water supplied by the Great Lakes Water Authority (GLWA). 
(b)  Whenever the supervisor of the township receives notification from the GLWA in conjunction with the water and radiological protection division of the state department of environmental quality that the supply or pressure demand for water cannot be accommodated and general welfare is likely to be endangered, or conditions within this water system of the township are likely to endanger the general welfare of the township, the supervisor shall determine that a state of emergency exists and prescribe the following emergency regulations which shall apply in the township for all properties connected to the township water system through the GLWA water supply: sprinkling of lawns and landscaping and all outdoor water use shall only be allowed for properties with even-numbered addresses on even-numbered dates within a month and for properties with odd-numbered addresses on odd-numbered dates within a month. 
(c)  Whenever the supervisor receives notification from the GLWA in conjunction with the drinking water and radiological protection division of the state department of environmental quality that provisions in subsection (b) of this section are not sufficient, or conditions within this water system of the township are likely to endanger the general welfare of the township, the following emergency regulations shall apply in the township for all properties connected to this township water system through the GLWA water supply: sprinkling of lawns and landscaping and all outdoor water use shall not be allowed. 
(d)  The township and the GLWA shall, within 24 hours of notification, cause these regulations to be posted at the township office and publicly announced by means of broadcasts or telecasts by the stations with a normal operating range covering the township, and may cause such announcement to be further declared in newspapers of general circulation when feasible. The regulations shall become effective immediately after notice by the township of enforcement of this section as posted at the township offices. Upon notification from the GLWA in conjunction with the drinking water and radiological protection division of the state department of environmental quality that the emergency regulations are no longer necessary, the township shall cause a public announcement to be made lifting the water restrictions. 
(e)  Any person convicted of using water in a manner contrary to the provisions of this section, or in any other way violating the provisions of this section, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(f)  It shall be the responsibility of the township to enforce this section. 
(Ord. No. 98, arts. 1, 2, 4-9-1997; Res. of 2-8-2017)  
Sec. 62-47. - Cross connection control. 
(a)  Adoption of state rules. The township adopts by reference, as amended from time to time, the water supply cross connection control rules of the state department of environmental quality, R 325.11401 through R 325.11407 of the administrative code. 
(b)  Purpose. The purpose of this section is to promote and protect the public health, safety, and welfare by the prevention and elimination of cross connections, which have been recognized as the cause of public health problems due to the hazard caused to drinking water quality. 
(c)  Administration. The OCWRC office operations and maintenance division shall be the designated authority and administrator of the cross connection control program. 
(d)  Cross connection control plan. Pursuant to Public Act 399 of 1976, R 325.11404 of the administrative code, a comprehensive cross connection control plan shall be developed and submitted to the state department of environmental quality, division of water supply, for review and approval. The plan shall outline the conduct of the township cross connection control program, including the method for performing initial inspections, determining inspection/reinspection frequencies, backflow prevention assembly tracking and testing schedules, annual reporting, generation of compliance, noncompliance, pertinent piping information requests, and water service shut-off notices. Upon approval by the state department of environmental quality, the plan will become an instrument of this section for providing program conduct and policies. Any changes to the approved plan will be submitted to the state department of environmental quality, for review and approval before final approval by the authority/agent. The cross connection control plan will be made available to the public for review. 
(e)  Designation of agents. The authority has the right to appoint a designated agent to administer the cross connection control program and perform inspections in accordance with the approved cross connection control program. 
(f)  Inspections. The authority/agent shall have the right to enter any facility for the sole purpose of inspecting for cross connections. If a facility fails to allow the authority/agent entry, the facility shall be deemed to have a cross connection that is an immediate hazard to the public and, as such, the authority/agent will follow the steps as outlined in the approved cross connection control plan. 
(g)  Discontinuance of water service for noncompliance. If a facility fails to comply in correcting any deficiencies identified during the cross connection inspection and subsequent reinspection, follow-up inspection, and steps as outlined in the approved cross connection control plan, the water service to the facility will be discontinued until such time that the deficiencies are corrected and approved by the authority/agent. 
(h)  Penalty. Violations of this section are a misdemeanor. In addition, at the request of the authority/agent, the corporation counsel may bring an action for injunctive relief or other appropriate action in the name of the people of the township to enforce this section or an order issued pursuant to this section. 
(Ord. No. 97, §§ 1—7, 10-9-1996; Ord. No. 97A, §§ 2-8, 7-10-2002; Res. of 2-8-2017)  
Sec. 62-48. - Sprinkling meter program. 
(a)  All water users within the township water supply system will be eligible to participate in the sprinkling meter program unless the township building department (hereafter for purposes of this article only, the "department") determines that participation in the program at a given premises would endanger the premises or the safe, efficient functioning of the water supply system or any element thereof. 
(b)  Any water user desiring to participate in the sprinkling meter program shall make written application to the township for the installation of the sprinkling meter. If the department determines that the applicant is eligible, then the applicant shall purchase a sprinkling meter from the OCWRC office. The applicant shall also install any other appurtenances, such as a cross connection/backflow preventer, that are required by the OCWRC office. If the township board determines that the administration of the sprinkling meter program imposes costs upon the township, then the township is authorized to set a fee for processing applications by resolution of the township board to defray such costs. The function of such sprinkling meter shall be to measure the quantity of water used that is not discharged into the township sewer system. All such meters shall be installed inside the premises. 
All sprinkling meters shall be permanently plumbed into the water system of the premises as mandated by the OCWR commissioner. No sprinkling meters shall be hooked to spigots or faucets. In the event that sewer usage is billed or allocated according to usage (as opposed to capacity), then no premises shall have its sewer usage adjusted unless any sprinkling meter upon such premises is in compliance with this article. The applicant shall contact the department in advance of the placement of a sprinkling meter to verify its location and compliance with these provisions. 
(c)  No water user participating in the sprinkling meter program shall cause or allow any water measured by the sprinkling meter to be discharged into the township sewer system. Any violation of this provision shall be a violation of this section; in addition to any other penalties set forth in this section or by law, such violation shall subject the water user to any sewer usage charge for the entire water measured by the sprinkling meter since its initial installation and, in addition, a penalty of ten percent shall apply. 
(d)  Meter(s) and remote reader(s) shall remain the property of the township or its designated agent and will at all times remain under its control, and subject to the rules and regulations established from time-to-time by the township water system ordinance. 
(e)  The owner of any premises where a meter is installed shall be held responsible for its care and protection from freezing or damage or interference by any person. 
(f)  All persons are forbidden to interfere with or move a water meter from any service connection without first receiving permission from the township. No person shall remove or break any seal on meters or bypass valves. 
(g)  In the event a meter should fail, it shall be the responsibility of the premises owner to have the meter repaired or replaced within 90 days. In the event a meter has failed to operate, the premises shall be billed at a rate equal to the greatest water use measurement of that meter taken over the preceding four quarterly billing periods. 
(h)  No determination of water usage made under the sprinkling meter program shall apply retroactively or entitle a water supply system user to a determination of usage prior to the connection of the sprinkling meter. 
(Ord. No. 105B.005, art. 1, 7-9-2008; Ord. No. 105B.006, art. 1, 5-13-2009; Res. of 2-8-2017)  
Secs. 62-49—62-80. - Reserved.

RESOLUTION 
REGARDING APPENDIX A OF CHAPTER 62 OF
THE OXFORD CHARTER TOWNSHIP CODE OF ORDINANCES 
WHEREAS, Section 62-31 of Chapter 62, Article II of the Oxford Charter Township Code of Ordinances provides that the Township Board shall establish a Water District to be serviced by the Water supply system. 
NOW THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED, that the Water District shall be set forth in Exhibit 1 to this Appendix A. 
WHEREAS, 62-41(a)(1) of Chapter 62, Article II of the Oxford Charter Township Code of Ordinances provides for a base fee to be multiplied by the Residential Equivalent Unit ("REU") assigned to each Premises for the purpose of determining Base Connection Charges. 
NOW THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED, that the amount of each base fee shall be $6,075.00. 
WHEREAS, Section 62-35(c) and Section 62-41(a)(3) of Chapter 62, Article II of the Oxford Charter Township Code of Ordinances provides for an escrow deposit for payment of profesional services, including those of the Township Engineer associated with the review of plans and specifications for the extension of the Water System. 
NOW THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED, that the amount of such escrow pursuant to 62-35(c) shall be $1,500. 
WHEREAS, 62-41 of Chapter 62, Article II of the Oxford Charter Township Code of Ordinances further provides that a schedule of REU's assigned to a particular Premises shall be adopted. 
NOW THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED that the Unit Factor Schedule attached as Exhibit 2 to this Appendix A is hereby adopted for the purposes of Section 62-41. 
WHEREAS, Section 62-41(a)(2) of Chapter 62, Article II of the Oxford Charter Township Code of Ordinances provides for a charge for the usage of water from the Water System. 
NOW THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED, that the amount of such Usage Charge shall be such amount as determined by the OCWRC office. 
WHEREAS, Section 62-38(e) of Chapter 62, Article II of the Oxford Charter Township Code of Ordinances provides for a fixed annual charge for the township's fire department usage of water from the Water System. 
NOW THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED, that the annual charge for such water usage shall be such amount as determined by the OCWRC office. 
WHEREAS, 62-36(a) and Section 62-42(b) of Chapter 62, Article II of the Oxford Charter Township Code of Ordinances provide for an inspection and approval fee for water service connections. 
NOW THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED, that the amount of such inspection and approval fees shall be as determined by the Charter Township of Oxford approved Fee Schedule. 
WHEREAS, Section 62-40 of Chapter 62, Article II of the Oxford Charter Township Code of Ordinances provides for a fee for the Township to turn water on and off in the event of a billing delinquency. 
NOW THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED, that the amount of such fee shall be the amount as determined by the OCWRC office. 
WHEREAS, Section 62-41(g) of Chapter 62, Article II of the Oxford Charter Township Code of Ordinances provides for payment of a base Connection Charge by installment and provides that the Township may charge interest for payment by installment. 
NOW THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED, that the amount of such interest shall be (8) percent reflecting the amount permissible pursuant to MCL 41.727(3) where no bonds have been issued. 
WHEREAS, Section 62-41(i) of Chapter 62, Article II of the Oxford Charter Township Code of Ordinances provides for payment of a fee for connection of a premises for purposes of fire suppression. 
NOW THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED, that the amount of such fee shall be $6,075.00. 
WHEREAS, Section 62-48(g) of Chapter 62, Article II of the Oxford Charter Township Code of Ordinances provides for payment of a fee for processing sprinkling meter applications. 
NOW THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED, that the fee for processing sprinkling meter applications shall be $640.00 for a dual meter. 
WHEREAS, Section 62-42(d) of Chapter 62, Article II of the Oxford Charter Township Code of Ordinances further requires persons entering private property for the purpose of inspecting, examining and/or maintaining the Water Supply System to present certain credentials to property owners to identify these persons as authorized agents of Oxford Township and Oakland County. 
NOW THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED that the following shall constitute the credentials required: 
1.  Any person employed by the Charter Township of Oxford shall possess a laminated identification card which contains a photograph of the employee, the employee's name and the employee's title. 
2.  Any person not employed by the Charter Township of Oxford, but under contract with the Charter Township of Oxford, shall possess an identification card, signed by the Township Clerk or Supervisor, specifically identifying that person and authorizing that person to inspect, examine and/or maintain the Water supply system. 
3.  Any person employed by the County of Oakland shall possess such an identification card and in such form as required by the County of Oakland.
